column2: Kurt Adzema Chief Financial Officer, Principal Accounting Officer and Executive Vice President of Finance
column3: Kurt Adzema Chief Financial Officer, Principal Accounting Officer and Executive Vice President of Finance
column4: Kurt Adzema Chief Financial Officer, Principal Accounting Officer and Executive Vice President of Finance
column5: Kurt Adzema Chief Financial Officer, Principal Accounting Officer and Executive Vice President
column6: Kurt Adzema Chief Financial Officer, Principal Accounting Officer and Executive Vice President

column8: Kurt Adzema Chief Financial Officer, Principal Accounting Officer and Executive Vice President of Finance

column12: Kurt Adzema Chief Financial Officer, Principal Accounting Officer and Executive Vice President of Finance

column2:
Thanks, Jerry. Sale of products for datacom applications increased by $18.2 million or 8.2% compared to the preceding quarter. This is primarily -- is the result of strong demand for our transceivers that address Wireless applications. The sale of products for telecom applications increased by $3.4 million or 4.1% compared to the preceding quarter.


In the fourth -- in the first quarter, we had one 10% or greater customer. Our Top 10 customers represented 57.7% of total revenues, compared to 60.9% in the preceding quarter. Non-GAAP gross margin decreased to 32% from 34.2% in the preceding quarter primarily driven by less favorable product mix, primarily the result of increased sales of transceivers that address Wireless applications and lower sales of 100 gigabit Ethernet transceivers, as well as an increase in depreciation as the result of an increased level of capital expenditures.


Non-GAAP operating expenses increased to $69.4 million from $65.9 million in the preceding quarter. This is primarily the result of the impact of a full quarter of the operating expenses associated with the acquisition of u2t Photonics, which closed during the fiscal fourth quarter; the acquisition of LightSmyth, which occurred during the first fiscal quarter; the costs associated with higher revenue levels during the quarter; the employer portion of payroll taxes associated with annual vesting of RSUs, which occurs every June; and higher legal expenses associated with multiple current ongoing patent litigations.


Non-GAAP operating income decreased $3.5 million to $35.4 million or 10.8% of revenue compared to $38.9 million or 12.7% of revenue in the preceding quarter primarily as the result of lower gross margin and higher operating expenses. Non-GAAP operating -- non-GAAP income was $33.3 million or $0.32 per diluted share compared to $37 million or $0.36 in the preceding quarter. Average diluted shares for non-GAAP purposes totaled approximately 106 million. This includes the impact of converting the $40 million of outstanding principal amount of our 5% coupon convertible notes to equity for purposes of calculating EPS. Therefore, you need to add back approximately $539,000 of interest expense and other costs associated with the 5% convertible notes to calculate diluted EPS.


For non-GAAP purposes, our $258 million of 0.5% convertible notes due in 2033, the interest expense associated with these convertible notes was approximately $323,000 in Q1. This interest expense is the only impact of these converts on our non-GAAP diluted earnings per share. For purposes of calculating non-GAAP diluted earnings per share for Q1, no shares are added as the result of the issuance of these notes. Non-GAAP taxes are expected to be approximately 6% for the remainder of the fiscal year.


Weighted average fully diluted shares for the fiscal second quarter are expected to be approximately 106 million for non-GAAP purposes. First fiscal quarter capital expenditures totaled $44.2 million. Depreciation increased $2.1 million in the fiscal first quarter. Capital expenditures are expected to be approximately $45 million in the fiscal second quarter primarily driven by the continued construction on the exterior shell of the second building of our new Wuxi, China factory. Second quarter depreciation is expected to increase approximately $2 million.


Cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments decreased $15.6 million to $497.4 million at the end of the first quarter compared to $513 million at the end of the preceding quarter. This is principally is the result of capital expenditures of $44.2 million, increase of inventory of $10.4 million, partially due to the acquisition of LightSmyth, increased accounts receivable of $6.3 million due to higher revenue levels and the reduction of accrued compensation of approximately $10 million primarily due to the payment of fiscal year end bonuses. There are a number of noncash or infrequently occurring charges and benefits, which we exclude from non-GAAP results, these totaled $19.1 million last quarter. We included all these items as required under GAAP with generated net income of $14.2 million or $0.14 per diluted share compared to $28.8 million or $0.28 per diluted share in the preceding quarter.


That concludes my comments and I'll turn it over to Eitan.
So Alex, I'll talk a little bit about the margins and I'll hand it over to Jerry for your second question. So as we mentioned, the reason the margins declined in the first quarter were the product mix that you mentioned. We sold a lot more Wireless transceivers, our transceivers for Wireless applications, which as you mentioned have lower gross margin. Combine that with the fact we sold less 100G, which has a higher gross margin and the fact that we added approximately $2 million of depreciation. That drove the decline of gross margin in Q1. To your point in Q2, as we sell less Wireless, and that's part of the reason why revenue was declining, a big contributor in Q2, you're right that the mix gets a little bit more favorable but that is offset by the decline in the overall revenue rate, as well as the fact that as we mentioned, depreciation again is going to increase approximately $2 million and we had our annual salary increases that happened at the beginning of the quarter and so that increases our manufacturing costs. So there is a little bit of a benefit to the mix, but the lower revenues and the higher costs offset that.
Well, I think as you point out, the key things driving it are going to be mix and revenue growth and those are obviously, difficult to predict. But I would say to your point, given the Q3 will have 1 month of the telecom price erosion and Q4 will have 3 months, that I think gross margins are going to stay in the low-30s for the remainder part of the fiscal year.
So for Q1, I'd say, the way to answer that question is we saw a slight decrease in 10G, 40G and the 100G Ethernet. And with the areas we saw growth, wherein as you pointed out, the Wireless as well as in the short wave transceivers or some of the Fibre Channel business.
I can take the consolidation question and we're always looking at opportunities for additional acquisitions and consolidation plays, but we haven't done anything at this point. But we will continue to look at those this fiscal year and beyond. In terms of the capital expenditures, we are spending an inordinate amount of money now on capital expenditures. As we talked about, some of that is being driven by the second building that we're building in Wuxi. But I think, ultimately, I think it's a testament to the fact that we ultimately believe in the long-term growth prospects of this business. But we do hope that once the building is completed, that starting next fiscal year, we'll have a lower level of capital expenditures.
We have in the past and we'll continue in the future on an ongoing basis to analyze the potential cash needs of the business both organically and inorganically and the rate of return for the deploying that capital to increase shareholder value. And we'll compare that to the alternatives to return capital and we'll make decisions accordingly. But we feel, as Jerry mentioned, we feel very good about the business. We feel like there's places where we can invest in R&D, places where we can invest in our manufacturing and infrastructure and potentially acquisitions that we can make that can increase shareholder value. So we're always looking at balancing that with the potential to return cash to shareholders.
We don't really comment on specific customers. So I can't really help you on that question.
Well again, I think in terms of CapEx, we're -- this quarter and the next quarter will probably be at very similar levels and then start to see it tail off a little bit again starting in the following fiscal year. But you have to remember, you have to kind of -- given that most assets are depreciated over 5 years, we're comparing the CapEx we spent this quarter versus the CapEx we spent 5 years ago. And that's the reason for the depreciation. We have a very small amount of depreciation rolling off and we've got a higher amount of depreciation being added on because of these high CapEx levels.
I think that sounds about right, Yes.
I guess, I'll take the first question and say again, our customers don't like us to talk about the different parts of the datacom business and split that out. So we can't provide that level of detail at this point.
Well again, it will depend on overall revenue growth and to your point, the relative revenue growth in Wireless versus other parts of the business. So certainly to the extent Wireless grows faster than that is a negative factor on gross margins. But at the same time, obviously, were doing things that we are trying to offset that. I would say typically gross margins in the third quarter, assuming a reasonable level of growth or relatively flat excluding mix. And so obviously, depending on what you assume on mix then that would determine what you assume on gross margins.
Well again, Bill, our customers have specifically asked us not to go into details in breaking apart those 2 businesses. So we are not going to be doing that.
Well, tunable XFP continues to ramp and our visibility is -- what we have right now is that these trends will continue going forward. As far as the overall telecom quarter-over-quarter, we grew, I think between 3% to 4%. And we say that there's some softness going into the Q2. So we expect it to be slightly soft going in here. But it becomes product-specific and the ROADMs -- there's a lot of developments around the ROADMs, the WSSs and the biggest impact on those is going to be when there's going to be a lot more demand from metro application, which we think that's 2015.
Well I think we said a couple of quarters ago, it was approximately 10% and as we said for this quarter, I think it was one of the primary -- the primary driver for the revenue growth we saw this quarter. But we're not going to break that out as a specific dollar amount.
Well, I think, again, given that we've already got one quarter behind us, giving guidance for sort of the second quarter, I mean, I think ultimately, we give guidance for the year then you're asking us to give guidance for Q3 and Q4. But I think what we've talked about in the past in terms of the overall markets and for the long-term, again, I think industry analysts expect this business to grow in kind of in the mid-teens and I think we have shown that over time, we tend to take market shares. So I still think -- we think of this long-term as a mid-teens growth business. And hopefully, if we grow that way, we'll get some leverage in our business and add faster to the bottom line. But, again, we're not going to provide our full year revenue guidance. We just don't have that level of visibility. We have never done that in the past, and we're not in any position to do it now.
Well, I think Jerry said that 100G was going to be a little soft in this quarter and I think again, it's going to be a -- continue to be a very competitive market. A while ago, as Jerry had mentioned, at one point we we're kind of the only game in town for that market, but other competitors have come in. That's the part of the natural process in this industry. But it's still a good product for us and still a good gross margin product for us. It's just not as good as it's been in the past and the revenue is soft.
Well, again, I think revenue growth -- returned revenue growth and obviously, the 10G and above Ethernet business, I think would -- could be a positive factor for that. But it's hard to predict how that is going to offset against the price erosion and the growth in Wireless. So that's why like I said, I think for the rest of the fiscal year, we're going to be in the low-30s in terms of gross margin.
Well, it depends on the revenue growth, right. I mean, you could have the same mix and if you've got a lot more revenue then we would expect margin to improve. If revenue goes down, we would expect it not to improve. So I think that's one big factor you've got to take into account.
I mean, again, it depends on the Wireless growth relative to the growth of the other products and the magnitude of the Wireless growth and the magnitude of the growth of the other products. So I don't think you can answer that question in a vacuum.
Well, again, I think they do have other customers, but as we mentioned from a revenue perspective, it's not material to our revenues. So I think they'll continue to have other customers. In terms of the vertical integration, Eitan can talk about that.
It's not a high labor-intensive component.
column3:
Thanks, Jerry. The sale of products for datacom applications decreased by $25.3 million or 10.5% compared to the preceding quarter. The sale of products for telecom applications decreased by $5.3 million or 6.2% compared to this preceding quarter.


In the second quarter, we had one 10% or greater customer. Our top 10 customers represented 55.8% of total revenues compared to 57.7% in the preceding quarter.


Non-GAAP gross margin decreased to 31.1% from 32% in the preceding quarter, primarily driven by decreased revenue levels and an increase in depreciation. Non-GAAP operating expenses decreased by $2.1 million, primarily due to lower legal costs related to ongoing patent litigation.


During the quarter, the company resolved one of its outstanding patent litigation cases. Non-GAAP operating income decreased $10.4 million to $25 million or 8.4% of revenues compared to $35.4 million or 10.8% of revenues in the preceding quarter, primarily as the result of lower revenue and gross margins.


Non-GAAP income was $23.5 million or $0.23 per diluted share compared to $33.3 million or 32% -- $0.32 in the preceding quarter.


Average diluted shares for non-GAAP purposes totaled 105.3 million. This includes the impact of converting the outstanding principal amount of our 5% convertible notes to equity for the purpose of calculating EPS. Therefore, you need to add back approximately $533,000 of interest expense and other costs associated with the 5% convertible notes to calculate diluted EPS.


Towards the end of the quarter, the company announced its intent to redeem the remaining $40 million of outstanding principal of our 5% converts due 2029. Prior to the schedule of redemption, the holder voluntarily converted such notes into shares of Finisar common stock. The notes were converted in accordance with the existing terms of the notes. $3.4 million were converted for approximately 314,000 shares on the Friday during the last week of the quarter. The remaining 36.7 million were converted during the first week of the third quarter for approximately 3.4 million shares.


For non-GAAP purposes, for our $258 million of 0.5% convertible notes due in 2033, the interest expense associated with these convertible notes was approximately $323,000 in Q2. This interest expense is the only impact of these converts on our non-GAAP diluted earnings per share. For purposes of calculating non-GAAP diluted earnings per share for Q2, no shares are added as the result of the issuance of the 0.5% convertible notes.


Non-GAAP taxes are estimated at 6% for the remainder of fiscal 2015. Weighted average fully diluted shares for fiscal third quarter are expected to be approximately 105.7 million for non-GAAP purposes.


Second quarter capital expenditures totaled $28.4 million. This was less than our prior forecast of approximately $45 million, primarily due to an approximate 1 quarter delay in the completion of the second building of our new Wuxi, China factory as well as the delay of certain planned capital expenditures due to lower-than-expected revenue levels. Capital expenditures are expected to be approximately $40 million in the third quarter, primarily driven by the continued construction of the second building of our new Wuxi, China factory. We now expect the second building to be completed by March 2015, and we expect to have all volume manufacturing moved from Shanghai to Wuxi and requalified with customers by October 2015.


We continue -- we will continue to perform R&D and NPI manufacturing in Shanghai as well as some corporate functions at that site.


Depreciation increased $1.3 million in the second fiscal quarter. Third quarter depreciation is expected to increase approximately $1.5 million.


Cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments decreased $20 million to $477.4 million at the end of the second quarter compared to $497.4 million at the end of the preceding quarter. It's primarily the result of capital expenditures of $28.4 million, increased inventory of $14.7 million, and legal settlement and associated expenses of approximately $13.7 million.


There are a number of noncash or infrequently occurring charges and benefits, which we excluded from non-GAAP results. These totaled $34.8 million last quarter. If you include all these items as required under GAAP, we generated a loss of $11.4 million or $0.11 per diluted share compared to net income of $14.2 million or $0.14 per diluted share in the preceding quarter.


That concludes my comments, and I'll turn it over to Eitan.
Sure. So again, you saw last quarter we did throttle it back some based on revenue expectations for that quarter. But it's really on a product-by-product basis. And there are definitely products where we need to add capacity. And certainly, there's CapEx spent on ramping newer products. So I still think until we finish the second Wuxi building. It's going to be high. And I think that's going to go through, as we talked about -- now it's probably going to go through the end of at least the fourth fiscal quarter and probably a little bit into Q1. But then I think starting in Q2 we could get a more normalized CapEx rate. But as Jerry mentioned, we expect growth in this business and, in particular, in areas like 40 gig, and we're going to continue to add capacity there.
I'll take the gross margin question. So as you think about -- obviously, we don't provide guidance for Q4 gross margin, and it's highly dependent on revenue growth and mix. But as you point out, traditionally, the fourth quarter gross margin is lower than the third quarter gross margin given that there is the full 3 months of the telecom price reductions baked in.
Well, again. We don't provide guidance for Q4. I would say traditionally, Q4 has been relatively flat, again, because you've got all things -- all else being equal, because you've got the full 3 months of the price erosion. But obviously, each Q4 is very different if you look back at history. So again, we're not providing guidance. But in terms of long term, certainly, we think the business is going to continue to grow. It goes back to the prior question about capital expenditures. We wouldn't be spending the money we're spending to make sure we can make the products that our customers demand if we didn't think there was going to be growth. So we're still very confident about long-term growth.
Are you saying if we excluded wireless? I mean, as Jerry mentioned, we expect 40 gig and 100 gig to grow in the quarter. So even without growth in wireless, we would expect the business to grow.
Well, I think it depends on where we are in the range of revenue guidance, right? It's a $15 million range of revenue guidance, so depending on if we're at the high end or the low end. But I think that is going to drive it. But we think there's going to be meaningful growth in 40 gig and also 100 gig in the quarter. It's not just all wireless.
I don't think we can actually predict exactly, if we're at the high end of the range, what products get us there. I mean, it's possible if we're at the high end of the range, that is driven by wireless. But it's also possible if we're at the high end of the range, it's driven by 40 gig. So I think there's a lot of variables, but I think when you take all those variables, product mix, into account, revenue growth and the 1 month of the price erosion, that's how we got our estimate of approximately 31% gross margin.
Well, again, I think as you look at what industry analysts have, I mean, I think for the industry, it's relatively low teens revenue growth, but we traditionally have gained market share. So and our hope is overall revenue to grow in the mid-teens over time. In terms of where we want to get the business, obviously, as we talked about last time, we're kind of at the lows of traditionally where gross margins have averaged. We've been as low as 30 and as high as 37. Our goal is to get them closer to the mid-30s. But we've got but a long ways to go. In terms of OpEx, our goal is to try to drive that closer to being 20% of revenue. But again, we've got a ways to go to that. We're continuing to invest in R&D, as Eitan talked about, but at the same time, we're trying to show some leverage on the operating expense line as we expect to do this quarter.
Yes, Troy. It was at the higher end of the 10% to 15% range again this year.
I don't think there's anything conceptually or philosophically. As Jerry mentioned, we're big believers in consolidation. We think the space needs consolidation. And as you mentioned, there's a lot of activity going on in the space right now, and we will continue to evaluate it. But as always, there's a lot of factors that go into M&A deals and whether or not they get done. And it can be challenging.
No. That detail is in the earning slides, and I mentioned it in the script.
Well, I think inventory going up is not a surprise when revenues were meaningfully -- were lower than expected. So that was not a big surprise. Obviously, we're working hard to reduce our inventory levels and adjust those accordingly based on our current forecasts, so we'll continue to work on that. But that was not a big surprise. In terms of CMI inventory hubs, I don't think we saw anything unusual in the quarter. And again, our forecast typically is based on what our customers are telling us they're going to pull from those hubs in a quarter, which maybe end up being different, but it's our best estimate based on what has been pulled through this quarter so far and what our customers are telling us. So I don't think there was a lot there. In terms of your comment about E&O. Again, that is an accounting exercise, and it is a noncash charge and so it's not a big deal.
No. It's a mathematical exercise, where we basically look at backward looking usage versus the current inventory out there. So I'm not going to get into all the details of what those products would be.
Well again, I think, as we have talked about, I mean, if you assume our revenue was down, then our OEM pulls were down. But as Jerry talked about, some of that was driven by some participants that don't use -- necessarily use hubs. So it's hard to parse that. But I would say that obviously, we expected revenues to be higher, which means probably hub pulls were a little bit less than expected. But our forecast for the third quarter takes into account what we're seeing in terms of current trends of hub pulls.
There was one 10% or greater customer, and top 10 represented 55.8% versus 57.7% in the prior quarter.
Sure. So you're right, I mean, gross, from a product mix perspective, it was relatively favorable given the fact that the wireless stuff carries lower gross margin than our average. But at the same time, you need to remember there was a pretty dramatic drop in volume. And because we're a vertically integrated manufacturer, we've got a fair amount of fixed cost. So I would say it was a favorable mix, but then offset by the drop in volume.
Do you mean quarter-over-quarter?
Yes, so I think for the third quarter for telecom, I would think it's going to be flat to slightly down, given the 1 month of the telecom price erosion. And the growth would primarily, as Jerry mentioned, be from 40 gig Ethernet, 100 gig Ethernet. And the wireless switch we've talked about, we include in our datacom product area.
It's about $28 million. $28.4 million.
Well, we had expected wireless to be significantly down in the second quarter. And I'd say, it was even weaker than we had expected. At the time we gave guidance back in September, our hopes were that we'd start to see pickup again in the wireless in our last month of our quarter. It really didn't happen. But as Jerry mentioned earlier, in our Q3, we expect Wireless to start growing again. And we think that's a growth market overall and for us, but it was just one of those quarters. We had, had a really strong quarter in Q1 and it fell off dramatically in Q2, but we expect it to start to grow again.
It's just test equipment at the end of the day. So we're continuing to add capital equipment. That's driving some of the CapEx that I talked about earlier.
column4:
Thanks, Jerry. Datacom revenue increased by $18.5 million or 8.5% compared to the preceding quarter. Telecom revenue decreased by $9.2 million or 11.3% compared to the preceding quarter primarily due to the impact of 1 month of the annual telecom price reduction that typically takes effect on January 1 and a decrease in demand for transceivers for telecom applications driven by sluggish carrier CapEx levels. In the third quarter, we had one 10% or greater customer. Our top 10 customers represented 56.1% of total revenues compared to 55.8% in the preceding quarter. Non-GAAP gross margins decreased to 30% from 31.1% in the preceding quarter, primarily driven by the impact of 1 month of the telecom price reduction and the impact of substantial yield loss for a new optical engine product for supercomputing applications that we started to ramp into production during the quarter. Non-GAAP operating expenses decreased $2.2 million to $65.1 million from $67.3 million in the preceding quarter. Non-GAAP operating income increased $1.9 million to $26.9 million or 8.8% of revenues compared to $25 million or 8.4% in the preceding quarter, primarily as the result of higher revenue and lower operating expenses. Non-GAAP income was $26.7 million or $0.25 per diluted share compared to $23.5 million or $0.23 in the preceding quarter. Average diluted shares for non-GAAP purposes totaled $106 million. For non-GAAP purposes, the interest expense for our $258 million of 0.5% convertible notes was approximately $323,000 in the third quarter, this interest expense is the only impact of these converts in our non-GAAP diluted earnings per share as no shares are added to the fully diluted share counts. Third quarter capital expenditures totaled $31.7 million. This was less than our prior forecast of approximately $40 million. Capital expenditures are expected to be approximately $35 million in the fourth quarter, primarily driven by the continued construction of the second building on our new Wuxi, China factory. We expect the second building to be completed by the end of the fourth quarter and we expect to have all remaining volume manufacturing moved from Shanghai to Wuxi and requalified with customers by the end of our second quarter of fiscal 2016. We will continue to perform R&D and NPI manufacturing work in Shanghai as well as some corporate functions. Cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments increased $11.4 million to $488.9 million at the end of the third quarter. Non-GAAP taxes are estimated at 6% for the fourth quarter and 6% to 7% for fiscal 2016. Weighted average fully diluted shares for the fiscal fourth quarter are expected to be approximately 107 million for non-GAAP purposes. There are a number of noncash or infrequently occurring charges in benefits which we exclude from non-GAAP results. These totaled $25 million last quarter. To include all these items, as required under GAAP, we generated net income of $1.7 million or $0.02 per diluted share compared to a net loss of $11.4 million or $0.11 per diluted share in the preceding quarter.


That concludes my comments, and I'll turn it over to Eitan.
Well, again, the guidance is reflective of the fact that -- the revenue guidance is reflective of the fact that we'll have the 1 extra week offset by the impact of Chinese New Year. The gross margin guidance is reflective of the fact that we will have 14 weeks of expenses as well as we'll have the full 3 months of the telecom price reduction.
Well, there's always variability of mix.
No, we typically provide a range about that wide. We widened it up a little bit this quarter just to reflect the fact that we've got 14 weeks instead of 13 weeks.
Well, I'd say the impact this quarter of that yield loss was probably about 75 basis points. In terms of the -- and certainly we're working on improving that yield. But as of today, we haven't made as much progress as we'd like, so I think we will continue to be challenged this quarter. But hopefully, by the time we get into Q1, we'll start to see some of the benefit in terms of the revenue opportunity. I think the revenue opportunity right now is still relatively small versus our overall business. But certainly, it's a business that we hope, once we improve the yield, that will be a proven [ph] ramp and sell a lot more. But it's still a pretty small part of our business even though it's having a big impact on our gross margins.
I mean, the way we're guiding telecom for next quarter, we say it's pretty much flat for this quarter. And maybe with the 14 weeks it's flat to slightly up, but no significant change quarter-over-quarter. There's some new products that are coming to the market right now from us, and as they ramp through the year, we should see an improvement. But most improvement, like we were talking before, what will be the driver for telecom, will be the metro, that still has few quarters to go before it becomes meaningful for the revenue on that segment.
Well, I think there are several factors. Certainly, we are focused on trying to keep OpEx relatively flat given the decline in gross margins so that we can improve our operating margin. So there are certainly a lot of focus on that. We did benefit some this quarter based on the continuing strengthening of the dollar. So I think that's part of it. And we did have some expenses that we thought we'd spend this quarter on R&D Project materials that got pushed into next quarter. So I'd say it's a combination of all 3 of those things.
I think, as Jerry mentioned, I mean, 40 gig and I assume you're talking Ethernet side, datacom side, so 40 and 100, it continues to be a very competitive space. And obviously, we're working hard to maintain our margins despite any pricing pressure that we see.
Well, Subu, we changed our fiscal year 2 years ago in fiscal '13. And so for most fiscal years, we have 13 weeks in every quarter and it's only once every 4 to 5 years that the fourth quarter will have 14 weeks. So we've never had this experience before. But as you think about Q1, given the fact that Q1 will have 13 weeks and Q4 will have 14 weeks, then I would expect revenues would decline just based on the pure number of weeks in the quarter.
Well, again, I think in this quarter you've got the benefit of 14 weeks and some partial offset as the result of Chinese New Year. So you have to take that delta and then apply it and then if there was a 13 to 13-week basis, certainly we would expect some level of growth going from Q4 to Q1. So then you should -- once you've adjusted for 13 versus 14 weeks, you should layer in a little bit of growth.
I would say we obviously don't provide guidance, but typically, the first quarter gross margin is higher than fourth quarter gross margin. So hopefully that pattern continues.
It's hard to break that down because, obviously, if the yield improves then we're also shipping more units, and so some of that offsets each other. But certainly, we've seen in the past -- again, we can look at, historically, meaningful improvement in the first quarter gross margin over the fourth quarter.
I would say operating expenses, most of it is variable. So if you look at that, I would say you're probably going to increase about $3.5 million or so this quarter. And then that $3.5 million would go back down the following quarter, but then there's obviously kind of a normal growth rate of operating expenses. And in the third quarter we just finished, we were at a pretty historically low level given some of the pushout in the project material on the R&D side. So I'd say there will be some growth in fiscal Q1 versus fiscal Q3.
Well, certainly, we've got ways to go given our guidance in Q4 of approximately 30%, but certainly -- we're certainly aiming to get back to the mid-30s, but I think we've got a couple of years to get there. So we should see some improvement from the 30% range in FY '16, we hope. Obviously, it depends on revenue growth and mix, but we've got a couple of years where we need to continue to prove it to get to where we really want it to be.
We're hoping to keep operating expenses relatively flat so that we get some leverage to that extent. And our goal is to ultimately drive that close to 20% of revenue over time. That will obviously depend on -- when we get there, will obviously depend on the pace of revenue growth. But certainly we're looking to get some level of leverage on the operating expense line. Realizing that some quarters are going to be lumpy and some are going to be up and some are going to be down, so it's not going to necessarily a be a straight line. But we certainly are driving towards getting some operating leverage at the operating expense line.
Well, again, we're not provided guidance for that. But historically, Q1 has had better gross margins than Q4.
Well, I'll answer it 2 ways. I think capital expenditures after this quarter should start to decline, as I mentioned the building -- the second building should be done this quarter. And so I would expect capital expenditures to start to decline as a result of that. In terms of depreciation, I expect depreciation to continue to increase because, again, we're comparing current CapEx levels with what's rolling off 5 years -- that you spent 5 years ago. So depreciation will continue to increase, but CapEx should come down and the rate of change of depreciation should start to be less.
Well, again, in this quarter, depreciation went up, I think, about $400,000.
So 40G grew the most, followed by wireless and then 100G.
It's always hard to tell quarter-to-quarter, but I think -- we think that 40G and 100G are going to be growth drivers next quarter. I'd say we expect wireless to be slightly up, but our clarity into that business is not perfect.
Again, we're not going to break it out product by product. I would say, tunable XFP was slightly down in the quarter.
Again, we're not going to break out the details of that. We break out telecom, we break out datacom, and will talk directionally about every product line, but I'm not going to break it out.
Well, we said last December nothing has changed since then. It was at the higher end of the 10% to 15% range.
No, we can't tell.
column5:
Well, I think we said both datacom and telecom grew. So I think in general talked about that. I think, again, the strength or the growth in datacom was primarily in 10 Gb and 100 Gb. And we had -- we did have some falloff in our wireless business. On the telecom side, I think we saw a little bit of growth in the WSS as well as I think tunable was a little bit of growth.
I think right now we think wireless in this coming quarter relative to prior quarter will be flat to slightly down given the 13 weeks versus the 14 weeks.
Again, as you think about the fourth quarter, we obviously had the benefit of the 14th week, but that was partially offset by the Chinese New Year. And so if you look at the growth that we had Q3 to Q4, that was about $14 million. So when you're thinking about next quarter, it's hard to exactly say what the impact of both those things were, but I think that's something. You can use that metric.
I don't think there's anything else I can say.
Well, if you're comparing this -- the forecast for this Q1, I believe, to last year's Q1, we did have a big spike in last year's Q1 because of wireless. And as we noted, wireless was -- has been down and we expect it to be probably flat to down a little bit again this quarter based on the 13- to 14-week basis.
Well, you're talking -- Mark, you're talking about the wireless in China, the CPRI wireless. So that's what we said. The majority of the wireless for us is going in China. We expect that for us to be flat to slightly down. So -- and the rest of the year, we'll see how it evolves. We don't know exactly.
Well, again, we continue to invest heavily in R&D. I think new products are the lifeblood of the company, so we'll continue to do that. As I've said several times, I think our ultimate goal is to get OpEx to approximately 20% of revenue. But we've got ways to go there, and that will be driven mainly by increases in revenue and some leverage on the operating expense line. But operating expenses will continue at some pace going forward.
Sure. I think as, again as we said for the guide, what's driving the positive increase is the additional weekly volumes that we expect given that overall revenue is relatively flat. But we have 13 weeks versus 14 weeks. So you got a higher weekly volume, which helps gross margin. As Eitan alluded to, we are seeing increased competition and I think that's the offsetting factor to margins.
Well, we -- I mean, to talk about 100 Gb datacom, again, it's an important part of our business. It grew last quarter. I think we said it's below 10% of revenue, but it's still a meaningful part of our revenue. And I'll let Eitan talk a little bit about CF -- 100 Gb CFP2 coherent.
Well, I think, again, in Q1, we will be losing the benefit of the 14th week, but we do think that most of the growth will come from 40 Gb datacom.
Well, I think, again, I think WSS did grew on the fourth quarter. I think our expectations are it's going to grow again in the first quarter. I don't know if Eitan wants to add some color commentary.
It's hard to exactly say what the impact of the 14-week and Chinese New Year. But I would say in general, if we had -- without the impact of that, I think last quarter would have been relatively flat. So then you can -- but we obviously have already given you our forecast for Q1.
Well, I think Jerry mentioned that we had some lumpiness at one 40 Gb customer that was a little bit lower than expected, so I think that's true. And I also think wireless was probably a little bit lower than expected when we saw, again, a little bit of strength in WSS and tunable despite the fact that we had the full 3 months of the telecom price reduction.
Yes, I mean margin, just forecasting margin beyond 1 quarter is a very difficult thing. There's just too many variables that go into it: revenue growth, product mix, increases in CapEx. So we're not comfortable doing that, so all I can provide you is our guidance for this quarter.
Well, we think it's going to help in that, that we think we're going to have continue to increase volume and we need the space and that's why we're building out the 2 additional floors.
I think all of those factors are very important, and I think they could all have an impact on margins both positively and negatively. And so I don't think we can, again, really forecast beyond the current quarter, but we'll take it 1 quarter at a time.
Yes, those, I think, would be the 2 biggest. I agree with Jerry.
Well, I think the area we're clearly investing the most in relates to 100 Gb CFP2, and I guess Eitan talked about that we expect to see more of those revenues in the next calendar year.
Well, I think -- again, I think some of these expenses are -- will definitely continue. A lot of these expenses, project material expenses that we've talked about related to qualification and new products, that's going to continue for many quarters. Some of that relates very much to the CFP2 that Eitan talked about. But also in the following second quarter, we have our annual merit increases, so I expect that to have a meaningful impact. Typically, merit increases equate to approximately $2 million on the OpEx line, so there will be some increases. But as I mentioned earlier, our ultimate goal is to get some operating leverage and ultimately reduce OpEx to something around 20% of revenue, but that's going to take some time and some revenue growth to get there. So I've talked about in the past, by early part of next fiscal year, hopefully.
Well, what I would say is we talked last time about how it was having about 75 basis points impact on our margin in Q3, and I think we made great strides during this quarter to make up most of that. And I think in general in terms of thinking about gross margin in the future, I wouldn't bake in any additional material improvement on the overall gross margin based on that. Certainly with all our products though, we continue to work on reducing costs and improving yields. But again, this is still, as of now, a relatively small part of our business. But hopefully it will grow over the coming years, but we have made some good progress over the last quarter.
Sure. So let's first talk about the CapEx related to the build -- to our original plan for the second Wuxi building, including fitting out the first 2 floors. Again, that CapEx is just lumpy and a little bit of it got pushed into the first quarter. But that building is done now and those 2 floors are fitted out, and we're in the process of starting to move stuff into those floors. And I think as we've said before, that will take probably several more quarters for that to move that out. And at that time, then our Shanghai facility will be primarily just the R&D and NPI facility. So we expect that to be completed, let's say, in the next 6 months or so once some of the qualifications are done. In terms of fitting out the additional 2 floors, I mean, that's a decision we're making now so that it's finished by the end of next fiscal year, so that we can be ready to hopefully accommodate additional volumes in fiscal '17. So a lot of these decisions to add facility or add capacity, you need to be thinking at least 12 months in advance. And that's what we're doing.
Well, I do think we'll see some benefit once we have completely moved manufacturing out of Shanghai. Which, again, we expect in about 6 months once the qualifications are done, and so we should see some benefit from that. So I think that's important. In terms of any difference between wages in Wuxi and wages in Shanghai, I mean, right now as we sit, we've already filled up our full building in Wuxi. So we've already seen some of that benefit. So that small and incremental amount of stuff that still needs to get moved from Shanghai to Wuxi, will we see a little bit of benefit? Sure. But we've already seen some of that benefit because we've moved a complete building and we've filled up that building with workers that are in Wuxi right now.
Well, I think we said both datacom and telecom grew. So I think in general talked about that. I think, again, the strength or the growth in datacom was primarily in 10 Gb and 100 Gb. And we had -- we did have some falloff in our wireless business. On the telecom side, I think we saw a little bit of growth in the WSS as well as I think tunable was a little bit of growth.

I don't think there's anything else I can say.
