column6:
Thanks, Jerry. Datacom revenue decreased by $8.7 million or 3.6% compared to the preceding quarter, primarily as the result of the impact of 1 fewer week in the prior quarter.


Telecom revenue increased $2.7 million or 3.4% compared to the preceding quarter. In the first quarter, we had two 10% or greater customers. Our top 10 customers represented 60.7% of total revenues compared to 58.8% in the preceding quarter.


Non-GAAP gross margin was 30.2% compared to 30.3% in the preceding quarter. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $68.4 million compared to $68.2 million in the prior quarter and exceeded forecast, primarily due to higher than expected cost associated with the qualification of new products. Non-GAAP operating income decreased $2.3 million to $26.5 million or 8.4% of revenues compared to $28.8 million or 9% of revenues in the preceding quarter, primarily as the result of lower revenue levels. Non-GAAP income was $24.5 million or $0.23 per diluted share compared to $26.9 million or $0.25 in the preceding quarter. Average diluted shares for non-GAAP purposes totaled 108.1 million. For non-GAAP purposes, the interest expense for our $258 million of convertible notes was approximately $323,000 in the first quarter. This interest expense is the only impact of these converts on our non-GAAP diluted earnings per share and has no -- and no shares are added to the fully diluted share counts.


Fiscal first quarter capital expenditures totaled $34.7 million, consistent with our forecast of approximately $35 million. Capital expenditures are expected to be approximately $35 million in the second fiscal quarter.


Cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments increased $5.5 million to $495.7 million at the end of the first quarter. Non-GAAP taxes for the second fiscal quarter and the remainder of the fiscal year are estimated at approximately 7.5%. Weighted average fully diluted shares for the second fiscal quarter are expected to be approximately 109 million for non-GAAP purposes.


There are a number of noncash or infrequently occurring charges and benefits which we exclude from our non-GAAP results. These total $21.1 million last quarter. If you include all these items as required under GAAP, we generated net income of $3.4 million or $0.03 per diluted share compared to net income of $7.3 million or $0.07 per diluted share in the preceding quarter.


That concludes my comments and I'll turn it back to Jerry.
ROADM was relatively flat last quarter.
Well, I'd say, obviously, we don't provide guidance for this, on the quarter that we're in on margin. And as you point out, there's lots of factors that go in the margin. There's obviously the pace of revenue growth. There's the product mix, including new products especially. And there's the ASP erosion. And so I think those are all factors that are out there. I think as we look at the current fiscal year, as Jerry said, we expect it to be a challenging year. And we obviously haven't gone through the telecom price negotiations yet. That will be kicking in, in January. And typically, if you look at our fiscal year, the progression of margins, Q4 tends to be the lowest margins inside the fiscal year. But there are certainly, as Jerry points out, factors why we're optimistic about FY '17. But sitting here and trying to quantify something that is that far out is very challenging because of all the different factors that play mix, revenue growth and ASP erosion, amongst many others.
I don't know if I -- I think what we've said is, historically, we've kind of been between 30% and 35%. And our goal is to be in that range. Obviously, we're saying, as we talked about starting last quarter, increased competition. And until we get some of these newer products out, that's obviously negatively impacting us. So I think there's -- I think the near term, things are definitely going to be challenging. We've got the price erosion coming up for the telecom side in January. And hopefully, things start to get better in FY '17.
40G is about 1/4 of our datacom business.
I don't think we have any material supply constraints at 40 gig, no.
Well, again, I think every quarter has its unique factors that go into that. But I think, as we -- what we've tried to communicate, obviously we don't give margin guidance beyond that. But the rest of this fiscal year, we expect to be challenged. And again, we do have, in the third quarter, you will have the impact of 1 month of the telecom price erosion. And in the fourth quarter, you'll have the full 3 months. So Q4 typically marks the low water point inside of a fiscal year. And you should model that accordingly.
Yes, there wasn't any kind of one particular product that drove it. I think, in general, we just saw an uptick in several areas. I would say we're not drawing any conclusion off of 1 quarter, and we think that telecom is going to be relatively flat in Q2.
I would say, in terms of what was not as strong as we expected, I think that the two areas would be wireless, which we've talked about as we categorize in the datacom segment. And legacy 100G CFP for datacom was down after an extremely strong quarter in Q4 that we talked about. So I would say, relative to our expectations, I think both those were a little bit lighter than we expected on the datacom side. We expect 100G for data center to bounce back, some in the second quarter and grow. But as Jerry mentioned, we're seeing some lumpiness on -- in the data center and 40G. So after extremely strong 40G quarter in Q1, we expect that to be down some.
Well, obviously, it's product by product. So we have certainly good and not so good products in each category. But I'd say in general, you add it all together, datacom is a little bit better than telecom.
So, all right, let's tackle the first question. I mean, I think as we talked about CapEx, right, so we are finishing the build-out of the second building, the remaining floors, the second building in Wuxi, and that will be completed by the end of this fiscal year. And so obviously, there's an elevated CapEx level associated with that. And we said this quarter it'd be about $35 million and I expect something similar for the subsequent quarters and then dropping back down to a more normalized, call it, $30 million thereafter. In terms of the duplicate facility cost, that just has to do with the move and moving out of -- well, not moving out of, but not fully utilizing the Shanghai building, moving additional operations from Shanghai to Wuxi. So I'd say the progression of that move is happening as planned. By the end of the fiscal year, we should have both those buildings completely built out. And all that we're going to move into those buildings moved, and we'll only be doing NPI and R&D in Shanghai. Your second question, about OpEx. I don't -- we talked about it in the past. Or I don't think anything's really changed. Our goal is to have OpEx approximately 20% of revenue. And I think we're going to get there through containing cost. So I think we're not saying, from the level that we're guiding this quarter that, that OpEx is going to go down. But hopefully, through some level of revenue growth and containing costs outside of incremental sales and marketing costs associated with higher revenues and we should get there, hopefully, in the first half of fiscal '17.
Well, I think Q2 expenses -- operating expenses will be lower than Q1. So we -- they are going down. I think part of that had to do with the fact that Q1 was higher than expected due to some project material related to some of these new projects that Jerry's talking about. So it can be lumpy. But I think a lot of it is spending and that we are investing now for these next generation of products, whether it be on the datacom or telecom side. And so that's why it is at an elevated level. And that's important for us as we go into FY '17 and have the right products. So I think over time, again as a percentage, we're trying to bring that down closer to 20%. But we're obviously going to make the right investment decisions and continue to invest in R&D and technology. So we'll balance our desire to improve our operating leverage with the fact that we need to invest in new products.
So I think we said that we expect both datacom and telecom to be roughly flat this quarter.
Well, I think we said for FY, we've talked about in FY '16, which is the year that we're in, right, that we are seeing increased pricing competition on the datacom side. And we've said that in our call back last June. I think Jerry's comment about why things are going to get better in FY '17 and somebody asked, well, why not sooner, I think one of his answers was for the kind of coherent side, on the metro rollout, that, that was delayed. And so, I still think -- I think those are 2 discrete items. One is FY '16 and one is an FY '17 comment.
And in terms of percent of revenue for 100G, we're looking at -- for 100 -- for CFP, CFP2, we're looking at roughly about 10% of revenue.
That's 10% of overall revenue, just to be clear.
But in terms of production, large production volumes where -- that's why we're pointing towards FY '17. So it will build towards the end of this fiscal year. But we should see the real benefit in FY -- so the material benefit in FY '17.
Well, I think, again, I think, Jerry mentioned, we think it's going to be challenging. But I'd say we expect revenue growth to continue. But at a more muted pace in the near term. But I think in the next fiscal year, we expect that to accelerate.
column7:
Thanks, Jerry. Datacom revenue increased by $0.5 million or 0.2% compared to the preceding quarter, primarily driven by growth in 100-gigabit Ethernet transceivers, partially offset by a decrease in 40-gigabit Ethernet transceivers after a record quarter for 40-gig in the preceding quarter. Telecom revenue increased by $6.6 million or 8.2% compared to the preceding quarter, primarily driven by growth in 10-gigabit tunable transceivers and wavelength selective switches.


In the second quarter, we had 2 10%-or-greater customers. Our top 10 customers represented 58.2% of total revenues compared to 60.7% in the preceding quarter.


Non-GAAP gross margin was 30.0% compared to 30.2% in the preceding quarter. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $68 million or 21.2% of revenue compared to $68.4 million or 21.8% of revenue in the preceding quarter.


Non-GAAP operating income increased $1.8 million to $28.3 million or 8.8% of revenue compared to $26.5 million or 8.4% in the preceding quarter, primarily as a result of higher revenue levels.


Non-GAAP income was $26.9 million or $0.25 per diluted share compared to $24.5 million or $0.23 in the preceding quarter. Average diluted shares for non-GAAP purposes totaled 107.5 million.


For non-GAAP purposes, interest expense for our $258 million of 0.5% convertible notes was approximately $323,000 in the second quarter. This interest is the only impact of these converts on non-GAAP diluted earnings per share as no shares are added to the fully diluted share count.


Second quarter capital expenditures totaled $29.5 million, lower than our forecast of approximately $35 million. Capital expenditures are expected to be approximately $35 million in the third quarter.


Cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments increased $25.1 million to $520.8 million at the end of the quarter.


Non-GAAP taxes for the third and fourth quarter are estimated at approximately 7.5%. Weighted average fully diluted shares for the third fiscal quarter are expected to be approximately 108.5 million for non-GAAP purposes. There are a number of noncash or infrequently occurring charges and benefits which we exclude from our non-GAAP results. These totaled $20.2 million last quarter. If you include all these items as required under GAAP, we generated net income of $6.6 million or $0.06 per diluted share compared to net income of $3.4 million or $0.03 per diluted share in the preceding quarter.


That concludes my comments, and I'll turn it back to Jerry.
Well, I think in absence of any sort of shift mix, I would say, we typically see the fourth quarter a little bit lower than the third quarter, exactly as you said, because of the 3 full months of the annual telecom price reductions. Ultimately, what will drive that probably most importantly will be mix. And depending on which products -- or how fast we're growing and which products are growing, we'll be plus or minus in that range. But I'd say in general, there will be the impact of the 3 full months, and you should take that into account.
We don't really comment on who those customers are.
Well, I think what I would say is, as we talked about in the quarter, 100-gig grew in the quarter and had a nice strong quarter there. So I think the percentage of overall or datacom revenue that's 100-gig, it went up in the quarter. In terms of 40-gig, as we talked about, 40-gig was down in the quarter after a large uptick in the prior quarter. So I would say directionally, 100-gig as a percent of revenue or datacom went up and 40-gig datacom went down. 10-gig is still the biggest part followed by 40-gig and then 100-gig, but 100-gig is gaining some ground here.
Yes. So CFP2 ACO is very important to us. I think we're making some good progress there. We're in qual with multiple customers and have gotten a lot of positive feedback there. So we think we're moving along nicely. Obviously, we're going to have to add and ramp capacity over time. And as we said before, we expect to have meaningful revenue from that product in the summer of calendar 2016.
So the reason why the CapEx was a little bit lower than expected this quarter just had to do with the timing of expenditures related to the final build-out of the second building in our Wuxi facility. And so it was just a matter of a timing exercise there. I think we've been consistent in saying in fiscal '16, we've been kind of expecting roughly $35 million a quarter in capital expenditures, driven by -- the higher level driven by the Wuxi build-out. And that we expect that to be finished in fiscal '16. And I'd expect capital expenditures as a percentage to drop down some in fiscal '17 to be more in the kind of the $30 million a quarter ballpark. But obviously, that will be driven and modulated based on demand.
column8:
Thanks, Jerry. Revenues decreased to $309.2 million, a decrease of $11.9 million or 3.7% from $321.1 million in the preceding quarter.


Telecom revenue increased by $2.6 million or 2.9% compared to the preceding quarter, primarily driven by growth in wavelength selective switches.


Datacom revenue decreased by $14.5 million or 6.2% compared to the preceding quarter, primarily driven by decline in the sale of 40-gigabit transceivers. We attributed this decline primarily to reduced levels of capital spending by Web 2.0 in hyperscale data center customers in anticipation of the rollout of the next generation 100-gig QSFP28 transceivers.


In the third quarter, we had 2 10% or greater customers. Our top 10 customers represented 58.4% of total revenues compared to 58.2% in the preceding quarter.


Non-GAAP gross margin was 30.3% compared to 30% in the preceding quarter as favorable product mix more than offset the impact of 1 month of annual telecom price negotiations, which typically take effect on January 1.


Non-GAAP operating expenses were $67.3 million compared to $68 million in the prior quarter. Non-GAAP income was $26.6 million or $0.25 per diluted share compared to $26.9 million or $0.25 diluted share in the preceding quarter.  Average diluted shares for non-GAAP purposes totaled $108.1 million.


For non-GAAP purposes, interest expense for our $258 million of 0.5% convertible notes was approximately $323,000 in the third quarter. This interest expense is the only impact of these converts on non-GAAP diluted earnings per share as no shares are added to the fully diluted share count.


Third quarter capital expenditures totaled $26.8 million, lower than our forecast of approximately $35 million, as some final expenditures associated with the fit-out of the second building in Wuxi, China rolled into the fourth quarter. Capital expenditures are expected to be approximately $33 million in the fourth quarter.


Cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments increased $10.3 million to $531 million at the end of the quarter.


Non-GAAP taxes for the third quarter were approximately $1 million and are estimated for the fourth fiscal quarter to be approximately $1 million. Non-GAAP taxes for fiscal 2017 are estimated to be approximately 7%.


Weighted average fully diluted shares for the fiscal fourth quarter are expected to be approximately 109 million for non-GAAP purposes. Excluded from our non-GAAP results, a number of charges or benefits that were either noncash or we consider outside of our core ongoing operating results. These totaled $14.5 million last quarter. If you include all these items as required under GAAP, we generated net income of $12.1 million or $0.11 per diluted share, compared to net income of $6.6 million or $0.06 per diluted share in the preceding quarter.


That concludes my comments, and I'll turn it back to Jerry.
Well, again, we only provide 1 quarter of gross margin forecast. As we talked in the past, our hope is always that new products carry higher ASPs and better gross margins. But that obviously depends on our ability to ramp and to yield them efficiently. But certainly, we hope that these products are positive on the gross margin perspective.
The growth quarter-over-quarter in that area was about 25%.
I'm sorry, so you want to compare CFP, CFP2 plus QSFP28 to 40-gig?
Again, I think, I guess the way I'd answer the question is that CFP versus CFP2/CFP4 are approximately the same size at this time. And we expect this QSFP28 ramp so obviously that's going to start shifting things even more in that direction.
Well, right now, our 100 gig, CFP, CFP2, CFP4 and QSFP28 is still a little bit below 40-gig, but not much.
Yes. It was primarily 40-gig but also 10-gig declined a little bit.
Well, again, I think the building is slightly different than the CapEx associated with tested -- the final tested assembly equipment for the constraints that Jerry's talking about. So those are 2 separate items. And again, we expect the CapEx associated with the final buildout in the last couple of floors in Wuxi to be finished in Q4. So what we're forecasting for Q4 is about $33 million of CapEx. And as I've said in the past, I hope that, that declines in FY '17 to something more around $30 million per quarter.
It's just timing. Often with construction projects, the timing of CapEx can be lumpy. And it just so happens that some of the expenditures that we thought would happen in Q3 are actually going to happen in Q4 for where they're building.
Well, again, I think, when you're looking at capacity, there's obviously -- the test and assembly equipment tends to be relatively short-term when you're relieving capacity constraints. Depending on the equipment, it can take anywhere from 3 to 6 months to get that equipment in. And in terms of longer-term capacity, that has more to do with capacity in fabs or big facility buildouts, which is what the Wuxi CapEx is related to.
Well, I think in terms of, as Jerry mentioned, in terms of revenue growth, I mean, our hope is the biggest driver for revenue growth in the coming -- in the calendar year that we're in or fiscal '17 is QSFP28. And we're counting on that to grow meaningfully over the coming quarters, and that should drive overall revenue growth for the company.
Are you talking in terms of the OEMs that are located in China or deployments in China?
Well, again, I don't think we provide guidance again beyond one quarter. But I certainly -- we certainly believe that WSS is a higher than our average gross margin, and so to the extent we sell more and that becomes a higher percentage of our telecom revenue, then that certainly should help. And I think the same thing on the datacom side for the 100-gigabit products. So I think those, the mix could be helpful there. And that will help offset other factors that are obviously always existing in the market.
We expect both to grow sequentially.
Was your second question about year-over-year datacom overall growth?
Sure. So I think first of all, when you're comparing FY '16 to FY '15, I'd say first you got to adjust for the fact that FY '15 had 1 extra week, so that's one of the things. But I think in general, we've been saying for a while that FY '16 was going to be a challenging year top line basis, and it's been a relatively flat year, but that we do feel better about FY '17. And that will be driven by the growth of new products like QSFP28 and CFP2 coherent as well as wavelength selective switches. So I think Jerry has said that we are optimistic for growth in FY '17.
I think it was about $22 million or $23 million. I don't have it right in front of me. It'll be in the 10-Q we just filed.
I would think that 10G will be flat to down and 40G will be relatively flat with the growth coming from 100G.
Well, there's always -- every quarter, there's always an amount of revenue that we leave on the table for certain products. But it's not a number we quantify.
Again, I don't have that number in front of me. That's not a number that we typically break out.
I think it was just some of the legacy products. I think, tunable was relatively flat. I think it was some of the older legacy products. I think amplifiers was a little bit down and some other stuff, but nothing really of note.
Yes. I think we said in the past Web 2.0 is probably about 20% or plus of datacom.
Is it a percent of overall? Or is it a percent of telecom? I mean datacom, sorry.
Yes, as a percent of datacom it's approximately 10%.
Well, we expected it to -- again, as Jerry talked about, we're being very opportunistic in that space, employing in the space when we think it's accretive to EPS. We had expected it to decline last quarter some, it actually was flat. And I'd say right now, as we sit here today, we're expecting approximately flat next quarter as well. But again, it's such an opportunistic situation. It can vary off of that.
column9:
Thanks, Jerry. Sales of products for datacom applications increased by $23.6 million or 10.8% compared to the preceding quarter, primarily driven by growth in 40G and 100G transceivers, including CFP, CFP2, CFP4, QSFP and QSFP28 form factors.


Sales of products for telecom applications decreased by $14.1 million or 15.6% compared to the preceding quarter, primarily as the result of the full 3 months of the telecom price negotiations and an unexpected decline in demand for legacy products, including 10G fixed wavelength and tunable transceivers and optical amplifiers. In addition, we experienced delays in adding capacity for manufacturing wavelength selective switches and delays in the qualification of new growth in line cards.


In the fourth quarter, we had 1 10% or greater customer. Our top 10 customers represented 56.4% of total revenues compared to 58.4% in the preceding quarter.


Non-GAAP gross margin improved to 30.6% compared to 30.3% in the preceding quarter, primarily due to favorable product mix partially offset by the impact of the full 3 months of annual telecom price negotiations, which typically take effect on January 1. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $66.2 million, compared to $67.3 million in the prior quarter. The decrease is primarily due to lower G&A costs, including lower legal expenses. Non-GAAP operating income was $31.2 million or 9.8% of revenues compared to $26.3 million or 8.5% of revenue in the preceding quarter. Non-GAAP income was $31.8 million or $0.29 per diluted share compared to $26.6 million or $0.25 per diluted share in the preceding quarter. Average diluted shares for non-GAAP purposes totaled 109.4 million. For non-GAAP purposes, interest expenses for the -- are $258 million of 0.5% convertible notes was approximately $323,000. This interest expense is the only impact of these converts on the non-GAAP diluted earnings per share as no shares are added to the fully diluted share count.


Interest and other income was approximately $685,000 in the fiscal fourth quarter and is expected to be at approximately similar level in the first quarter of fiscal 2017. Non-GAAP taxes for the fourth quarter were approximately $100,000. Non-GAAP taxes for fiscal 2017 are expected to be approximately 5% to 6%.


Cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments increased $31.4 million to $562.5 million at the end of the quarter. Capital expenditures are expected to be approximately $30 million in the first quarter of fiscal 2017. Weighted average fully diluted shares for the first quarter of fiscal '17 are expected to be approximately 111 million for non-GAAP purposes.


We excluded from our non-GAAP results a number of charges or benefits to either noncash or we consider outside of our core ongoing operating operations. This totaled $18.8 million last quarter. If you include all of these items, as required under GAAP, we generated net income of $13.1 million or $0.12 per diluted share compared to net income of $12.1 million or $0.11 per diluted share in the preceding quarter.


That concludes my comments, and I'll turn it back to Jerry.
I would also add that Q3 was a little quarter for us in the 40G. So it's a little bit of a bounce back from a tough Q3 for 40G and, of course, 40G datacom in the fourth quarter. And we think in general, it will be relatively flattish in the Q1.
Yes. Well, we had some pretty extreme, favorable mix this last quarter, obviously, as we talked about with all the growth especially coming -- a lot of the growth coming from 100G datacom and with some of the weakness coming from legacy telecom products that have lower gross margin. And so you saw the benefits in that quarter of what can happen. Obviously, we think we're going to sell more 100G this quarter, which should be helpful, which is why we're comfortable expecting 31% gross margin in Q1. It's hard to predict what the margins will be after that. As always, there's a bunch of factors that determine margin. It's not just product mix. It's revenue growth rate. It's our ability to ramp in yield cost effectively our new products. And obviously, it's the pricing environment. So I'd say we're pleased with where our gross margins were for the fourth quarter. We're happy that the first quarter, as expected, that those gross margins are going to increase, and we'll see where we go after that. But we don't give any guidance beyond Q1.
Well, I would say, in general, that it grew at least...
20% quarter-over-quarter, yes, sort of what I was going to say, about 20% quarter-over-quarter.
Well, so I think first of all, we're not going to break out every single product line. But overall, again, you have the full 3 months of the telecom price reductions that affect every area. WSS was still up a little bit, but it was not up nearly as much as we expected due to the delays of adding capacity that Jerry talked about, not from -- certainly not from a lack of orders. And I would say unexpectedly, we saw 10G tunable declined. Part of that was due to the fact that a large customer ended up pulling several million dollars of product after the end of the quarter that we expected them to pull in the last week of the quarter. And we expect that telecom business to pop back this quarter. So as I think about the growth that we are expecting this quarter at the midpoint, I'd say we probably may see more telecom growth and even datacom growth just given how weak some of the products were in the fourth quarter.
Yes. And part of that was due to the just annual price reductions, and part of that was units.
Again, I'm not going to break it down by product line by product line. But as I said, WSS was up a little bit, and you can do the math on the rest of it.
Are you talking telecom, Alex?
Well, there will be datacom price declines there. As you know, datacom price declines happen every 3 to 6 months. So there will be the typical price declines on the datacom side. But we've gone through the annual telecom price negotiations, and the major impact of that was reflected in Q4.
I think we've talked about it being roughly 20% of datacom, and I still think that number is plus or minus in that ballpark.
Well, as you know, most of our revenue comes through, just in time, CMI inventory hubs. So our book-to-bill is not really a great measure for us, but certainly, it was better than 1. And that is why we're forecasting the growth that we are forecasting.
In Q3, yes. In Q3, we had 2. In Q4, we had 1.
Sure. So of the estimated $30 million expected, there's only a handful of that, that is for facilities. For the most part, we're -- at this point, we're done with the second Wuxi building. I think there might be $1 million left that's going to happen this quarter that's related to that. So most of that is equipment, but obviously, there are some maintenance CapEx as well as some adding capacity. So as far as beyond Q1, I would estimate -- it's always hard to tell, but I would estimate an average of $30 million per quarter for each of the 4 quarters of fiscal '17 at this point.
Yes. There's a lot of factors, as we've talked about in the past, that go into gross margin and trying to predict that 2 years out is the challenge.
WSS.
Yes.
The primary driver of the growth of that business is for WSS on a stand-alone basis.
Yes. So I think we talked last quarter that QSFP28 was about $2.5 million. It more than doubled this quarter, and we'd expect it to more than double again next quarter. In terms of overall 100 gigabit datacom, it's about 25% now of datacom revenue, and that includes CFP, CFP2, CFP4 as well as QSFP28. So that's our  -- and then next is 40G datacom, which is about 22% of datacom. And 10G is also a little bit less now than 40G last quarter but both 21% of datacom.
I think CFP is still bigger than CFP2.
Well, again, I think the decline in the quarter, obviously, was partially due to the price decline, the annual price reductions, but it caught us a little bit by surprise on some of this legacy stuff that's going down -- that went down, I should say. But we expect that business to pop back. And as I said, looking kind at the midpoint of guidance, the $15 million or so of growth, I'd expect more than half of that to come from telecom. So I think that the -- this -- the large decline we saw this quarter, we do not think that that's an ongoing trend. I think in terms of telecom growing and getting back to higher levels, I think that's going to be dependent on 2 things. It's going to be dependent on WSS and ROADM line card growth, which Jerry just talked about. And then it's going to be also dependent on the success of 100G CFP2 ACO. And I think the combination of those 2 things are probably the biggest potential growth drivers to get that business back to a more attractive level.
On the 10G tunable side?
Well, there was one large customer, again, that I mentioned that we thought was going to pull multiple millions of dollars before the end of the quarter and ended up pulling in the first week. So that was specific to that customer. But I don't think -- it was more of a customer thing than a geography thing, I guess.
You know I'm not going to get into that.
Yes. I would say 40G datacom ended up being stronger than expected in the fourth quarter. I also think we were able to make more 100G CFP and CFP2 than expected in the quarter. And so we're able to expand capacity a little bit more there, and we knew that demand was there. So I would say it was a combination of stronger demand in 40G datacom and our ability to make a couple more CFP and CFP2 100G datacom modules than we had originally expected.
Well, again, we've talked about how it was at the high end of the 10% to 15% range. But we've been -- we said that in the last -- in the December conference call. So it wasn't -- didn't end up being worse in this quarter than what we had said back then.
Well, about 20% is fiber channel and then the rest is everything else.
Fiscal fourth quarter was about $20 million, and that was less than expected. So we had some delays in both some of the final CapEx associated with our Wuxi building as well as some delays in some of that CapEx associated with the expansion of capacity for wavelength selective switches. And so it's a little bit lower than expected, but we think for this quarter, they'll be about $30 million.
For telecom, I think 100G is still a pretty small piece of that. As Jerry mentioned, for CFP2 ACO, we're only shipping a small amount of units, so between that and -- 100G is a small amount for us.
It's a -- I wouldn't classify it as any gig. That's a different category or product.
column10:
Thanks, Jerry.


Sales of telecom products increased by $22 million or 29% compared to the preceding quarter. This increase was due to higher sales of wavelength selective switches, coherent receivers and 100-gig transceivers as well as a rebound in the demand for other telecom products including amplifiers and 10-gig transceivers, both tunable and fixed wavelength.


Sale of datacom products increased by $0.5 million or 0.2% compared to the preceding quarter, primarily driven by growth in demand for 100-gigabit transceivers including CFP, CFP2, CFP4, and QSFP28 form factors, partially offset by a decline on the sale of transceivers for wireless applications and 40-gig transceivers.


Datacom revenue, excluding transceivers for wireless applications, increased 3.1% over the prior quarter. Sale of 100-gig transceivers for datacom applications increased 21.8% over the prior quarter and 115.8% over the first quarter of the prior fiscal year.


In the first quarter, we had 2 10% or greater customers. Our top 10 customers represented 60.2% of total revenues compared to 56.4% in the preceding quarter. Non-GAAP gross margins improved to 31.1% compared to 30.6% in the preceding quarter, primarily due to favorable product mix and a benefit of vertical integration over the larger volume.


Non-GAAP operating expenses were $69.3 million compared to $66.2 million in the prior quarter. This increase was due to higher payroll taxes from the annual vesting of employee stock grants, higher legal expenses from 2 patent trials that completed in the quarter and higher employee compensation levels. Non-GAAP operating expenses as a percent of revenue decreased to approximately 20.3% of revenue compared to 20.8% in the preceding quarter.


Non-GAAP operating income was $43.5 million or 12.8% of revenue compared to $31.2 million or 9.8% of revenue in the preceding quarter. Non-GAAP income was $41.8 million or $0.38 per diluted share compared to $31.8 million or $0.29 in the preceding quarter.


Average diluted shares for non-GAAP purposes total 110.8 million. For non-GAAP purposes, interest expenses for our $258 million 0.5% convertible notes was approximately $323,000 in the fourth quarter. This interest expense is the only impact of these converts on non-GAAP earnings per diluted share as no shares are added to the fully diluted share count.


Interest and other income was approximately $300,000 in the first fiscal quarter and is expected to be at a similar level on the second fiscal quarter.


Non-GAAP taxes for the first quarter were approximately $2 million, and non-GAAP taxes for the second fiscal quarter and the remainder of the year are estimated between 4% and 5%.


Cash and cash equivalents and short-term investments increased $31.3 million to $593.8 million at the end of the quarter. Capital expenditures are expected to be about $30 million in the second quarter of fiscal 2017. Weighted average fully diluted shares for the second fiscal quarter are expected to be approximately 112 million for non-GAAP purposes.


We have excluded from our non-GAAP results a number of charges or benefits that would -- either noncash or we consider outside of our core ongoing operating results. These totaled $17.9 million last quarter. If you exclude all these items as required under GAAP, we generated net income of $23.9 million or $0.22 per diluted share compared to net income of $13.1 million or $0.12 per diluted share in the preceding quarter.


That concludes my comments, and I'll turn it back to Jerry.
Well, I think the -- there are 2 things that drove the better-than-expected gross margins in the quarter. I think was -- first was favorable product mix. I think not only did we sell more 100-gig transceivers than we expected, but we had a meaningful decline in wireless transceivers, which as we've talked about in the past have a less-than-average gross margin. So there definitely was a favorable mix component to that. And then I think the other thing was we had higher volumes than expected. And as Jerry pointed out, when we have higher volumes, we benefit from our vertical integration strategy that differentiates us from others. So I think it was the combination of the 2 that helped us get to the 33%. Obviously, we're hoping that, that continues to improve, and we are guiding to 34% for our next quarter. So we are hopeful that's a positive trend that will continue. But as always, we only give one quarter guidance.
Well, I think what we said last time was that we expected QSFP28 to more than double this quarter, and it definitely did that. And again, we expect that to be the major -- one of the major growth drivers for the subsequent quarter. And that's quite possible that that's going to double again or more in the quarter -- in Q2. So I think that's a big growth engine for us, and we are capacity constrained, as Jerry mentioned, and we're adding capacity as fast as we can on those products.
Well, I think it's still relatively small for us, and so I wouldn't say it materially contributes to that growth. We expect it to grow, but it's not material as a percent of our overall telecom business at this point. But it's an important product for us, and we continue to work hard to get that product qualified at various customers and to ramp our production capacity.
I think, again, WSS was strong. We had said we expected it to grow 10%, and it grew meaningfully better than that. So that was, obviously, a key contributor to the growth in telecom. But we really saw a rebound, a broad rebound in our telecom products. As we talked about last quarter, we saw kind of an unexpected decline in a variety of products last quarter. But we expected those to rebound, and we factored that into our guidance. And so it was a pretty broad rebound in telecom. WSS was certainly a key contributor. In terms of our forecast and factoring in some qualification on line cards, certainly, we have some revenue baked into that for the qualification. But again, we don't expect that to have a huge impact until the subsequent quarter, hopefully, since we'll only -- if we get qualified this quarter, will only have a partial impact.
Sure. So 40 gig was down a little bit this quarter, but I think the context you have to understand is last quarter was surprisingly strong in that business. We actually went back and saw that, that was our second highest quarter in terms of 40-gig revenue on the datacom side. It was last quarter. And we all know that business tends to be quite lumpy. So even though 40 gig was down a little bit this quarter relative to incredibly strong Q4, it was still up relative to Q3. In terms of the future for 40 gig or our forecast for Q2, we're still very positive on 40 gig. We think it's going to be -- could grow. It'll be flat, but hopefully grow. And 10 gig grew a little bit last quarter, and I think probably will be more flattish this quarter. But both those products are still very important products in our product portfolio, and the revenues are holding up quite well.
Well, again, I think you need to understand it's a big part of telecom, but it was not -- so it did not grow as fast as the 30% that we had -- roughly 30% that we had for telecom. But from a dollar perspective, it was a very large contributor, if that makes sense.
Well, again, I think we've talked for a long time about, historically, our margins have been between 30% and 35%. And when we're going through these cycles, where we have new products out there with better gross margins and our revenue is growing at a strong pace, then we tend to be towards the upper end of that range. And that's what we're seeing now. I think last year when we didn't have the newer products, we were at the lower end of the range. So I think we're very pleased with what margins we had last quarter. I'd say we're very pleased with what we see is the outlook. And depending on how fast we continue to grow revenue and what the mix of that revenue is, we're hopeful that those margins can further improve.
Yes. 40G is about 20% of datacom at this point.
So I think your assumptions historically have been correct in the fact that I think a couple of years ago, certainly that was the case where I think the datacom margins were running higher than telecom. But I think we've been saying it for a while now that I think they're kind of within spitting distance of each other at this point. Obviously, it's highly dependent on the products that we're talking about in both datacom and telecom. I have products that have margins meaningfully higher than our current margins and meaningfully lower. So it's really a product-by-product basis. But right now, I would say they are roughly equivalent.
I think in general, I'd say some up, some down. As we've talked about in the past, this is pretty lumpy. So we talked a little bit about 40 gig being down a little bit, and that's primarily the Web 2.0. But I'd still say they've been at approximately the same level. But as Jerry pointed out, we sold a lot more QSFP28 where some of that is going to the Web 2.0. So I'd say in general, it's been approximately the same percentage for us, but we certainly are optimistic on that business and expect it to grow meaningfully.
That's always a tough question. I think on a percentage basis, I think they could each grow at the roughly the same percentage. But I think since datacom is roughly 70% of the business from a nominal dollar perspective, my guess is datacom will grow more, if that makes sense.
It's always hard to break that out. But I'd say approximately of 1 point of that was related -- a point, and maybe a little bit more than a point was related to mix, and a little less than a point was related to leverage in the facility. But those are hard, hard calculations to isolate.
Yes. I mean, I think again when we talked about last quarter that fact that again telecom was surprisingly down meaningfully last quarter. And we talked about some of that just being timing issues and timing of polls and stuff like that. So again, just like I told you not to read too much about the decline last time, I wouldn't necessarily extract extrapolate off of the 30% growth this quarter. But like I said, we expect our overall business to grow meaningfully this quarter, and we expect telecom to grow meaningfully and contribute to that this quarter.
Sure. So we had expected the CapEx to be close to $30 million this quarter, but it was less. So to be clear, it was closer to $20 million. That was primarily 2 things. We had some expenditures associated with some fit out of an additional space in our Ipoh, Malaysia facility, and that rolled from Q1 to Q2. And then also, we had some timing of receiving some high dollar amount equipment into one of our fabs that also got pushed. So neither of those had impact on our capacity but did push -- made our CapEx this quarter to be closer to $20 million than $30 million. For this quarter, we expect $30 million, approximately $30 million of CapEx. And I'd say for the remaining part of the fiscal year, we'd expect about $30 million of CapEx per quarter.
Yes.
I'm not sure of the exact question you're asking. I mean, they're -- our top customers are the same top customers that we've had in the past. What's the second part of your question?
Yes. That's not a -- those aren't numbers that we break out. But needless to say, both those customers have been strong.
The non-GAAP tax rate, yes, 4% to 5% for the rest of the year, yes.
Yes. Well, I think when you look at last quarter, datacom, we had expected datacom to grow overall at a higher rate, and I'd say the main thing that was significantly softer than expected was the wireless business. And as we talked about in the past, that business has again lower gross -- significantly lower gross margins than the other parts of our business, and that's what helped us with our margins. So that -- I think that's part of it. Again, I think we thought 40 gig would be more flat. It was down a little bit. So -- but again, that was coming off of a quarter where it was our second highest quarter in 40 gig ever. So again, that business tends to be lumpy because it tends to go into the Web 2.0 guys. So I'd say 40 gig was a little lighter than expected. Wireless was significantly lighter than expected. As we go to the telecom side, I think again we had predicted a rebound after last quarter when we gave our guidance. I would just say some of these things just bounce back a little bit better than expected. And so it was -- again, the telecom growth was really a pretty broad-based rebound in growth.
I mean, clearly, we expect the growth in the quarter on the datacom side to be both on the CFP, CFP2 as well as QSFP28. I think as I mentioned, we expect QSFP28 will -- could double again or more than double again this quarter. So both those products, we expect to see growth and strengthen. I think 10 gig and 40 gig will be more likely more flattish. But again, those can vary quarter-to-quarter by a couple of million dollars. But again, we think those businesses have legs, and we're not reading into any one quarter down or any one quarter up in either of the 10 or the 40-gig datacom business, so...
It was actually up a little bit.
column11:
Thank you, Jerry. Sales of telecom products increased by $9.7 million or 9.9% compared to the first quarter. This increase was due to higher sales of 100-gigabit transceivers as well as wavelength selective switches and ROADM line cards. Sales of datacom products increased by $18.8 million or 7.7% compared to the first quarter. This increase was primarily due to higher sales of 100-gig transceivers. Sales of 100-gig transceivers for datacom applications increased approximately 30% compared to the first quarter and more than 80% over the second quarter of the prior fiscal year. Sales of 40-gig transceivers were approximately flat compared to the first quarter.


In the second quarter, we had two 10% or greater customers. Our top 10 customers represented 57.9% of total revenues compared to 60.2% in the first quarter. Non-GAAP gross margins improved to 37.2% compared to 33.1% in the first quarter, primarily due to favorable product mix and operational leverage from our vertical integration.


Non-GAAP operating expenses were $69.4 million compared to $69.3 million in the prior quarter. Non-GAAP operating expenses as a percent of revenue decreased to approximately 18.8% of revenue compared to 20.3% in the first quarter. Non-GAAP operating income was $68.3 million or 18.5% of revenue compared to $43.5 million or 12.8% of revenue in the first quarter. Non-GAAP income was $65.2 million or $0.58 per diluted share compared to $41.8 million or $0.38 in the preceding quarter. Average diluted shares for non-GAAP purposes totaled 113.2 million.


For non-GAAP purposes, interest expense for our $258 million of 0.5% convertible notes was approximately $323,000 in the second quarter. This interest expense is the only impact of this converts on non-GAAP diluted earnings per share as no shares are added to the fully diluted share count.


Interest and other income was approximately $500,000 in the second quarter and is expected to be a similar level in the third quarter. Non-GAAP taxes for the second quarter was approximately $3.6 million, non-GAAP taxes for the third quarter and the remainder of the fiscal year are estimated to be approximately 5%. Cash and cash equivalents and short-term investments increased $32.5 million to $626.3 million at the end of the quarter.


Capital expenditures for the upcoming third quarter are estimated to be approximately $40 million. This elevated level of CapEx will continue in the fiscal fourth quarter as well. Weighted average fully diluted shares for the third fiscal quarter are expected to be approximately 115 million for non-GAAP purposes.


We've excluded from our non-GAAP results a number of charges or benefits that were either noncash or we consider outside our core ongoing operating results. These totaled $16.4 million in the last quarter. If you excluded all of these items, as required under GAAP, we generated net income of $48.8 million or $0.43 per diluted share compared to net income of $23.9 million or $0.22 per diluted share in the first quarter.


That concludes my comments, and I'll turn it back to Jerry.
Well, there's always a lot of factors that go into margin as we know. It comes down to revenue growth, product mix and the competitive environment. I think, as Jerry pointed out, the telecom price reductions were less this year than we've seen in prior years. So obviously, that's helpful as you think about having the full 3 months of impact in the fourth quarter, so that's helpful. But again, we're not going to provide guidance for the fourth quarter.
Yes, I can answer that. I think between WSS and ROADM line card, there's about 10% growth last quarter in terms of -- I'm sorry, you wanted to break down what of datacom?
Yes. 10-gig was actually up a little bit, wireless was actually down several million dollars. So that helped them on the mix side of things.
It's in that ballpark.
I think, SAN was relatively flat in the quarter. So again, as Jerry said, most of the growth came from 100 gig.
I think as Jerry mentioned, we hope that not only capacity this quarter for QSFP28, but in subsequent quarters. So I think the hope would be that, that product continues to grow that the demand is there. And certainly that will be helpful as you look to the Q3 to Q4 comparison and certainly, we'll make it a lot easier for growth in the fourth quarter.
James, what was the second question?
Yes. I think, we said we expected it to more than double or are doubled.
To double again? No, I don't think it's going to double again next quarter. But it's going to grow significantly, as Jerry said. I think that will be -- 100 gig will be the key driver for growth this quarter.
Sure. So I'd say, first of all, I think what I said is historically, we typically been between 30 and 35%. But certainly, we've had quarters where we've been above that and were above that now. I think in terms of looking to the future, as I've always said, it comes down to revenue growth, product mix and the competitive environment. And so it's trying to predict multiple quarters out is challenging in our industry but obviously, we're very optimistic now and were very pleased with where our margins were last quarter and with our guidance this quarter, but we don't provide guidance beyond this quarter.
Yes. So we had a couple of lawsuits that happened when we went to trial in the first quarter, and that rolled off. And so I think, hopefully, that large expense is behind us. I mean, I do expect G&A to continue to grow, but I don't expect legal to, in the near term, to pop back up to the old levels. So I'd expect it to grow from the levels that we're at now over the subsequent quarters.
Yes. It's about 30% to 35% of the account.
Yes, it's kind of in the low 20s percent of datacom.
I think we've said in the past, that's 15% to 20% of revenue. And I still think it's in that ballpark.
It was about $30 million.
We're not getting into that, Dave. We're not at that stage yet.
And it will come down to volume at the end of the day, again, when you're looking at fixed costs to the extent once you add the capacity, it all comes down to how many units go down through that fixed cost.
It's still predominantly WSS. Obviously, once we get some of these calls down on line cards, we expect that to shift some, but it's predominantly WSS at this point still.
column12:
Thanks, Jerry. Sales of datacom products increased by $7.3 million or 2.8% compared to the second quarter. This increase is primarily due to higher sales of 100-gigabit transceivers. Sales of 100-gigabit transceivers for datacom applications increased approximately 9% compared to the second quarter and more than 110% over the third quarter of the prior fiscal year. Sales of telecom products increased by $3.5 million or 3.2% compared to the second quarter. This increase was due to higher sales of wavelength-selective switches and ROADM line cards, primarily to our Chinese OEM customers.


In the second quarter we had 2 10% or greater customers. Our top 10 customers represented 57.4% of total revenues compared to 57.9% in the second quarter.


Non-GAAP gross margin was 37% compared to 37.2% in the second quarter. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $70.5 million compared to $69.4 million in the prior quarter. Non-GAAP operating expenses as a percent of revenue decreased to approximately 18.5% of revenue compared to 18.8% in the second quarter. Non-GAAP operating income was $70.4 million or 18.5% of revenues compared to $68.3 million or 18.5% of revenue in the second quarter. Non-GAAP operating -- non-GAAP income was $67.2 million or $0.59 per diluted share compared to $65.2 million or $0.58 in the preceding quarter.


Average diluted shares for non-GAAP purposes totaled 114.9.


Interest and other income was approximately $900,000 in the third quarter and is expected to be approximately $1.3 million in the fourth fiscal quarter.


Non-GAAP taxes for the third quarter were approximately $4.1 million. Non-GAAP taxes for the fourth fiscal quarter are estimated to be approximately 5%. Non-GAAP taxes for fiscal '18 are estimated at approximately 6%.


Cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments increased by $588 million to one point -- approximately $1.2 billion at the end of the third quarter compared to $626.3 million at the end of the second quarter. This increase is primarily due to the issuance of $575 million of 0.5% convertible notes due in December 2036, which yielded net proceeds of $569.3 million. Excluding those net proceeds, cash would have increased $18.7 million during the quarter.


Capital expenditures were approximately $42 million in the third quarter and are expected to be approximately $50 million in the fourth fiscal quarter. The increase in capital expenditures in the fourth quarter will be driven by the expansion of capacity in our VCSEL laser fab in Allen, Texas to enable us to pursue new 3D sensing opportunities for consumer applications. In addition, at the beginning of the fourth quarter, we acquired the rights to a parse of land adjacent to our current manufacturing facility in Wuxi, China. In the fourth quarter, we expect to start the construction of a building on this site, whose primarily use will be manufacturing. We expect the construction of this building will be completed in the second half of calendar 2018.


Capital expenditures for fiscal '18 are estimated to be approximately $35 million to $40 million per quarter. Weighted average fully diluted shares for the fourth fiscal quarter are expected to be approximately 115.5 million for non-GAAP purposes. Excluded from our non-GAAP results a number of charges or benefits that were either noncash or we consider outside of our core ongoing operating results. These totaled $20.8 million last quarter. If you included all these items as required under GAAP, we generated net income of $46.4 million or $0.40 per diluted share compared to net income of $48.8 million or $0.43 per diluted share in the second quarter.


The concludes my comments and I'll turn it back to Jerry.
I think the second thing is, as Jerry mentioned in his comments, is we expect revenue to grow again starting in the first quarter, and I think that's different. I think this is -- obviously, we've had -- we sold less than we expected this quarter and the guidance is lower than we had expected, but we do expect fiscal '18 to be a strong year for all the reasons Jerry talked about.
So Doug, can you clarify? You keep referring to them as qualification issues. I think Jerry alluded, we've got some technical issues on the CFP with a couple of customers that we're working through, but can you be more specific on your question?
Well, again, I don't think we're get into that level of detail. It's a little hard to break it out in terms of the impact of the technical challenges with those customers versus -- we have seen just in general some slower demand in CFP, I think, that others have also talked about around Chinese New Year and expect in the first half of the year. So it's a little hard to quantify just the impact of that. But obviously, it's something that we hope to resolve shortly and get shipping on those again. But in the meantime, 100-gig QSFP continues to grow at an incredible rate for us. And as Jerry said, we expect to continue that capacity and be sold out this year, and that's really going to be the growth driver for the company.
Well, I think -- it's certainly -- there's a lot of factors that go into that. I think Jerry just finished talking about the 3D sensing opportunity, and that could have a major impact and really add to our revenue. So I think it all depends on how aggressive you want to be on your assumptions on that, but we're not at the point where we're willing to quantify that. So -- but certainly, I think there's a lot of reasons why we're optimistic about FY '18 that Jerry talked, starts with the QSFP28 sensors, some of the Metro products going into Verizon, and then still WSS domestically in China. So lots of reasons to be positive and expect significant growth in fiscal '18.
Well, I think -- again, I think we talked about 10-gig and lower short wave being down, and I think that's a combination of several things. I think it is a little bit of the wireless, as you talked about, Alex, but it's also we do see in 1-gig Ethernet and 10-gig Ethernet being down this quarter. So you're right, there's still -- wireless is a couple of percent low single-digit percent. Certainly, as a percent of the business, we expect it to decline just because it's not really going, but there will be opportunities down the road, maybe not in the near term, to come out with next-generation products and be more aggressive in that market. But I think certainly, in the near term, it's a flat to declining market and certainly, a smaller and smaller percent of our revenue as most of our growth is driven by QSFP28.
Well, I'd say that -- I would say it was slightly down. So I think all that growth really came from WSS last quarter.
I think the main driver, to your point, Alex, is the WSS.
Well, I mean, I think it was -- no, I think if you factor in pricing, it was probably flat on units if you assumed you got the 1-month average pricing right.  So...
Well, I think as we always talk about, we only give one quarter gross margin guidance, but gross margin is a big -- the big factor for gross margin are revenue growth, product mix and, obviously, the competitive environment. So we are very excited, as Jerry talked about, about some of these VCSEL 3D sensing applications. And obviously, depending on growth and volume, that can be quite nice for us, so that can be helpful. And QSFP28, as that grows, is -- on average, has a higher gross margin than our average gross margin. So again, Wavelength Selective Switch tends to be a favorable product mix. So we have lots of opportunities out there that we're pursuing that could be additive to margin, and that will obviously have to be balanced by what's going on in the competitive market.
Well, I think as Jerry said, for the ROADM line cards and the ACOs with a key OEM and Verizon, we're not going get -- we don't expect to be qualified until Q1, so there's not going to be material revenue in Q4 for that.
Well, I mean, there's a lot of questions in your question. I think the simple answer is the place where we have the most visibility in this business is -- and we think is the biggest growth driver is QSFP28, which is datacom. So we expect datacom growth to be strong in fiscal '18. I think when you look at some of these opportunities that Jerry talks about, whether it's wavelength selective switches and -- domestically in China or the Metro deployments at Verizon, obviously, if we go and we execute on those, where we really haven't sold WSS in China domestically or have these quals, then that's a greenfield opportunity and that can add a lot to that to it. But as we've seen, there are some risk on the timing on those. And so I'd say we're most confident, actually, probably on the datacom side because we really do believe QSFP28, the demand is very strong or expected to continue to be strong, and we are adding significant capacity throughout the fiscal year. And so we really think that's going to be the #1 driver for us.
Yes. I mean, I don't have all this, the breakdown of the revenue this year versus last year. I mean, obviously, last year, we had -- we were at the higher end of the 10% to 15% range for annual ASP reduction , so I think that had more impact last year. I think this year, as we talked about it, it's obviously the -- that the price erosion, although, again, that was at the lower end this year, but then as Jerry mentioned, we expect to sell less CFP modules -- 100-gig CFP modules into China, partially driven by some of these technical issues that we're working through right now that we hope to have resolved by the end of the quarter and start to see the benefit of having those resolved next fiscal year.
Well, I don't know, first of all, if I'd call Q3, where we grew about 3%, a mess, but certainly, as Jerry pointed out, Q3 was a little lighter than expected. It was primarily because 100-gig CFP into China was less than expected. I think that was the result, partially because we thought there were going to be some orders in the last week just prior to Chinese New Year that didn't happen. And then secondly, as Jerry's already talked about, we had some technical glitches that we're working through, and that affected that sale. I mean, that's the story on Q3. I think the story on Q4 is, again, we continue to have -- we're still working through those technical issues. We think that it will get resolved, hopefully, by the end of the quarter, but obviously, it's affecting Q4. And I think also, as we talked about, there's kind of the typical Q4 seasonality issues that are out there, both in terms of Chinese New Year, but also in terms of the price erosion. So if we -- I don't think it's that big a difference. Obviously, we're disappointed, but at the same time, we're very optimistic about FY '18. And if we resolve these issues and we continue to grow QSFP28 and some of these other things start to kick in, in the second half of the year, we think FY '18 can be a very good year. So...

column2: Jerry S. Rawls Co-Founder, Executive Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
