column2:
Thank you, Cassandra, and good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate your taking the time to listen to our conference call today. The replay of this call should appear on our website within 8 hours. An audio replay will be available for 2 weeks by calling area code (888) 203-1112 for domestic, or area code (719) 457-0820 for international, then enter the ID number 7685228.


I need to remind all of you that any forward-looking statements in today's discussion are subject to risks and uncertainties, which are discussed at length in our annual and quarterly SEC filings. Actual events and results can differ materially from any forward-looking statements. As a result, any forward-looking statements are subject to sudden and dramatic changes. In addition, the company undertakes no obligations to update information presented in forward-looking statements. In addition, unless otherwise indicated, all results discussed are on a non-GAAP basis. A complete reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP results may be found in our earnings press release and in the Investor Relations section of our website.


We have prepared some slides for today's conference call. You can access them by connecting to the Investor Relations page of our website at finisar.com. Click on Investors, then scroll down to Webcast Archives and click. You'll see a listing for today's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call.


I am pleased to report that our first quarter revenues were $327.6 million, a new all-time record for Finisar. Quarterly revenues increased by $21.6 million or 7.1% over the previous quarter. Our quarterly revenues increased for the eighth consecutive quarter.


And now with that, I'll let Kurt Adzema, review the rest of the numbers. Kurt?
Thanks, Eitan. As Eitan mentioned, we expect a dip in demand for transceivers for Wireless applications in our second fiscal quarter. As a result of this decrease, as well as soft demand from several datacom and telecom customers, we expect our overall revenues to decline to between $305 million and $320 million. We expect non-GAAP gross margins to be between 31% and 32%. This is a result of lower revenues, an increase in depreciation of approximately $2 million, and the impact of the annual employee salary increases, which took effect at the beginning of the second fiscal quarter.


Non-GAAP operating expenses are expected to increase approximately $1 million primarily as the result of the impact of our employees' annual salary increases and higher legal expenses from multiple patent litigations. We expect non-GAAP operating margins to be approximately 8.5% to 9.5% and non-GAAP earnings per diluted share to be in the range of $0.23 to $0.27 per share.


While we are disappointed with the near-term revenue outlook for our second quarter, we continue to believe in the long-term growth prospects of the company. Finisar's revenue is driven primarily by growth in the worldwide demand for bandwidth from the ever-increasing distribution and use of video images and digital information. Another important trend that is benefiting us is the growth in cloud services, which drives networking hardware upgrades, and the build-out of new hyperscale data centers. These large data centers need many more optical connections, providing terrific opportunities for Finisar products. We believe Finisar is uniquely positioned with our broad product line, extensive customer engagements, profitable vertically integrated business model and strong balance sheet to capitalize on these market opportunities.
And now with that, I'm going to turn it back over to Cassandra and open it up for questions. Cassandra?

Question and Answer
.....................................................................................................................................................................................................................
With respect to 100G Ethernet as a driver, particularly the CFP2, it is obviously, for us a very exciting product. It is an exciting product transition. And we have -- I won't tell you every -- probably every single user of CFP1 100G is now qualifying CFP2 100G. And so it's going to be a very nice transition for the industry, for us as a company. It's started. We are shipping all the CFP2s that we can make today, I won't say that we are in full-bore production, but we are shipping thousands of units And I predict that 100G Ethernet is going to be a growth driver probably not in our Q2 but I would think in -- later in this fiscal year, we will see increased activity and revenue growth at 100G.
Both of those are hard to predict right now because the CFP is going to have a life that will go on for several years. There are a lot of slots that have been created for it in all sorts of systems and some of those slots are empty. They will be filled on network expansion and the network expansion projects in future periods. So I don't know exactly when the crossover of CFP2 dollar volume or unit volume is greater than CFP. I would hope that we ought to have 100G Ethernet revenues back to our -- or close to our record levels in our fiscal year '16 probably. I would guess fiscal year '16.
We don't believe this optics -- You were saying this was a bad business. We don't think optics is a bad business. We think there's a bright future to it. There's -- this is all of the uses for higher-speed optical connections to deliver information. They're not decreasing. They're increasing at a pretty rapid rate. Now it doesn't -- it's not always straight up. We've had quarters in the past where we have either had flat or declining revenues, but we recovered from that and we came back. So I'm still very optimistic about the optics industry and about our role in it and our place in it.
We get premiums when we deliver products that have extraordinary performance. And we go through product cycles where we deliver extraordinary performance and we generate premiums for our products. However, it's a very competitive industry and over time, we have competitors who fall in line, who develop competing products, who have similar performance characteristics. And sometimes that takes a year and sometimes it takes 3 years. But nevertheless, we always find ourselves in that position. So our job is to continue to fund research and development projects, to develop new -- a higher performance, cutting-edge products that do give us a performance edge and higher margins. And so we'll go through several cycles and when we go through those cycles, you'll see our margins -- our margins should come back up like they have in the past.
You're talking about in the second quarter?
It's hard for me to distinguish between those businesses because some -- what's Enterprise and what's hyper data center and what's Web 2.0 and lots of some of the same products end up in all those different places. In general, we predict that we're -- our business is going to be soft again in the datacom sector driven mostly by the Wireless. I think most of the other products are going to be, I don't know, they may be up a bit or maybe down a bit but I think the impact is mostly on the -- in the Wireless.
And yes, we do expect that the datacom business is going to be stronger in the second half of this year and into the next fiscal year. So we -- we think long-term, that business at 10G, 40G, 100G, 200G will come after that. I mean, there's a whole progression of faster and faster connections and more and more optical in these data centers. So we're pretty optimistic about that whole sector.
Yes.
I don't think that's affecting us. It's an opportunity where one of our competitors were successful in selling a proprietary solution. There's an exclusive arrangement involved with that product. And it's one that we currently don't offer. But I think we will have some technical solutions that will be equivalent, that we will be offering in very short order. So I'm -- but I don't think that, that has affected any kind of meaningful shift that affects our revenues.
Well we don't give specific guidance for the third and fourth quarter. And if you remember, our datacom business is served almost totally from customer-managed inventory hubs. They are just-in-time hubs where the customers pull the product and just-in-time delivery for their shipments. So our visibility in a traditional sense because looking at backlog, we have -- it doesn't exist. So -- but I will tell you that our customers are optimistic. Now, will that optimism for our third and fourth quarters turn into pulls out of those hubs and it will turn into revenue for us? Well, generally, our customers in the past when they have been optimistic, yes, it did turn into revenue. So we're -- we feel pretty good about it.
Well, we're shipping a lot -- as many as we can make right now. And the real issue is, most of those are going into early systems and design efforts and system tests that are being done by the system builders. So what they have to do is they've got to get their systems designed. They've got to get them fully vetted and qualified and then go into production for general availability. Then we have a production stream that produces parts for those. And we don't think that production stream -- it's increasing quarterly, but my guess is it's not till the end of the fiscal year, at least the end of the calendar year, before we really start seeing that product ramp in any -- in a big way.
Yes. We think we're spending CapEx for the right reason and that's to expand capacity. Because we think our customers are going to demand that capacity from us. And if you look at our revenues, I mean, there have been -- all the sequential growth of our revenues for the last 8 quarters is -- I don't know. We've been on quite a unit run, as well as a revenue dollar run that has demanded more capacity out of our factories. So we're -- I think we're spending money in the right place.
Let's see. We've got -- we have -- as you pointed out, there a number of -- and in fact some of them are not 100G, some of them are 300G. So we are -- some of these board-mounted optical engines have enormous bandwidth for a very small size of the device. We are working in most of these areas on relatively new developments, whether they be totally new systems on the part of the manufacturer, or in some cases big, new supercomputers. I would expect that -- I mean, I still expect that in our next fiscal year for sure, our 100G Ethernet business overall is going to be bigger than it ever has been in the past. But can it be as a result of some of these other products, could it be larger even sooner? And the answer is maybe. But on -- I don't know what I would necessarily predict.
Let's see, pricing. Pricing varies sector-to-sector, country-to-country. It's all over the place in some sense. But it's a competitive industry. It always has been a competitive industry. And prices don't ever go up. So that's just a fact that we live with and the only issue is, do they go down faster in 1 quarter than they do in another quarter or 1 year more than they did in the previous year. Right now, I would say the market in China is particularly competitive because there's a lot of domestic Chinese suppliers that supply there and are qualified to supply there. So that's probably the toughest pricing environment that we face right now. I think in the rest of our -- in the rest of the markets -- telecom, we're about to go through an annual price negotiation that will come in this fall for effect in calendar year '15. So I don't yet know how that's going to turn out. In our broad datacom Enterprise as well as the hyper data center activity, all of that is -- are price negotiations or are purchase order negotiations on a shorter-term basis, typically, quarterly or every 6 months. There's nothing in general, nothing extraordinary that's going on in pricing or competition there. So it's...
Well, I think it's about the same as we see. An increase in revenues over our historical levels in 100G Ethernet. So if that happens in this -- late this fiscal year or early in the next fiscal year, I think that -- I think we would expect not only revenues to be at record levels, but we would also expect the profit contributions to be there.
That's not right.
Dmitry, I'll talk a little bit about the datacom opportunities and I'm going to let Eitan work on telecom. From our standpoint, we don't think we have exhausted the opportunities in datacom at all. We think there are many exciting opportunities still in the 40G, 100G and even faster. And many, many different form factors: the CFP2, the CFP4, the QSFP. We are still very optimistic that the datacom market is -- it provides a lot of opportunities for an optics company like us. So we are investing record, record dollars in R&D on a record number of projects for us to support a really big customer base. So Eitan, you want to talk about this telecom side?
Cassandra, thank you. And I thank everyone else for tuning in today. We appreciate your time. And we hope that you will be able to tune in 3 months from now as we have our second quarter call. Good day.
column3:
Thank you, Kevin, and good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate your taking the time to listen to our conference call today. A replay of this call should appear on our website within 8 hours. An audio replay will be available for 2 weeks by calling area code (888) 203-1112 for domestic, or area code (719) 457-0820 for international. Then, you should enter the ID number 1607677.


I need to remind all of you that any forward-looking statements in today's discussion are subject to risks and uncertainties which are discussed at length in our annual and quarterly SEC filings. Actual events and results can differ materially from any forward-looking statements. In addition, the company undertakes no obligations to update any forward-looking information presented. Unless otherwise indicated, all results discussed are on a non-GAAP basis. A complete reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP results may be found in our earnings press release, and in the Investor Relations section of our website. We have prepared some slides for today's earnings call. You can view them by connecting to the Investor Relations page of our website at finisar.com, click on Investors, then scroll down to webcast archives and click. You'll see a listing for today's second quarter 2015 earnings call.


Revenues for our second fiscal quarter were $297 million, an increase of $6.3 million compared to the second fiscal quarter of 2014, but a decrease of $30.7 million or 9.4% from the first fiscal quarter of fiscal 2015.


The second quarter was challenging. During the quarter, we experience decreased demand from both the telecom and datacom markets. Telecom suffered from sluggish carrier capital expenditures. And datacom saw decreased sales of transceivers for wireless applications. In addition, datacom revenues declined due to lumpy orders from a few large customers.


Now I'll let Kurt review the rest of the numbers. Kurt?
Thanks, Eitan. We expect our revenue to grow sequentially in the third fiscal quarter. This growth will primarily be driven by the demand for 40 gigabit and 100 gigabit datacom transceivers as well as transceivers for wireless applications. We expect revenues for our third quarter will be in the range of $297 million to $312 million.


We expect non-GAAP gross margins to be approximately 31% as the benefit from growth and revenues is offset by the impact of 1 month of the annual telecom price reductions that typically take effect on January 1. In addition, as Kurt pointed out earlier, depreciation will increase by approximately $1.5 million over Q2. As a reminder, our fourth quarter will have a full 3-months' impact of the annual telecom price reduction.


Non-GAAP operating expenses are expected to be approximately flat with Q2, except the potential increase in sales and marketing due to higher revenue levels. Non-GAAP operating margins are expected to be approximately 8.4% to 9.4%.


Non-GAAP earnings per diluted share should be in the range of $0.23 to $0.27 per share. We continue to believe in the long-term growth prospects of the company. Finisar's revenue is driven primarily by the growth in worldwide demand for bandwidth with the ever-increasing distribution and use of video and other digital information.


In addition, Finisar continues to benefit from the growth in cloud services, which drives network hardware upgrades of existing data centers and the build-out of new hyperscale data centers. These large data centers need more high-speed optical connections. Over time we believe data centers and carriers will spend more money on optics to meet their needs for increased bandwidth. And we believe Finisar is uniquely positioned with our broad product line, extensive customer engagements, profitable vertically-integrated business model, and strong balance sheet to capitalize on these market opportunities.
And now, with that I'm going to turn it back over to Kevin and open it up for questions.

Question and Answer
.....................................................................................................................................................................................................................
Well, we think our revenues are going to increase in our third quarter, and we're very about optimistic about the future beyond that. So we had some, I don't know, rough water in this last quarter. It was a tough quarter for us. But we're still very optimistic that the strength, in particular, in the datacom sector is going to drive our revenues higher. Telecom, I don't know. Maybe, Eitan, do you want to talk a little bit about metro upgrades and some of the spending we expect to come in 2015 and 2016 there?
You asked about CapEx.
Well, datacom is competitive. We have a number of competitors there. And has it really changed? We see a few more Chinese competitors than we've probably seen if we think about this year versus last year. But I don't -- I think one of the things that has occurred over the last several years is that we had a lot of success in terms of revenue growth in the datacom sector. And therefore, I think there's a number of competitors who, heretofore, had revenues mostly in telecom that are now trying to build products that can be sold into the datacom sector. So we expect competition to stay rigorous, but I don't think it's going to be dramatically different than what it has been in the past.
Let's see. Consolidation. I think it's a good thing. We have thought for a long time that we have -- there's more companies in our industry that are doing research and development on the same products, and I don't think that's very efficient. And I think the industry in general would benefit from having a fewer number of competitors. So if we could consolidate or if this industry could consolidate into a more efficient sector, it would be good for all of us, I think.
The other thing you asked about, Subu, was revenue being lumpy and where was that? Well, it was from customers who have construction projects that consume a lot of optics.
Yes.
We're starting to ship more of the CFP2. We have -- but our revenues are still a lot more in CFP than they are in CFP2. And our revenues overall in the 100 gig Ethernet are growing and we expect them to continue to grow.
My guess is you've got some of everything that's rolled in there. We've got some that's lumpy because we sell a lot of it into the big data centers. We have some that goes into wireless, and as we've said, wireless was weak in the quarter. And our prices never go up. So they always come down a little bit, so there's always some impact of pricing in there.
I think 10 gig will continue to grow for several years. 10 gigabit will be -- for the enterprise data centers will be the predominant speed for all the new switches that are going to be used in enterprise networking. Now 40 gig is predominantly used by the Web 2.0 mega data centers or hyperscale data centers. And I think the growth rate in 40 gig is clearly going to be faster on a percentage basis than 10 gig will.
Well, we sell our 40 gig QSFP products to a number of companies. But mostly, they're in the Web 2.0 space as opposed to the OEM space. And the typical uses are for top-of-rack switch to the aggregation switch connections. So you're coming out with multiple -- but it's about density in that you've got 10 gig lanes, but in a single port, you now can put 4 10-gig lanes in a single plug-in, whereas before it was 1 10-gig lane per plug-in. So it's increasing the density of the bit density of the switch, and it's mostly switch-to-switch connections.
I think it's going to be a very healthy ramp as we move through 2015. And not everybody in the space has made the move from 10 gigabit to 40 gigabit yet. So there are still others yet to move.
I think you're right on. Consolidation occurs when you have the number of participants actually decrease in number. In this particular case with the Koch Industries acquisition, you're not -- we're not decreasing the number of participants. They just have a different ownership. But I do think it's very exciting that a deep-pockets investment group like the Koch brothers would choose the optics industry as a place to put billions of their dollars at work.
With respect to datacom in 2015 and beyond, I think that the good thing about growth is that it happens at the highest speeds. And yes, though there may be some competitors who appear in the market that weren't there a couple of years ago, most of them offer products that are not cutting-edge. And so when we gain market share and historically have gained market share, most of that comes not because we were knocking off new equipment companies in the industry, and mostly became -- because as the speeds move higher, we were there with products and we actually had fewer competitors at the higher speeds. So I think it's very possible that we would continue to gain market share in datacom.
Well, yes. I mean, China is the big market, and so that's where the most of the volume is.
Well, we think 40 gig overall is going to grow for quite a while. So we're very positive on the sector. We're adding capacity. Some of that CapEx that Kurt talked about is headed in that direction. In the quarter, the lumpiness had to do with project pauses. And one of the things about the mega data center, hyper data center market is that they are construction projects, and they're subject to construction delays and all of the pieces coming together at the right time. And sometimes it isn't perfect.
I'm not sure that we could tell you exactly what all the sources of weakness are. There was a supply chain problem with one of the ICs, the critical ICs. But we have also, we've also heard feedback from China that said there was inventory correction because there was too much inventory at some of the -- at not only the big carriers but also some of the equipment companies. So they sound a little bit inconsistent to say, wait a minute, we've slowed down because we've got a supply chain, but also our inventories are too high so we've got a correction. But one of the problems is that there's always a bit of mystery when you're dealing with China. It's just a little different than sort of our traditional business in the U.S.
No, I do think so. I don't think any of the competitive aspects of that business are affecting the projects. Projects are mostly related to construction, sometimes weather, transportation, lots of things that can contribute to that. And overall, I can't -- with respect to the economics of the cloud services business, it's a little difficult for us to understand exactly how lucrative that business is for all of the participants right now. I mean, it is obviously, the expectations are very high. But the amount of money that is being spent on the expansion in that industry is unbelievable. So is the spending proportional to the opportunity? I don't know. I think, Ted, we're going to have to depend on analysts like you to go do the calculations.
Well, the forecasts that we've read would say -- or have said, that there's something in the order of 2 million towers that are required to do a 4G upgrade in China. And in the last year, they did a 200,000 tower upgrade, and now it's a few hundred thousand more. But at that rate, it's going to take another 2 years at least, maybe 3. And it depends a lot on the political winds in China because a lot of the spending is driven by national priorities, and that's a little hard to predict sometimes.
Well, by then we hope our 100 gig CFP2 coherent is now a big success in the market and we get a big market share, and we think that's going to help a lot. We think that there's still fourth generation upgrades of wireless in the rest of the world. I mean, China is leading the world right now, but there's still a lot of 3G towers in the rest of the world where upgrades are coming. And I don't know when -- fifth generation is out there ahead of us somewhere. Now it's few years away I think, but there is discussions, planning, experiments, hardware, lots of things going on that -- where people are planning the next wireless generation, which will be even higher bandwidth.
Sure.
Let's see. With respect to your Cisco question, Cisco is our largest customer. They have been for a long time and they're a very good customer, a successful company. And as you pointed out, the softness in our datacom business in the last quarter was predominantly Web 2.0.
I don't know what our market share is in 40 gig datacom. I guess I'd have to look at -- dig up the Infonetics, our Infonetics or LightCounting or one of those industry analysts and see what they had to say. But off the top of my head, I don't know what it is.
Yes. I mean the answer is, for 40 gig, we've had more orders than we were able to deliver, so it's still pretty strong demand.
Well, we have seen, historically, competition that came from Chinese suppliers, where most of it appeared in the gray market. It was counterfeits, knockoffs, what were known as compatibles, where the security codes from the big OEMs were programmed into these devices. Some of them -- and many of them even came with counterfeit labels that said they were from a big OEM. So that was a big sale of things from China. In the last couple of years, we have seen more inroads, if that's the right word, more companies making sales calls anyway, at least in some of the data center users that were companies from China. So I think that's -- and some of those were 10 gigabit. So that's -- and I don't think that that's really surprising because most of the Chinese competitors are usually a couple of generations behind wherever our latest product is. And the 10-gig product has been out there for several years.
Well, I thank you, Kevin, and I appreciate your help. And my thanks to everyone for tuning in today. We hope that you will come back in 3 months and join us again. So all of you have a good day.
column4:
Thank you, Matt. And good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate your taking the time to listen to our conference call today. A replay of this call should appear on our website within 8 hours. An audio replay will be available for 2 weeks by calling area code (888) 203-1112 for domestic, or area code (719) 457-0820 for international. And then enter the ID number 3629508.


I need to remind all of you that any forward-looking statements in today's discussion are subject to risks and uncertainties which are discussed at length in our annual and quarterly SEC filings. Actual events and results can differ materially from any forward-looking statements. In addition, the company undertakes no obligations to update any forward-looking information presented. In addition, unless otherwise indicated, all results discussed are on a non-GAAP basis. A complete reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP results may be found in our earnings press release and in the Investor Relations section of our website. We have prepared some slides for today's earnings call. You can view them by connecting to the Investor Relations page of our website at finisar.com, click on Investors, then scroll down and click on website -- Webcast Archives. You'll see a listing for today's third quarter 2015 earnings call.


Revenues for our just completed third fiscal quarter were $306.3 million, an increase of $9.3 million over the prior quarter. Revenue growth was primarily driven by the demand for 40 gigabit and 100 gigabit transceivers for datacom applications as well as transceivers for fourth generation wireless base station installations.


And now, with that, I'll let Kurt review the rest of the numbers. Kurt?
Well, as you point out, that market is still going strong. There are an awful lot of 40 gig transceivers in the QSFP form factor that are being consumed by a number of the big cloud services operators and it's a competitive market. It's like all the markets that we participate in. It has a number of competitors and it's all about performance. It's all about economics. So I don't know how to describe it much differently than that.
Well, the telecom pricing pressure comes mostly at the end of the calendar year where we have negotiations with the big equipment companies for prices that go for a yearly -- for 12 months. There are a few exceptions to that, but for the most part, we negotiate sort of 12-month agreements in the telecom business. So that's behind us now.
Let's see. Our crossover for CFP2 to CFP is -- we're not quite there, but we're almost there. And we had substantial growth in CFP2, but we also had -- we had a very good quarter for the CFPs.
I don't really have a lot of good data on that one. Just a minute. We don't see much of it, but I know that they're being sold, so I don't -- and I couldn't comment on the volumes. I couldn't comment on the impact, if there is an impact on our business. And I just don't know.
Well, we continue to believe that consolidation is important in our industry, and it would be attractive to achieve consolidation. But with respect to JDSU, or any other company, I don't think we have any particular comments to make.
Well, one of the frustrations of that Web 2.0 sector is all of the revenue that goes into it, at least from our end, is sort of dependent upon construction projects. And the construction projects have many facets. There's physical structure, there's electrical distribution, there's air-conditioning, there's the wiring, there's all the hardware that goes in. And if any one of those runs late, then the whole project runs late and you get -- and our optics after you got all the stuff in place get plugged in, and now you connect everything. So forecasting has been a challenge, because our customers in these construction projects have been challenged with having predictable schedules. And so I -- the business is strong, the market has still a lot of demand, percentage growth maybe slower in the future than it has been in the past, I've read predictions like that. But the absolute magnitude of the growth is greater than it has been in the past and -- or are expected to be. So it's a big market becoming a much bigger market. So we're still paying a lot of attention there. And we just wish that there was a little less volatility, if that's the right word, in the shipment patterns that we have with the big 2.0 operators.
Let's see. Datacom, in general, I would say the enterprise part of the business is mostly 10 gigabit Ethernet, and 10 gigabit Ethernet continues to be a good product, and revenues we expect for the quarter will be up a bit in that sector. It's not the 100 gig and 40 gig have pretty specific targets but they're not really enterprise. They tend to be hyperscale or the client sides of routers. But overall enterprise seems to be doing well with moderate growth rates. The Fibre Channel sector, I mean, it's again not a rapidly growing sector overall. But one of the things that we're seeing now is much more rapid take of 16 gig Fibre Channel. Most of our shipments for several years now have been 8 gigabit Fibre Channel. And the 16 gig was sort of limited to the switch makers. But now we're starting to ship 16 gigabit Fibre Channel to a number of the equipment suppliers of the storage arrays and host bus adapters, et cetera. So we expect that 16 gig will be greater than 8 gig shipments here, probably within the next year.
Oh, Avago and  Emulex. I don't have -- I don't really have a view of that one. Emulex has been a good customer of ours for a long time. On the other hand, now we -- Avago is a competitor in that datacom space. And so my guess is that there's going to be some decisions that have to be made there. But in general, any customer, anyone of the equipment companies wants to have at least 2 sources of supply even if one is internal. So I would expect that we will still have ongoing relationship with Emulex.
We think so, but nobody told us exactly. It's been a -- there's an element of security and maybe you can even say secrecy that goes with some of the Web 2.0 competitors. I mean, the competitive guys that are in the Web 2.0 business building out these data centers and they're trying to protect information about their business and their activities. So it's not always that we have very specific information about why is our business going up or why was our business going down. In this case it was going up, so. And to follow up...
Well, the biggest change over that period when our gross margins have gone from 37% to 30% has been in 100 gig Ethernet. If you recall, if we go back a 1.5 years ago, we had virtually, I don't know, if we didn't have 100% of the market, we had 85% or 90% of the market. We were an early entry. We had a CFP 100 gig LR4 device that was fully functional. It contained an IC set that we designed here at Finisar and there were no other functional ICs in the industry. And so our sales were growing very rapidly, our margins were exceptionally high. We were on allocation for several quarters. And -- but all that came to an end as merchant semiconductor companies were able to correct the errors in their chips and produce functional chips, and so then a number of competitors were empowered. They entered the market at substantially lower prices and so we had -- our prices had to come down to be competitive. So that has been the largest impact on our margins over the last year, 1.5 years.
Yes.
It's still the same.
Let's see. CFP2 is going to be an exciting product area. It is exciting for us right now in that we are shipping everything we can build. If we could double our output, we could sell double our output. But we are increasing our capacity. Demand is strong. Equipment companies are designing blades that have CFP2 ports because they can double the density on their blades. And I think it's an exciting market. Now the margins there will never be as high as they were with our original CFP because we have competitors and in CFP, we were the only game in town. So -- but the margins are quite good. I mean, it's not like, it's a bad product. It's a good product and we think the demand is going to be strong as the equipment companies convert their boxes to having these high density blades. I mean, there's still a lot of ports for CFP. There's a lot of ports even that are being shipped from the OEMs, but there's a lot of ports in the field that are -- that were shipped where blades were not fully populated and for the expansion of networks at -- in central offices. They continue to buy CFPs and plug them in the CFP slots. So we're going to see CFP revenue for quite some time but CFP2 is clearly growing faster.
Higher. CFP2 is higher than the corporate average.
All of the above. I mean, any consolidation move could accomplish any one of those things or multiple of them. And the more of factors that you could make positive contribution through some acquisition, I mean, that makes it more attractive. That means there's more value there, so.
Thanks, everybody, for tuning in today. We appreciate your time and your attention, and we hope you're going to join us again 3 months from now. Good day.
column5:
It's mostly in the datacom space.
I would say it's both single mode and multimode.
Well, hyperscale data centers are a little bit different than enterprise in that they often will accept products that are "good enough" and don't necessarily have to meet all of the industry specifications, the Bellcore specs, et cetera. And so that means that they will accept offerings from less than Tier 1 companies. And so it's a -- there is a bit more competitive pressures that go into that space. And so -- but nevertheless, we expect to maintain our market share. We're the largest supplier in the world and we're the largest supplier into that space. And I -- our expectations are that we will be -- we will absolutely be competitive and we're going to maintain our market share.
It's lumpiness. We expect that 40 Gb is going to be very strong next quarter. We had one particular customer who we expected to ship more to, and they had predicted but they -- part of the lumpiness of their acceptance pattern shifted out to the next quarter.
Well, it's both strength in CFP and CFP2. We still sell more CFP and there's more CFP slots out there to fill than there are CFP2. But as you might expect, more and more hardware designs are being created with CFP2 sockets. So we think over the next year or 2, CFP2 is going to continue to increase and it will eventually overtake CFP. But right now, they're both alive, well and doing -- and strong in revenue and -- but still, CFP is larger.
It's 10 Gb, it's wireless. And it's 40 Gb as well because remember, 40 Gb is really 4 lanes of 10 Gb, so the basic technology is still 10 Gb technology and it's not at 100 Gb.
It will happen in the second half of this year as well start seeing much more 100 Gb 4x25 in data centers, and I think it will be really exciting in the calendar year '16. And overall, that data center market is still the fastest-growing segment in all of optics, so it is quite an opportunity.
Well, we expect that our datacom business is going to continue to grow; and we expect that it's going to be the strongest part of our business, led by hyperscale or Web 2.0 data centers. But the challenge in that space is that there aren't hundreds of customers. There are a handful of customers, and each one of them has their own characteristics of forecasting, accepting delivery, et cetera, and they often are related to construction projects, which have at least historically been pretty lumpy in terms of their sort of stops and starts or unexpected delays.
Book-to-bill is above 1. Visibility in datacom is -- it varies some. Most of our customers, particularly enterprise customers, are -- we operate on just-in-time hubs. And so we have, by classic definition, no visibility. On the day they want the product, they pull it out of the hub. They send us an electronic notice. We ship them an electronic invoice and the transaction is complete. But there was no visibility beyond the fact that they had given us a forecast and that we had inventory there available to pull. With the Web 2.0 group, we have some inventory hubs that we provide, but much of it is on orders that are shipped based on a purchase order. So there's a little visibility there, but it varies. But overall in datacom, visibility is limited to what our customers tell us they're going to pull or they're going to take.
Most of them, almost all, are taking 40 Gb products. All will take 100 Gb products.
I think it's an architecture decision. It's sort of what switches did they buy? What servers did they buy? What are the slots that they've invested in? And then what is their transition plan to transition to the next faster piece of equipment? And I think there's a number of them that are -- there's been lots of publicity about Broadcom and their Tomahawk chipset and its availability in the second half of this year and systems that will actually be built and deployed with it. So that will provide 100 Gb ports and multiples of 25. It's 4x25. So it's mostly architectural.
We wouldn't invest all that money in that beautiful new factory in China if we didn't think it was going to help. So...
We're going to be in that business as long as we can make money in that business. And if the day comes when prices get so low that we say "It's not profitable to continue", then we'll stop. But generally, we have a lot of capacity and when there's a lot of demand, we can sell our capacity and get a reasonable price for it.
Product mix is always probably the most important factor probably followed by volume.
But we're excited also about a whole series of products that are based on lane rates of 25 gigabits or 28 gigabits. So multiples of 25, 4x25 is 100. 12x25 is 300. There's a number of products that will use the 25 gigabit technology to provide really enormous bandwidth. And our product portfolio in that area, I don't -- there are a number of products that will be introduced here over the next 6 to 9 months.
You're asking about intra data center? That means inside the data center?
Yes, well, it's going to develop rapidly. As equipment is deployed, it has 100 Gb slots for optics to plug into. It will develop -- it will follow those switches and those servers. It's going to have -- it's going to start in a big way in the second half of this calendar year and we'll go into next fiscal year -- or next calendar year we expect it to be a very strong and very robust market.
PSM4 probably is next year. That single mode, most of -- a lot of the offerings that we're going to have in the space will be single mode in LR4 or will be multimode in SR4, 4SR as they refer to it.
Well, in the data center market, market share leaders for years have been Finisar and Avago and I don't -- that hasn't changed. But in the Web 2.0 space, there's a number of new entrants that are at least offering products there some more successful than others. But I still think that I don't think market share in the datacom space has changed.
Yes.
We are a modestly or moderately acquisitive company. We've done, I think since our IPO, maybe 21 acquisitions. Most of them were pretty small. Most of them were for specific technologies. But -- and I am certain we will do more acquisitions in the future. Consolidation would be one motivation to do an acquisition, and I believe strongly in consolidation as an important part of a healthy market. But I can't predict when any consolidation transaction is likely to be available. So we're interested.
Most of our revenue comes today from a couple of customers, but we have a number of them that are lined up in the wings that are either in some stage of evaluation or qualification.
We have high hopes in this area because we think it is a pretty amazing product. To be able to supply as much bandwidth in a smaller package as these optical engines do, I think it's a very attractive packaging alternative for anybody building a system or building a motherboard. So we have -- our expectations are that we're going to see dramatic growth in this product line over the next couple of years, maybe forever. I mean, it's -- we just think that it's a product whose time has come and the applications for it are going to increase every year.
Well, I apologize for being muddled. We are optimistic about our business. We're building new factories because we think we're going to need the volumes. We expect that optics are going to continue to grow and the principal driver right now is the Web 2.0 space. And then next year, it's going to be big in telecom with all of the metro build-outs. So I apologize again. We don't want to be muddled. We are optimistic. So it's -- we don't give guidance beyond the next quarter and that's been our policy for a long time. So...
Thanks, Shannon, and thank you, everyone, who joined us today. We hope you'll all be able to join us again 3 months from now. Good day.

I would say it's both single mode and multimode.

column6:
Thank you, Kevin, and good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate your taking the time to listen to our conference call today. A replay of this call should appear on our website within 8 hours. An audio replay will be available for 2 weeks by calling area code (888) 203-1112 for domestic, or area code (719) 457-0820 for international. Then, you enter the ID number 8055566.


I need to remind all of you that any forward-looking statements in today's discussion are subject to risks and uncertainties which are discussed at length in our annual and quarterly SEC filings. Actual events and results can differ materially from any forward-looking statements.


In addition, the company undertakes no obligations to update any forward-looking information presented. Unless otherwise indicated, all results discussed are on a non-GAAP basis. A complete reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP results may be found in our earnings press release and in the Investor Relations section of our website.


We have prepared some slides for today's earnings call. You can view them by connecting to the Investor Relations page of our website at finisar.com, click on Investors, then scroll down and click on Webcast Archives. You'll see a listing for today's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call.


Before I begin the discussion of our first quarter results, let me review an announcement we made today. We announced the resignation of Chief Executive Officer and Director, Eitan Gertel. On behalf of the entire company, we thank Eitan for his contributions to Finisar. Since joining the company in 2008, in connection with the Optium merger, Eitan has played an important role in Finisar's success as the world's largest supplier of optical transceivers. We appreciate Eitan's leadership and the important initiatives he has driven for the company.


With Eitan's departure, I have assumed the title of Chief Executive Officer and will continue as the company's principal executive officer and as its Chairman.


Revenues for our first quarter of fiscal year 2016 were $314 million compared to $320 million in the prior quarter. However, the prior quarter had the benefit of an additional week for a total of 14 weeks versus Q1 which had 13 weeks. Taking that into consideration, the first fiscal quarter had a higher average weekly revenue than the prior quarter. This higher weekly revenue in Q1 was primarily from increased sales of 40 gigabit transceivers for datacom applications.


Now I'll turn it over to Kurt for a review of the numbers.
Thanks, Kurt. We expect revenues for our second quarter of fiscal year 2016 to be in the range of $304 million to $324 million. We expect non-GAAP gross margins to be approximately 30% as we continue to see a high level of competition. We have started taking actions to reduce our operating expense levels. We expect operating expenses to be approximately 21.4% of revenue in the second quarter as compared to 21.8% in the first quarter. Our target is to ultimately have operating expenses at approximately 20% of revenue. Our plan is to achieve this during the first half of fiscal 2017.


Non-GAAP operating margins in Q2 are expected to be approximately 8% to 9%. Non-GAAP earnings per diluted share are expected to be in the range of $0.20 to $0.26 per share.


While we expect the remainder of fiscal 2016 to be challenging, we are optimistic about fiscal 2017. We expect to benefit from the ramp of many new products and associated revenue growth, driven by both data center construction and upgrades and the increased deployments of ROADMs and 100G coherent transceivers in the telecom/metro market. We continue to believe that the long-term growth prospects of our company and the optical communications industry are positive.


From our position as the industry leader, we will continue to develop the technology and the next generation of products for both the datacom and the telecom markets.


Finisar's revenue is driven primarily by growth in the global demand for bandwidth due to the increasing distribution and use of video, images and digital information. In addition, Finisar continues to benefit from the growth in cloud services, which drives networking hardware upgrades of existing data centers and the build-out of new hyperscale data centers.
And now, I'm going to turn it back over to Kevin and open it up for questions. Kevin?

Question and Answer
.....................................................................................................................................................................................................................
Eitan's resignation resulted from a decision made mutually by him and the Board of Directors. Eitan -- it had nothing to do with performance or any particular event or circumstance. Just the Board and Eitan agreed to effect this transition now. We appreciated Eitan. I like Eitan. He made valuable contributions to the company and we're grateful for that. But with the second part of your question, it doesn't affect any of the programs that were related to the telecom market. We're still very enthusiastic about our development of line cards, our development of 100G Coherent tranceivers, the whole family of wavelength selective switches. This is -- those are all still important initiatives for the company.
Well, what we said was that we expected that our fiscal year '17 would be stronger. And we were optimistic about it. Our fiscal year '17 starts on May 1. Our fiscal year '16 ends on April 30. So it's a little earlier than you suggested. But we're still -- it's all about 100G in the data center. It's about the 25G rollout and all of the 25G I/O that's related to switches and servers. That's really important, that's coming. One of the things that has happened though in the last quarter, since I last spoke to you, anyway, was that -- is that we have heard that the major telecom metro upgrade has been pushed out another quarter and is now, appears to be a second half of calendar year '16 event. So there's a little delay in some of the revenue opportunities.
I don't think there's any important change in that. I think it still exists. It is still a part of the industry that we have to deal with and it's -- I think it's reality, and -- but it's not different than our products have been for a decade. The lower end products always affect competition from non-Tier 1 companies. And in some period of time, it just takes -- whether it's a 1 year or a 3-year, whatever the period, they -- Tier 2 competitors always catch up. So...
Well, OpEx -- the biggest part of our operating expenses are in fact R&D. But we still spend a lot of money in G&A and we spend a lot of money in sales and marketing and all the administrative kinds of things. And so we're just trying to tighten up in all of those areas to make sure we're as efficient as we possibly can be. And if you're -- as Alex pointed out, our earnings have declined. And one of the things we're trying to do is turn that around. We are spending more money on R&D than any other company in this industry by a lot. And I'm -- I think we are spending sufficient dollars to invest in technology and product development. So it's -- we're -- we remain committed to R&D as the lifeblood of the company.
For us, the answer is, move products through the development cycle at a faster pace, and we're trying to evaluate all of the hurdles and the chokepoints that we have in the product development cycle and try -- how we ease those. But we're not considering to diversify into the hamburger business or any other unrelated business. We're committed to optical communications. That's what we do well. That's what we have the most talented workforce and pool of engineers in the world. And we're going to continue to exploit that.
Data center, I can't tell you necessarily what total data center spending is. I can tell you what -- our -- the demand for optics remain strong. Our sales there remain strong. We're optimistic. But one of the thing -- and it's going to be strong for a long time. But one of the things that is proven to be a characteristic of the Web 2.0 market is that the revenues there are lumpy. They are unpredictable to some level by us. But they're also unpredictable in -- by some of the Web 2.0 companies themselves.
Well, I think economies of scale are a key differentiator in almost any market. And I think that's one of the advantages we have in optical communications, is that we have the largest volume of anybody in the industry. So I think that benefits us. I have said many times that I think of -- consolidation could benefit this industry. But it is so fragmented, particularly on the telecom side. But as we see in the Web 2.0 space, it's becoming more fragmented on the datacom side as well. So it's -- consolidation would be a long, long roll up of a lot of companies. So I think it'd be very -- I still think it's very difficult to do. And that's one of the reason we have had so little effective consolidation in the past.
Right now, we're matching prices. In some cases, we don't actually match the price, but we have to get close. And we haven't seen levels, or we haven't seen products get to the level where we've had to walk away.
Actually, 40G was probably a little better than expected. We had a really strong quarter in the 40G and datacom. And that was, I think a little bit due to, as I referred to earlier, the lumpiness in the Web 2.0 demand.
It was pretty steady through the whole quarter.
I would say there's a wave of activity on the part of the Web 2.0 companies that are moving toward that 25G I/O end switches. And that's going to be multiple, like, 4 -- and the 4x 25G or 100G ethernet is going to be an interconnect, that's going to be important in calendar year '16. Tell me again, Joseph, you asked some question earlier that sort of blew by me.
There will be some differences. There's some customers who will want 4x 25G in single mode versions and there will be other customers who want 4x 25G for multi-mode versions inside the data center and only transitioning to single mode as the links go across campuses or between data centers. And that is not uniform. The uniformity in the push by the Web 2.0 companies is that push toward the 25G I/O for the switches.
China is probably -- overall, it approaches 10% of our revenue. Maybe it's a little more than 10% of our revenue, I guess, now if I add up sort of the OEM stuff and all of that various, various big consumers over there. The -- but in general, I don't know, I think the China demand has been pretty good. We had a weak quarter in wireless. But we don't think the future is -- we think there's going to be -- the fourth-generation LTE expansion in China is still going on, we expect to sell a lot of transceivers there, and now, for I don't know, how many -- next couple of years, anyway.
We have 25G lasers. We have 25G photo detectors. We are -- I -- we have the building blocks to build those products. And right now -- and we have supplied early samples and the prototypes for companies to do their system test to a number of customers. So it's coming, and we're ready.
I don't know. I just heard that one of the big carriers who is targeting a 100G Coherent upgrade of their metro network next year has moved that -- the implementation date out by a quarter. So I don't know exactly what that means. It's maybe between them and the system vendors that are supplying them. It could -- often in these systems, the long tent pole is software and it could be the network management system at the service provider or it could be the similar software interface at the equipment provider. I just don't know, I would be speculating.
Well, we are interested in consolidation. And over the years, we have -- we've completed, I think, 21 acquisitions since we went public in 1999. So I'm sure we will do more acquisitions. But the criteria for each one of them is that it is a benefit to our shareholders. And it's a benefit because we can increase earnings per share. We can acquire technology that we can use to build products that will increase earnings per share. And it's a simple criteria. So we will continue to use that criteria as we approach opportunities for consolidation.
Well, calendar year '16, which is most of our fiscal year '17, is going to be the year of 25G I/O in the data centers. And so there will be a whole new series of switches, families of switches that will come from all of the networking equipment companies and the white box switch companies, a new -- servers with 25G I/O. So I mean, it's a whole series of new optical products where the base rate is 25 gigabits. And then we do multiples of 25G, was where we get to the 100G I/O in a single socket.
James, I think our revenues in 100G are still larger in CFP than they are CFP2. But I think our volumes may be larger in CFP2.
I think it's going to be meaningful this fiscal year, right? I think we're seeing increases in sales. We're shipping a lot of early production or early samples for qualification and testing to a number of customers, both OEMs and Web 2.0 companies. So I honestly -- I think it's -- our third and fourth quarters of this fiscal year, I think we're going to see meaningful revenue from the QSFP28 form factor.
Well, the opportunity is large. It is -- if I quote the RHK and Infonetics, some of the guys who track these markets, it's a $500 million market in 2016, '17, increasing to an $800 million a year market in '17, '18. And then the question is, what share of that market can we win? Well, we're still very optimistic that we have an excellent product that is going to garner a disproportionate market share. So we're optimistic about it.
We're working on lower-cost versions of all the products that we ship into the Web 2.0 space. We're-- and we'll have reduced cost in 10G, reduced cost in 40G and our new 100G products are coming out. The cost reduced versions of those will be out early. So I -- it's -- I would say most of these are about the targets about the first of the calendar year, or the end of this calendar year.
No, I haven't. I have seen -- Huawei has acquired small optics companies in Europe that had, not production capability, but technology. Nothing recently, but on the last couple of years, maybe. But I haven't seen anything out of China recently.
Well, we think it's an advantage to be vertically integrated. Now you've got to define vertical integration. I mean, for us, a typical transceiver has a laser that we make, a photo detector that we make, a number of ICs or a large integrated IC that we design and we go to foundry to have it fabricated. And then we do assembly and test, where we put together the printed circuit board with the optics, with the stampings and castings and connectors to connect it to the optical network. So vertical integration, that's really important to us are those lasers, photo detectors and ICs. The assembly and test is something that we do very efficiently because of our scale of operations. But we always weigh make versus buy there. Could -- can we have a contract manufacturer do it for us for less money than we can do it ourselves? In general, we find that, that analysis shows that we can do it more efficiently and less expensively ourselves. But we are sure open to that. It's -- I don't know -- that's just part of trying to run the most efficient business we can.
Well, we think of ourselves as a growth company. We think of ourselves as a company who is increasing market share. And we have done that very consistently for the last, I don't know, 8 years, we've increased market share every year. And our expectation and our goal is to continue with that. The industry analysts that track our industry, Light Counting, RHK and Phonetics, predict that this industry is going to grow at somewhere around 12% per year for the next 5 years. Now I will point out that the industry -- their estimates 5 years ago were a little optimistic. But nevertheless, our goal was that our revenue should grow that faster, faster. And we're investing in a lot of new products and a lot of new technologies to make sure that, that can happen.
Well, the succession plan is not one that we're likely have public discussions about. I will tell you that it's an important discussion at the Board level, and obviously, at our most recent Board meeting, which was yesterday and the day before, there were a lot of discussions about succession. So yes, there's -- there is planning. There is discussions and -- but nothing is -- there's no succession imminent. I have assured the Board that I'm around for the foreseeable future.
Well, we're optimistic about the wireless business. I expect that we'll see -- I don't know, I think our revenues will grow a bit in this quarter. But I think that for the next several quarters, I would expect that our wireless revenues will increase. Storage is actually an interesting space. We're seeing -- we've seen some strength in storage, particularly with respect to 16 gigabit Fibre Channel and whereas our revenues of 16 gigabit are climbing pretty rapidly to overtake 8 gigabit. So I think that's -- the storage market is one that people don't think of very often. But we at Finisar have a very large market share there. And I just happened to look the other day at a Light Counting report for the Fibre Channel market. And they do predict that it's -- that optics and Fiber Channel are going to grow at a 9% rate per year for the next 5 years. So it's not a stagnant market.
No, that's actually...
The thing that's nice about the storage market is that storage is about Fibre Channel and SANs. It's the company jewels. It's the Oracle database. The SAP database. It has to be rock-solid reliable. Companies that supply equipment into that space, like our reliability, like that we are the gold standard of the industry and that's an advantage for us. It's -- whereas it's a little -- it's a lot different than that in the Web 2.0 space.
Well, I think it's been a real asset for the company. Yesterday, I was at Cisco and was on stage receiving an award for Finisar for the last year as being the most flexible company, in terms of achieving unexpected deliveries of product when Cisco had upside demand. And the reason we can do that is we own our own factories. And we can respond quickly. We control our own priorities. Now to your -- to the extent that -- the other issue with the factories is we control our quality, we control our turnaround and responsiveness. We control our IP and if you -- if we went to a contract manufacturer, all of the equipment that we put in these factories, we would have to spend that same CapEx, short of just building the building. We'd have to spend that same CapEx to put equipment in the factories of our contract manufacturers. Because they operate basic pick and place equipment. But if you want specialized test racks, you want temperature testing, you want wavelength measurement, et cetera, you have to provide the equipment to them. So it's -- the CapEx burden is still pretty high.
Well, Kevin, I thank you very much for hosting us today. And I thank everyone who tuned in. We appreciate your taking the time to spend with us, and we hope you'll be able to join us again 3 months from now. Have a good day.
column7:
Thank you, Tom, and good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate your taking the time to listen to our conference call today. A replay of this call should appear on our website within 8 hours. An audio replay will be available for 2 weeks by calling area code (888) 203-1112 for domestic or area code (719) 457-0820 for international, then enter the ID number 1806814.


I need to remind all of you that any forward-looking statements in today's discussions are subject to risks and uncertainties which are discussed at length in our annual and quarterly SEC filings. Actual events and results can differ materially from any forward-looking statements. In addition, the company undertakes no obligations to update any forward-looking information presented.


Unless otherwise indicated, all results discussed are on a non-GAAP basis. A complete reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP results may be found in our earnings press release and in the Investor Relations section of our website.


We have prepared some slides for today's earnings call. You can view them by connecting to the Investor Relations page of our website at finisar.com. Click on Investors, then scroll down to Webcast Archives and click, you'll see a listing for today's second quarter 2016 earnings call.


I am pleased to announce revenues for our second fiscal quarter were $321.1 million, up from $314 million in the prior quarter, a quarter-to-quarter increase of just over 2%. This increase was primarily from strong sales of 100-gigabit Ethernet transceivers, 10-gigabit tunable transceivers and wavelength selective switches. We also saw a resurgence in demand from China during the quarter.


Now I'll let Kurt review the rest of the numbers. Kurt?
Thanks, Kurt. We expect revenues for our third fiscal quarter to be in the range of $300 million to $320 million. We expect telecom revenues to grow again during the quarter, and we expect continued strong demand for 10-gigabit tunable transceivers and wavelength selective switches. We also expect demand from China to remain strong.


We are seeing continued demand for 100-gigabit Ethernet transceivers. However, we expect that growth to be more than offset by reduced revenue in 40-gigabit Ethernet transceivers. This is due to the lumpiness in demand at multiple large data centers. We also expect a decline in sales of Ethernet transceivers for wireless applications that we include in our datacom bucket. Overall, we expect datacom revenues in Q3 to decline a bit.


We expect third quarter non-GAAP gross margins to be approximately 30%, as the positive impact of favorable product mix is offset by the impact of 1 month of the annual telecom price reductions that typically take effect on January 1. Please note that our fiscal fourth quarter will include 3 months of these annual price reductions.


We expect operating expenses to be flat to down a little in Q3 in the range of $67.5 million to $68 million. Non-GAAP operating margins are expected to be approximately 7.5% to 8.5%. Non-GAAP earnings per diluted share are expected to be in the range of $0.19 to $0.25.


While we expect the remainder of fiscal 2016 to be a bit challenging, we are optimistic about fiscal 2017. We expect to benefit from the ramp of many new products and associated revenue growth, driven by both data center construction and upgrades and the increased deployment of ROADMs in 100-gig and 200-gig coherent transceivers in the telecom metro market.


We continue to believe that the long-term growth prospects of our company and the optical communications industry are positive. From our position as the industry leader, we will continue to develop the technology and the next generation of products for both the datacom and the telecom markets.


Finisar's revenue is driven primarily by growth in the global demand for bandwidth due to the increasing distribution and use of video, images and digital information. In addition, Finisar continues to benefit from the growth in cloud services, which drives network hardware upgrades of existing data centers and the build-out of new hyperscale data centers.
And now, with that, I'm going to turn it back over to Tom and open it up for questions. Tom?

Question and Answer
.....................................................................................................................................................................................................................
Well, actually the demand in China comes from a number of customers and I think a number of end applications. Wireless is pretty strong in China. I think -- we don't participate in the PONs market, but they're spending a lot of money on PONs. The long-haul upgrade program for 100-gig coherent is well underway and is moving in a very positive direction. So I don't know. Overall, demand from China is pretty good. In addition, they're building a number of big data centers over there. And so equipment suppliers that supply equipment into these data centers as well as the data centers themselves are also pretty strong in demand.
Patrick, let me go back. You asked me a question and I didn't answer, and it just struck me. And that was about, are there going to be ROADMs in China? And the answer is, yes, I think so. We're seeing a ripple of ROADM sales in China and ROADM trials, et cetera, and some installations. So will it get started in a big way? I can't predict that yet, but this is very encouraging.
Well, that one's difficult for me to predict because I do not know how well Foxconn will operate the subsidiary. I think it's a little different than other things that they do in that they have to develop new products, develop new technology, go through qualification and field trials and all the things that you do in the optics business, and I think that's a bit different than what most of the things Foxconn's done in the past. So we'll see. I mean, it's all going to play out.
Well, demand for wavelength selective switches is strong. Most of the demand, as you might imagine, is for Flexgrid optical switches. And we see it from all over the world. So I'm not going to comment specifically on any particular customer, but I just think it's fair to say that it's an exciting time for us as we have -- as we see the volumes increase and we are -- lead times going out on wavelength selective switches.
Well, 100-gig includes a number of products. And the most -- the important ones today are the CFP form factor, the CFP2 form factor and the QSFP28. We are shipping everything we can, and we're not -- and the lead times are going out. So it's a very strong market right now. And it's strong in all 3 form factors. The QSFP28 is the one that I would say, on a percentage basis, we've seen the greatest increase in revenue. And I expect that, that will be the case over the next, oh, probably 1 to 2 years. I'm sure it's going to take off because that's the big product for the hyperscale data centers.
Well, we have -- there's a number of flavors in the QSFP28 family. And our total revenues were measured in millions of dollars, but not tens of millions of dollars. But we expect it to be up at a very steep rate over the next N number of quarters.
Oh, I would hate to be so cocky as to say I think price pressure is behind us. I think we have a very competitive industry. And I suspect we're always going to find that there is some price pressure. But my hope is in the next -- this next quarter and the quarter after that at least in the datacom market prices will be more stable, and we expect that.
Well, let's back up. First of all, with respect to the telecom price negotiations, it's about the same as it has been in the last 3 years. It's always -- we've always said it's usually normally between 10% and 15%. In the last 3 years, it's been closer to 15% than it was to 10%. It's the same this year. With respect -- I don't -- with respect to Verizon, I was merely -- in the last conference call -- reciting what I had been told by one of our customers, that they expected their big revenues to come in the second half of 2016 -- of calendar 2016. I suspect that is still the case. But I do know that equipment suppliers are starting to get orders for 2016 deliveries, but I'm sure it will ramp during the year.
Yes. Right, on a sequential basis.
Correct.
That's also correct.
Well, we will have products that have non-hermetic packaging included as part of our effort to produce the lowest-cost designs that we can for the application. And I assure you, our goal is to always be cost competitive so that we can be price competitive in each of the market segments that we serve. So we will have non-hermetic components in our devices.
Oh, the first ones are probably sampling to some customers now and generally available, I'd say, in our fourth quarter or maybe the first quarter of fiscal '17.
No, I'm sure it won't. We'll take them one at a time. And I'm sure the first products are likely to be 10-gig/40-gig products.
Well, my assumption is that the Tomahawk chipset from Broadcom is going to be generally available to all the switch builders in 2016. And they will have -- I mean, there have been a number of designs that have been announced that are around that. But in terms of production, I assume, my -- our belief is that 2016 is going to see a number of product introductions and production releases. So that implies that products with 25-gigabit I/O are going to be in much demand next year.
No Fibre Channel that I know off, all Ethernet, mostly 10-gig and a little 40-gig.
Well, most of the wavelengths that are currently in telecom transport systems are still 10 gigabits. And there are a few big phone companies worldwide that are adding 100-gig coherent and doing upgrades. But I will tell you, there's an awful lot of them that are still adding 10-gigabit wavelengths to fibers. And that's where they're going. We're selling them to equipment companies.
No, it's broad.
Our view is that revenues in this area have been below our expectations for some time and we now -- they're starting to fulfill our expectations. So we think we're going to sell tunable transceivers for quite some time.
No, it's quite global. Demand is strong from European customers, American -- U.S. customers as well as Asian. And I think it's mostly an increase in demand, is what I would say. I mean, I'd like to think that we're taking share, but I'm not sure, honestly. I just know that we're selling all we can build.
CFP4 is sure much smaller than the CFP and the CFP2.
That is totally dependent upon the growth in 100-gig. And if you listened, I don't know, 6 months ago to some of these big data center builders, I would have told you that it would have fallen off very rapidly as we move into 2016, at least in that sector. But, it turns out -- I suspect things don't always turn out exactly as predicted. So my guess is that the 40-gig continues as a pretty strong product into end of 2016 for some period, as we see the increase in sales of 100-gig in the QSFP28 form factor.
Well, we sell a lot of single mode as well. But we, as a company, have historically been strongest in VCSEL-based multimode devices. So I would expect that, that's where we would continue to be the strongest.
Well, it's pretty amazing because it wasn't that long ago that we developed this concept of Flexgrid. And that we could -- instead of fixed spacing of wavelengths, we could put them in super channels, and we could put them on flexible spacing and then work on the granularity and finer and finer granularity between wavelengths. And that allowed the phone companies to be able to use their coherent transmission links as spectrally efficient as they could possibly be. And it took a while. I mean, it literally took a year or more for some of the major phone companies to open their eyes and say, that's really valuable. But I will tell you, the Flexgrid is most of what we're selling today worldwide. Makes no difference whether it's U.S., Europe or Asia.
Well, Tom, thank you very much. And we are pleased that all of you tuned in today. We hope to see you again in 3 months at our third quarter conference call. So good day to all of you.
column8:
Thank you, Sarah, and good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate your taking the time to listen to our conference call today. A replay of this call should appear on our website within 8 hours. An audio replay will be available for 2 weeks by calling area code (888) 203-1112 for domestic or area code (719) 457-0820 for international, then enter the ID number 1574347.


I need to remind all of you that any forward-looking statements in today's discussion are subject to risks and uncertainties which are discussed at length in our annual and quarterly SEC filings. Actual events and results can differ materially from any forward-looking statements. In addition, the company undertakes no obligations to update any forward-looking information presented today.


In addition, unless otherwise indicated, all results are discussed on a non-GAAP basis. A complete reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP results may be found in our earnings press release and in the Investor Relations section of our website.


We have prepared some slides for today's earnings call, and you can view them by connecting to the Investor Relations page of our website at finisar.com. Click on Investors, then scroll down to Webcast Archives and click. You'll see a listing for today's third quarter 2016 earnings call.


I am pleased to announce revenues for our third fiscal quarter were $309.2 million. This was close to the midpoint of our guidance for the quarter which was $300 million to $320 million. Due to a favorable product mix, gross margins were a bit better than expected at 30.3%. In addition, we benefited from lower-than-expected expenses to produce $0.25 in earnings per fully diluted share, which was at the upper end of our guidance.


And now with that, I'll let Kurt review the rest of the numbers. Kurt?
Thanks, Kurt. We expect revenues for our fourth fiscal quarter to be in the range of $307 million to $327 million. We expect both datacom and telecom revenues to grow relative to the third quarter. We are seeing strong growth from China due to the continued long-haul and wireless buildouts at China Telecom, China Unicom and China Mobile as well as strength in North America from the expansion of next generation metro networks.


We also expect telecom revenue growth in Q4 from Europe and the Middle East. Datacom revenue growth during the quarter is expected to be primarily due to increased sales of 100-gigabit ethernet transceivers in CFP, CFP2, CFP4 and QSFP28 form factors.


Telecom revenue growth during the quarter is expected to be primarily due to continued strong demand for wavelength selective switches and ROADM line cards. In addition, we expect growth from our 100-gig and 200-gig line-side products such as CFP2 ACO. Given the strong demand for our 100-gig client-side modules as well as our wavelength selective switches, wavelength selective switch-based line cards and our CFP2 ACO products, we are capacity constrained on all of these products and we are actively adding capacity to meet customer demand.


We expect fourth quarter non-GAAP gross margins to be approximately 30% as the positive impact of favorable product mix is offset by the impact of 3 months of the annual telecom price reductions. We expect operating expenses to be relatively flat at approximately $67.5 million.


Non-GAAP operating margins are expected to be between 8.2% and 9.2%. Non-GAAP earnings per diluted share are expected to be between $0.22 and $0.28 per share.


We continue to believe that the long-term growth prospects of our company in the optical communications industry are positive. In fiscal 2017, we expect to benefit from the increased sales of many new products, driven by both data center construction and upgrades and increased deployment of ROADMs and the 100-gig, 200-gig coherent transceivers in telecom long-haul and metro.


Finisar's revenue is primarily driven by growth in the global demand for bandwidth, from the increasing distribution and use of video, images and digital information.
