In addition, Finisar continues to benefit from the growth in cloud services, which drives networking hardware upgrades of existing data centers and the construction of new hyperscale data centers.
And now with that, I'm going to turn it back over to Sarah and open it up for questions.

Question and Answer
.....................................................................................................................................................................................................................
Well, we're shipping our QSFP28 in, I consider it to be, volumes because in previous quarters we shipped hundreds and now we're shipping thousands, so I think that's good progress. And we expect that the impact throughout this -- the rest of this calendar year is going to be, is -- well, let's see. The growth rate will be very impressive for us and probably the highest growth part of any of our product lines that we sell.
Well, our WSS business today in total is pretty close to 30% of our telecom revenues. And we expect it to grow. Demand is very strong there.
I don't -- from our standpoint, I couldn't point to a single market segment or a geography or a customer, a large customer, where I think it's had any impact all. So I'm -- obviously, when there's any change like that taking place, our hopes would be that it's beneficial to us. But I have no data to indicate that yet, so.
Well, it is a competitive business, and we have, in some segments of the business, seen competition from companies that we never had to compete with before. But that's life in the Web 2.0 space. It is: They control their environment; they control both ends of the network; they don't have to be interoperable with anybody but their own equipment; they don't have to sell these products to anybody else. You know the drill, it never gets too hot and it never gets too cold in those data centers. And it never rains in there, so they don't have to worry about Bellcore qualifications. So we haven't -- we are competing with companies that we have never competed against before in that Web 2.0 space. But overall, our business has held up really quite good in 10 gigabit. It's still -- I don't know, I would guess we -- it's still our largest product segment of them all. And we're not predicting strong growth in the future, but 10 gigabits in the enterprise is still the workhorse of data really.
It's not coming down at that same steep rate.
Yes.
First of all, we don't think the ZTE situation is going to have a meaningful impact on us. It's not a -- they have not been anywhere near our 10% customer in the past. My hope is that whatever these restrictions that finally come out from the government on shipments to ZTE, that they don't extend that to Huawei or to other companies in China. I have no reason to believe that they will but I'm -- it's -- anyway, I would hate to see that happen. Let's see. And will it benefit any of our business at Huawei? No, I doubt it. I mean maybe it benefits Huawei and if Huawei's volume is up because ZTE can't ship to some of the customers that they compete with Huawei for that might increase demand from Huawei. So I guess it's possible. It could benefit our relative volumes that we do with Huawei.
Well, one of the things that's a little hard for us to size is exactly what -- when we sell to China, we sell to OEMs, and about 20% of our revenue today goes to China. And how much of that stays in the country versus exported from China from those OEMs is -- and it varies some from each one of the OEMs to the other OEMs. I mean, some export more than others. So it's really hard to say exactly what stays in the country and what doesn't. Generally, one of the things that I think I would tell you though that's pretty exciting is that, heretofore, everything that we have shipped in wavelength selective switches to China have been exported. But now in the last quarter, we shipped wavelength selective switches to China that were actually used in end networks in China in a deployment. And so we think that as a wave of the future that is going to be very positive for that whole ROADM segment.
Well, we think our product position is great. We think we have a very competitive, high-performance wavelength selective switch. We invented this concept of flexible grid spacing of the wavelengths. And a number of the carriers, most of the major carriers in the Western world now all demand that. And we're being told that the Chinese carriers are demanding that. So that plays to our strength, and we expect that product line to be very strong for now for -- our expectations are it could be a real boom in that product line for a couple of years, maybe longer.
Well, we believe that we have a CFP2 module that will be very competitive at 100-gig but will be superior in performance to any of the offerings that we have seen in the market so far at 200-gig and 250-gig and for 16 quantum transmission. And -- so I'm -- that's -- I think will be -- obviously, we will be competitive at 100-gig but I think we're going to be tough to match at the higher data rates.
Well, first of all, Chinese New Year always has a seasonal impact because things just shut down over there for a week. But nevertheless, demand continues to be strong out of China. And the answer to the question about "How long can the demand stay strong, or even increase?" is all related to government spending, it's government stimulus, it's infrastructure spending. So our expectations, at least from what we are being told by the equipment companies anyway, is that they expect it for, I don't know, a couple of years at least. But even then, I think everybody is speculating it. All the policies of spending are determined really by the government, so [indiscernible].
We expect qualifications to be received this quarter. And we're building line cards right now for delivery.
Wow, I bet we're shipping more than 3 flavors.
We're not shipping PSM4 flavor. We're not shipping. Not yet. We're shipping LR4, we're shipping SR4 and we're shipping a few of short wavelength multiplex devices.
Yes. I think there's a few more competitors in the 100-gig cycle than there were in the 40-gig cycle.
Well, let's see. First of all, let me talk about QSFP28. It's a good product. Gross margins are above our company average. We expect it to be additive to our gross margins. And now will they be quite as high as what a 100-gig was back in the introduction of our first CFP 100-gig? Or back in the early days of 10 gig? Probably not quite. But like all new product cycles, it appears that pricing is still attractive there and it will be.
I can't predict that it would be any different, honestly. I mean, I don't -- I think we're -- actually, I think we are more competitive in the early stages of the 100-gig QSFP28 than we were in the early stages of the QSFP 40-gig. So I think that bodes well for us. But to predict market share, how it's going to shake out, I -- I don't -- I can't -- I don't have any data today that would say it would be any different.
We don't expect it to fall off a cliff, but we're not optimistic about strong growth in 40-gig any longer because of the strong -- really strong growth in 100-gig. So most of the 40-gig sales went into the Web 2.0 space and most of the 100-gig, QSFP28 anyway, is going to go into the Web 2.0 space. So I would say that they're still going to deploy 40 gig and there's still some of the Web 2.0 guys that are going to buy 40-gig for some period of time. But we just don't -- we just expected the conversion to 100-gig is going to take some of the impetus out of that and it will -- but our expectation honestly is it will decline at some rate but not off a cliff for sure.
Well, I think you hit a nail right on the head with VMI. Because the last time we had a big inventory correction was back in our Q3 of '11, our fiscal year '11. And our wavelength selective switches and our 40-gig transceivers and, all of a sudden, what had been enormous demand for a couple of years before that, all of a sudden stopped because of the inventory correction. Well, since then, most of -- I mean those products are now in vendor managed inventory hubs. So we ship to hubs, which kind of balance the inventory, we have some visibility as to what that inventory is. Now having said that, our customers do what businesses do when they're short in supply of key components. And that is they typically will double order, and they will hoard, and they will -- they try to protect their revenue stream. And I think it is a natural behavior on the part of all the equipment companies. And we try to gauge where the shipments need to be to support production as opposed to where inventory builds might be taking place. But I think it's inevitable that there would be some inventory buildup. Now with having said that, though, I still think it is, we'll see less of an impact from a correction than we have seen in the past just because of the inventory hubs that are in existence now.
I couldn't tell you for sure because they never will admit that they're double ordering. But I would suggest that to the extent that there are limited supplies in the industry, the supply chains of big equipment companies are trying to place orders any place they can. And so it's possible.
Wireless, we have not exited the business. We still sell opportunistically into the wireless business where we have capacity and where there is demand for capacity for buildouts. And that sometimes gets business at prices that we find attractive.
Right.
What's -- the other one you asked about was -- tell me again.
Web 2.0 demand has been a little slow. It's hard to say because it's never uniform across all of the Web 2.0 cloud services providers. But we have seen, in some cases, demand for 40 gig to be down a little bit in anticipation of deploying 100 gig. We also always see that forecasting in that space is always an iffy -- it's just an iffy subject because they're not very accurate. And I suspect it's because of the construction project nature of their business that construction projects have holes and they have delays and they have other things that go on. And that delays the sequence of all the materials that get delivered to a job site. So I don't -- I think the demand -- everything we know about the demand for Web 2.0, overall, it remains strong and I think for the next year, it's going to be strong. It's just quarter-to-quarter, you see variations.
CFP2 coherent is a rapidly growing market, and it's going to be huge for optics. And it's going to be huge for optics for the next several years as all the telecom companies worldwide, as they upgrade their networks they're putting in ROADM capabilities and they're putting in the 100-gig into coherent. And it's the combination of the two that makes these networks so capable. So now to talk about how any one company that's entered -- that has not yet entered the market but has announced product but they haven't built it yet is hard to predict because those products aren't yet available to customers. And aren't -- at least we're not running into them. So I'm -- I hear the announcements, I read the announcements. I anticipate that there are going to be new entrants that will have real products in the market. I suspect when we go to OFC this year, we're going to see some first off samples that will be demonstrated there by one or more companies. But I'm not going to predict yet that we're -- we won't be very competitive with those. And our solution is an internal laser and an internal modulator.
We'll have our first revenues this quarter off of the pilot line. We'll have -- and as we -- over the next few quarters after that, we will start moving -- we'll be moving that product into one of our Asian plants for volume ramp.
Great. Thank you, Sarah. And thanks to everyone who tuned in today. We appreciate your taking the time to spend with us. And we hope you'll be able to join us again in 3 months. Everybody, have a good day or a good evening. Thanks.
column9:
Thank you, Rachel, and good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate your taking the time to listen to our conference call. A replay of this call should appear on our website within 8 hours. An audio replay will be available for 2 weeks by calling area code (888) 203-1112 for domestic or area code (719) 457-0820 for international, then enter the ID number 9069246.


I need to remind all of you that any forward-looking statements in today's discussion are subject to risks and uncertainties, which are discussed at length in our annual and quarterly SEC filings. Actual events and results can differ materially from any forward-looking statements. In addition, the company undertakes no obligations to update any forward-looking information presented.


Unless otherwise indicated, all results discussed are on a non-GAAP basis. A complete reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP results may be found in our earnings press release and in the Investor Relations section of our website.


We have prepared some slides for today's conference. You can view them by connecting to the Investor Relations page of our website at finisar.com. Click on Investors, then scroll down to Webcast Archives and click. You'll see a listing for today's fourth quarter 2016 earnings call.


I am pleased to announce that revenues for our fourth fiscal quarter were $318.8 million, an increase of $9.6 million or 3.1% over the third quarter. This growth was primarily from increased demand for 40 gigabit per second and 100 gigabit per second datacom transceivers. Gross margin was 30.6%. Combined with lower expenses, this resulted in non-GAAP earnings per fully diluted share of $0.29, which was $0.01 above the upper end of our guidance range.


And now I'll let Kurt review the rest of the numbers. Kurt?
Thanks, Kurt. For our first fiscal quarter of FY '17, we expect revenues to be in the range of $323 million to $343 million. We expect both datacom and telecom revenues to be greater than the fourth quarter. We continue to see strong demand from China due to the long-haul and wireless build-outs at all the major carriers. North America demand remains strong due to the expansion of next-generation metro networks. Europe and Middle East demand is also strong.


We expect datacom revenue growth during the first quarter will be primarily from increased sales of 100 gigabit Ethernet transceivers. Telecom revenue growth in the first quarter is expected to be primarily from continued strong demand for our wavelength selective switches, 10 gigabit tunable transceivers and our ROADM line cards. In addition, revenues for 100 gigabit and 200 gigabit line-side products, such as CFP2 ACO, are expected to increase. We are experiencing such strong demand for our broad range of our product lines that we have many capacity constraints. We are actively adding capacity to try to meet our customers' demands.


We expect non-GAAP gross margin for the first quarter of FY '17 to be approximately 31%. We expect operating expenses to increase to approximately $68.5 million, mostly due to higher legal expenses from a patent trial where we are the plaintiff. We also expect an increase in payroll taxes from the annual vesting of employee RSU grants, which occurs every June. In addition, sales and marketing expenses are expected to be higher due to the expected growth in revenue.


Non-GAAP operating margins are expected to be between 9.9% and 10.9%, and non-GAAP earnings per diluted share are expected to be in the range of $0.27 to $0.33 per share.


Overall demand is strong from a broad range of customers, and we expect demand to remain strong for quite some time. We continue to believe in the long-term growth prospects of our company in the optical communications industry, and we think they're positive. In our fiscal 2017, we expect to benefit from the ramp of many new products. Revenue growth will be driven by both data center construction and upgrades as well as increased deployment of ROADMs and 100-gigabit and 200-gigabit coherent transceivers in telecom networks.


Finisar's revenue is driven primarily by growth in the global demand for bandwidth due to the increasing distribution and use of video, images and digital information. In addition, we continue to benefit from the growth in cloud services, which drives network hardware upgrades of existing data centers and the construction of new hyperscale data centers.
And now with that, I'm going to turn it back over to Rachel and open it up for questions. Rachel?

Question and Answer
.....................................................................................................................................................................................................................
Let's see. Verizon, we don't -- we're not qualifying directly with Verizon. We qualify with equipment companies who supply to Verizon. And qualification is in progress. A lot of tests have been run. A lot of success has been achieved. But there's a lot of details that relate to firmware or software, all kinds of things. And it's like we expect full qualification at any time, and it could happen in weeks or it could be longer. But we expect it's making good progress, and we expect it to be completed shortly. ROADM capacity is -- for us, it's the wavelength selective switch capacity. It's a reasonably complicated subject in that we do most of the work in China in our Wuxi factory. So we have to add equipment and people and training there, and it takes a fair amount of training for this. And we also end up -- we do some of the work on many of the wavelength selective switch products back in our Sydney, Australia facility. So anyway, we -- it's a little more complicated subject than just saying, "Oh, we didn't get all the equipment in and running because you not only have to have the equipment. You got to have operators hired, and you got to have operators trained." And so somewhere between all of that, we didn't quite get the capacity up in the line that we thought we were, but we feel free -- we feel sure we're going to have it online this next quarter, and we're predicting that our revenues for wavelength selective switches will be up nicely.
Well, we don't have any market share with Verizon. So our market share can only go up.
I don't really have a breakout, I can say, between single-mode intra-data center and single mode that goes inter-data center. The 40G decline is one of those things where we've expected the decline in 40G revenues prior to this time but are surprised of its strength. But that -- maybe that's not surprising since there have been a lot of switches deployed with 40 gigabit sockets in them for, what, the last 2, 3 years. And some of those sockets aren't built yet. And so there is still an ongoing market of -- as you expand capacity in existing 40G data centers, filling those sockets with 40G transceivers. So I'm not the guy that's going to -- because I predicted that it would have declined already but -- so I was wrong, and I'm not going to predict again when it's going to decline.
About 20%.
I don't know that I'm ready to predict magnitude. I will tell you that we shipped about 100 units last quarter. Some of those actually ended up in end-customer installations. So they're actually in the field, but they were part of systems that our customers, the equipment companies, wanted to ship with some urgency because we have not completed our full qualification -- all the qualification tests that go into the CFP2 ACO. So we're close but we've got a few things that are still in the oven, as they say and -- but all that stuff, I expect to be cleared up soon, and we expect that we're going to ship several times in the first quarter what we shipped in the first quarter -- in the fourth quarter.
That's correct. Our ultimate production of this product is going to be in Wuxi, China.
In general or for this product?
I think so. You're talking of expectation?
In prior quarter, we had 2.
We have no information about that. So I only know what I read on the web because I don't read much. It's not covered in the local papers.
Well, Huawei is a big customer for this entire industry. And if they got into hot water with the U.S. government and the same problem that happened with ZTE happened with Huawei, I mean it would be a problem for a lot of companies in the optics industry. I have no reason to expect that that's the case. I only know the rumors that you've heard. Our view of demand from China both for domestic use and for their export of systems is that demand remains strong. So...
I think it's too early to tell what my -- what our hopes are that with the shortages in the industry, supply will be more of an issue than price. Now we'll wait and see how that shakes out. With respect to the CapEx and capacity, I'll let Kurt address that one.
Let's see. It's got to be a good year for our fiscal '17 and for calendar year '17. For the rest of '16 and '17, I think it would be a very good year in data centers. As you pointed out, it's now the roll-out of 25-gigabit lanes and then, end times, 25 gigabit in transceivers. So I can tell you we're sold out on all those versions of 25-gigabit lane products, and the orders keep coming. So it's going to be a good year. Cavium and QLogic, I don't know how to read that one. Cavium is an IC company. They make switch chips. I don't know what else is in their product line because I'm not that familiar with the company. QLogic is, obviously, the -- one of the HBA players in the fiber channel industry, and they're good at it. So I don't expect there to be much change in the -- at least in the fiber channel side of QLogic's business. I mean, there may be some. One of the things that QLogic has been investing in for some time has been Ethernet NIC cards. And so maybe the Cavium -- being part of Cavium would benefit their Ethernet NIC card business.
None yet, and I don't -- right now, the biggest concerns we have is all about capacity. It's about we've got more orders than we can ship. So...
Well, the baseline is right. And exactly where we're going to end up the calendar year is not clear, but it will be higher than the baseline. So we're -- I mean, we are expecting growth in that business. We have very strong demand in the wavelength selective switch product lines, and we're adding capacity.
Let's see. Getting back to the high end of our range is a long-term goal, but I don't -- it's unlikely that we're going to get back to 35% in the -- anywhere in the near future. I guess that could change, but that's not what I expect right now. But it's nice that our gross margins were better this quarter. It's nice that they're going to be even better next quarter. I think that's a very positive trend. The whole thing about -- there are -- there is increased competition particularly in the Web 2.0 space, but the demand is so strong that there isn't enough productive capacity. A lot of the demand, a lot -- excuse me, a lot of the competition comes from smaller companies who don't have a lot of production capacity, who are forward pricing in order to gain market share. And then they got the challenge of, can they deliver? So how does -- how the equilibrium is going to be reached probably isn't clear yet. I just know that we run the biggest factories in the optics in the world. We have -- we are a dependable supplier, and all of these equipment companies and all of these Web 2.0 companies know they can count on us that we can produce the parts. So -- and the orders keep flowing. So...
We don't give any guidance beyond our next quarter. And is that -- I mean, is it possible? Sure, it's possible, but we're not necessarily predicting today.
And your question...
Excuse me, WSS?
Okay. Our WSS sales or worldwide -- and it is true that demand from China has been strong, but it's also true that demand from North America and even Europe is a bit strong. So I am -- we expect that there will be a -- our business is strong. And remember, we're not qualified in the line cards. We're trying to get qualified in for Verizon yet. So if -- when that happens, that's going to be an extra spurt in this WSS business. So I think -- I'm very optimistic about our wavelength selective switch business and the outlook there for quite some time.
Not clear. Whether we have capacity available or incremental business depends on how the rest of the world demand for wavelength selective switches goes. And the world's demand for ROADMs right now is pretty strong. I mean, in any developed country of the world, whether -- whatever continent they're on, if they're building a new telephone network or adding to an existing one, it includes ROADMs and it typically includes 100G coherent transmission. So I'm -- I guess, maybe my answer is, I sure hope we have the capacity but I'm -- to serve all of our customers, but I'm not certain. It depends on the growth and demand.
I'm not aware of any constraints there for us. We're quite vertically integrated on our QSFP28 product.
It's hard to tell in the short run what our share is and how it's shifting. I mean, we sort of see the data from the analysts like LightCounting that comes out sort of 6 months, Light -- that says, "Here's how it was the last half of last year." So I'm not sure whether we're really gaining share or not. But I will tell you that the 100G deployment in the world is strong, 100G coherent business in the world is strong, and the 100G CFP usually goes on the client side of those routers that have 100G output. So there's a lot of 100G everywhere. So it's -- and did we gain share on a worldwide basis during that period? Honestly, I would be speculating. And I can -- for sure, I can point to a couple of customers where I think we gain share but...
For the growth here, it would more than double.
We have some pretty big orders that we're trying to fill, but we have very big forecast from lots of customers about what their needs are going to be. And we have a lot of incoming phone calls about people concerned about their deliveries. So they're anxious. So we're building capacity. We're building more parts. And our expectations for growth in the QSFP28 product line is we're very optimistic there.
I don't know. I think there's a lot of -- there's been a lot of speculation and a lot of talk that was either overly ambitious by somebody. But generally, I think as I mentioned earlier, the advantage that we have is big capacity and the ability to supply and the ability to increase our capacity to ramp production. And I -- and it's not -- we don't generally have the lowest prices in the industry, and I doubt that we ever will have. We like to think that we make the best products in the industry, and we're the most reliable supplier. So I think for a long time, the demand is going to be stronger than the world's capacity for these products, and some of the components that go in these products are going to be in short supply as well. So we feel like we're in pretty good shape since we make all the lasers that go in our QSFP28s with the integrated circuits, and they're of our design and from our foundry runs. So we're -- I think we're in good shape.
Thank you, Rachel, and thank you, everyone, for tuning in to our fourth quarter conference call today. We hope you'll be able to join us again in 3 months. Have a good day.
column10:
Thank you, Tom, and good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate your taking the time to listen to our conference call today. A replay of this call should appear on our website within 8 hours. An audio replay will be available for 2 weeks by calling area code (888) 203-1112 for domestic or area code (719) 457-0820 for international, then enter the ID number 1833924.


I need to remind all of you that any forward-looking statements in today's discussion are subject to risks and uncertainties, which are discussed at length in our annual and quarterly SEC filings. Actual events and results can differ materially from any forward-looking statements. In addition, the company undertakes no obligations to update any forward-looking information that is presented.


Unless otherwise indicated, all results discussed are on a non-GAAP basis. A complete reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP results may be found in our earnings press release and in the Investor Relations section of our website.


We have prepared some slides for today's earnings call. You can view them by connecting to the Investor Relations page on our website at finisar.com, click on Investors then scroll down to Webcast Archives and click. You'll see a listing for today's first quarter 2017 earnings call.


I am pleased to announce that Finisar achieved a new company record for revenues on our first quarter. Our sales were $341.3 million, an increase of $22.5 million or 7.1% over the prior quarter. This growth was primarily driven by strong demand for 100-gigabit per second transceivers in the CFP, CFP2, CFP4 and QSFP28 form factors. In addition, demand for wavelength selective switches remains strong.


Our non-GAAP gross margins improved significantly to 33.1%. This increase was primarily due to a favorable product mix and the  leverage we achieved with larger volumes in our vertically-integrated manufacturing infrastructure. The combination of higher revenues and better-than-expected gross margins resulted in non-GAAP earnings per fully diluted share of $0.38, up 31% over our fourth quarter EPS and up 65% over our first quarter a year ago.


Now I'll let Kurt review the rest of the numbers.
Thanks, Kurt.


We expect revenues for our second fiscal quarter of 2017 to be in the range of $355 million to $375 million. We expect both datacom and telecom revenues to grow quarter-to-quarter.


We continue to see strong worldwide demand for telecom optical components due to the new long-haul metro and wireless deployments by many major carriers. Demand from North America and China remain particularly strong from the metro build-outs in North America and both long haul and metro deployments in China.


In the second quarter, we expect revenue growth for our datacom products, primarily from increased sales of 100-gigabit Ethernet transceivers. Strong demand for wavelength selective switches and the ROADM line cards will contribute to our Q2 telecom revenue growth. In addition, we expect increased line-side revenues for 100-gigabit per second and 200-gigabit per second coherent CFP2 ACO transceivers.


We are still sold out for a number of products and continue to add capacity to meet the strong demand. Some of our capacity expansion investments include 100-gig client-side transceivers, QSFP28, wavelength selective switches, line cards, 25-gigabit lasers and our 100-gigabit and 200-gigabit coherent CFP2 ACO transceivers.


We expect second quarter non-GAAP gross margins to improve again to approximately 34%. We expect operating expenses to increase to approximately $71 million in the second quarter. This increase is primarily from our annual salary merit increases that occurred on August 1, plus higher sales in marketing expenses related to increased revenue, but partially offset by lower legal expenses. Non-GAAP operating margins are expected to improve again to between 14.3% and 15.3%. Non-GAAP earnings per diluted share are expected to be up again to between $0.44 a share and $0.50 a share.


We continue to believe that the long-term growth prospects for our company in the optical communications industry are positive. In fiscal 2017, we expect the benefit from the ramp of many new products. Revenue growth will be driven by both data center construction, 100-gigabit upgrades and the increased deployment of ROADMs and 100-gigabit per second, 200-gigabit per second coherent transceivers in telecom, long haul and metro markets. It truly is a great time to be in the optical communication business.


Finisar's revenue was primarily driven by growth in the global demand for bandwidth due to the increasing distribution and use of video, images and digital information. In addition, Finisar benefits from the growth in cloud services, which drives network and hardware upgrades of existing data centers and the construction of new hyperscale data centers.


And with that, I'm going to turn it back over to Tom and open it up for questions.
Tom?

Question and Answer
.....................................................................................................................................................................................................................
It's a strong area. You asked about competition. There are a number of people that make products in that area, but we have a great product. I mean, it works well. We can build a lot of them. We sold most of them, I would guess. And that's not even fair. I was going to say we sold most of them in Web 2.0. I guess majority went to the Web 2.0 segment, but there was a lot of them that went to the Enterprise segment as well. So it's a great product, and there's more demand right now than we can supply, and I'm sure the whole industry can supply.
We are currently qualified with 2 OEMs who are shipping our product to their customers, and they use 2 different DSPs. We are in qualification with, I think, every other DSP that exist at some OEM. So we're making progress against that arsenal of DSPs that we have to inter-operate with. And we're making progress with the OEMs, but it's obviously slower than we had hoped.
Both. Actually that's not true. The places we're qualified right now, they are COTS DSP. We're in qualification with in-house DSPs, but I don't think we're fully qualified at any place that has an in-house DSP.
I think you're right. I mean, that's the way we view it, is that 100-gig rollout, the 25-gig lens and the Web 2.0 space has been -- the demand was really strong. Don't get me wrong. And -- but on the other hand, the difficulties they're having with a number of components, maybe that contributes to the reason that our 40-gig business remains as strong as it is. 10 gigabit is still strong mostly in Enterprise data centers.
I think it's interesting. I think if they accomplish what they were targeting, I mean, somebody deserves a Nobel Prize. It's difficult. Smart people have been working on this for 20 or 25 years. And if they can make a breakthrough, it's huge.
Well, I think it'll impact the industry. I mean in theory, it will impact -- it will have an effect on their economics of building things if they can build everything plainer. I think that's really positive, but I don't -- it's not positive for us. It's really positive for them. I think it'd be a great technology to have if you can do it, but I'll just assure you that there is a lot of skepticism in the industry right now about whether it really can be done.
Most of what we're selling today, probably the biggest volume is LR4 followed by CWDM followed by SR4.
Well, I'm sure you can predict our expectations in an industry where there are shortages everywhere. I would sure hope that our competitors aren't going to think that they have to buy market share by lowering their prices when they can't deliver the products that are on order today. So I hope that, that means that we have some price -- more price stability in the industry.
One thing I would interject with Web 2.0 is that is -- my view is it will end up 15% to 20% of our total revenue. I mean that's where we were -- and that's where we've been. But I do -- one of the things that I think you have to keep in mind, or I would remind you, is that we have -- we are the #1 company in the Web 2.0 space. You can name every one of these big cloud service providers and all the optics demand they have, we supply way more than anybody else in the industry.
Well, operator -- the service providers in China are, today, benefiting from infrastructure spending by the government, and they are upgrading their networks to 100 gigabits. We're not deploying ROADMs yet. The automation of optical networks using ROADMs has just not arrived in China. But they have run field trials, and they are running field trials in the second half of this year. And deployments are, I was going to use the word promised, but deployments are predicted in a big way in calendar year '17. So that is the new day for us, is the day that ROADMs start getting used in the bone systems or phone networks in China. Now we benefit a lot from 100-gigabit deployment in China. A lot of our competitors benefit from all the components that they supply: the lasers, the receivers, modulators, all the components that get slaughtered on the -- onto line cards by the big OEMs over there. It's a big market today, and it's big because of Chinese upgrades. But it's also big because the world's telephone networks are all -- when they do upgrades, anywhere in the world, they upgrade to 100 gigabit. I mean, that's just sort of a standard of today's upgrade. And so a lot of what the Chinese OEMs sell is for export to a lot of Third World countries in particular as well as some of the European countries.
Let's see. First of all, you're incorrect. We sell a lot of dual rate CFPs, CFP2s. We sell a lot more than 10 gigabits in China, but I think the biggest opportunity in China in the future is the deployment of ROADMs.
Well, I think it's going to stick around. A lot of 10 gig is going to be used in wireless, in the wireless fronthaul and wireless backhaul as well. So there's -- I don't know. I don't anticipate the 10-gig demand is going to drop off substantially in China.
I think the latter is what you -- is our strategy. What we're -- we're investing in products that we think we know have better-than-average gross margins for us and where the demand is strong, and we're here selectively not investing in some other segments which have -- which are less profitable. So I think that any businessman would make the same decision.
I don't know I could say we're making a bigger investment in the competition. I mean, 100-gigabit everything is pot, and so we're all expanding capacity in any 100-gigabit flavor that we sell. We're not investing as much in 10 gigabits, but I won't tell you that there are no specific segments of 10 gigabit we're investing in. Wavelength selective switches, we're investing a lot there. But I don't know that, that's -- that we're investing more than our competitors. Our competitors have stepped up their capital spending a fair amount over the last few quarters, and so I don't know how we are currently differentiating about where we're investing relative to everyone else because I don't know exactly where everyone else is investing. I just know they're spending more money.
We have increases in particularly in China and in North America. And we have some telecom OEMs that are in Europe, not many but a few. And the rest of the world has got -- it's pretty sparse.
Well, it vary. We have a big project where we're trying to qualify line card that'll end up in Verizon Metro system, and we are not yet qualified. We're in what is known as system verification tests, and we're not -- we haven't squeezed through that hole in the wall yet. We're making progress. But every time you run into a bit error from some rare condition, I mean, believe me, the systems guys drag up some rare conditions under which your device has to operate or turn the power off and on a thousand times in a second. And you can't take any bit errors really -- drop it on the floor and can't take any bit errors or whatever the torture that they want to apply to it. But we're working our way through it. We're making progress. The changes have not been hard where they have been, just changing software and firmware and tuning. So I believe we're closing in, but we're clearly late. Our expectations were that we were going to be fully qualified some number of quarters ago, and we're not yet. But I'm still optimistic, and it's coming. In calendar year '17, we're going to have substantial revenue coming.
Right.
Wuxi has been a wonderful story for us. We have about 5,000 people there. We -- if you recall, we now have the 600,000 square-foot manufacturing building, actually 2 300,000 square-foot buildings side by side. But we make telecom products. We make datacom products. We make a lot of 100-gig products. We typically make more difficult products, a lot of telecom is get -- does get made there because we have really good engineering support. And a lot of these complicated wavelength division, multiplexed TOSs, tunable TOSs, all these assemblies are really quite difficult and really quite complex. And so the assembly of those things and the tuning of all that is one of the specialties that Wuxi has. In addition, they build all the optical assemblies for our wavelength selective switches. So anyway, we're really proud of Wuxi and what they've accomplished. And they are -- any time we move a product to Wuxi from some remote location where we're doing some work, they make a heck of an impact in terms of the cost reduction on those items.
100 gig is clearly a competitive marketplace, and competitive -- there are competitive products in virtually everything that we make. But we make really good products, and they perform at a very high level. And we run the biggest optical factories in the world, and so we have economics of scale. And as Kurt pointed out earlier, as our volumes increase, we have leverage. And so we're in a great position with respect to costs of 100-gig products. And when there's a shortage in the world, our prices don't decline -- normally don't decline as fast as the customers would like them to. I mean, every customer wants prices to go down really, really fast. But I will tell you that in order to assure their revenue streams, in many cases, they just have to have a steady supply from guys like us. And so supply becomes more important than price in many cases.
Well, it depends on what meaningful revenue is. I mean, $1 million or $2 million a quarter, not so meaningful to us. But our expectations, all these qualifications that we're in will all yield a revenue stream that's going to be quite a few millions of dollars per quarter. So I'm -- I will not predict again which quarter we're going to get qualified at some of these major OEMs, but I will -- but I'm certain it's coming. And I think calendar year '17, we're going to see meaningful revenue, I mean, tens of millions of dollars from our CFP2 ACO.
Well, we make line cards today in Wuxi, China. We have major OEMs who buy line cards from us that are -- that include wavelength selective switches and erbium-doped fiber amplifiers and channel monitors and software and all that stuff. I mean, they're big, complicated line cards, and they're expensive. So we make them. We make them every quarter. That business is actually doing quite well right now with other customers. But these are systems around -- they go into systems around the world. But to my knowledge, none of them are going in the Verizon systems right now. So the one we're all focused on is trying to qualify a line card that will go into a ROADM rack with Verizon and be -- so that we can participate in their 100-gig Metro upgrade. But for us, it will be built in Wuxi. We have a whole infrastructure up there that can build these. We have actually built dozens of these Verizon line cards already. So we've got processes, we've got people, jigs, fixtures. We know how to do it. It's not capital-intensive in that the capital goes into building the Wavelength Selective Switch. That's where -- that's the most capital-intensive part of it. But the line card itself is -- it's sheet metal, it's a circuit board and a channel monitor and a Wavelength Selective Switch. You put them all together and button it up and you got -- and then you have to terminate a lot of fibers. There's a fair amount of labor that goes into building line cards because of the fiber routing and the fiber termination. But we're in pretty good shape where it comes to line cards.
Well, it's clearly different than what we had thought. It's slower than we have expected because we haven't qualified in most of the OEMs where we're in our qualification testing right now. We shipped about 100 units in the quarter. And I -- the real issue is you got to get through all these qualifications, and you got to get on the ADL. And we're -- I think we're within shouting distance of completing a number of them. We've completed 2, so far. But I'm not -- it's just taking longer than anybody predicted. It's just -- we're going to get there. We've got to -- we get some customers who come back and pat us on the back and tell us how great our product is and blah, blah, blah. But that's great. But we need to be on an ADL, and we need purchased orders. So I do expect that after -- by the end of our fiscal year, I think we're going to be shipping meaningful quantities. I do believe we will be qualified at some of the bigger OEMs, and so we're still diligently working on these knits and gnats of this qualification program.
Well, Tom, thank you very much. And everybody, we appreciate you tuning in to our second quarter conference call -- I mean, excuse me, our first quarter conference call today. We hope you'll be able to join us again 3 months from now, and I hope you have a good day. Thanks.
column11:
Thank you, Angela, and good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate your taking the time to listen to our conference call today. A replay of this call should appear on our website within 8 hours. An audio replay will be available for 2 weeks by calling area code (888) 203-1112 for domestic or area code (719) 457-0820 for international, then enter the ID number 7509499.


I need to remind all of you that any forward-looking statements in today's discussion are subject to risks and uncertainties, which are discussed at length in our annual and quarterly SEC filings. Actual events and results can differ materially from any forward-looking statements. In addition, the company undertakes no obligations to update any forward-looking information presented. Unless otherwise indicated, all results discussed are on a non-GAAP basis. A complete reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP results may be found in our earnings press release and in the Investor Relations section of our website.


We have prepared some slides for today's earnings call. You can view them by connecting to the Investor Relations page of our website at finisar.com, click on Investors, then scroll down to Webcast Archives and click on it. You'll see a listing for today's second quarter 2017 earnings call.


I am pleased to announce that Finisar achieved all-time quarterly record for revenues and profits in our second quarter. We had a very good quarter. Revenues were $369.9 million, an increase of $28.5 million or 8.4% over the first quarter. This growth was primarily driven by strong demand for 100-gigabit per second transceivers. In addition, customer demand was also strong for wavelength selective switches and ROADM line cards.


Our gross margins improved significantly to 37.2% due to a favorable product mix and the leverage we achieved from our vertical integration with larger production volumes. The combination of revenues being at the higher end of our guidance range, plus higher gross margins, resulted in earnings per fully diluted share of $0.58, which is well above our Q2 guidance range.


And now with that, I'll let Kurt review the rest of the numbers. Kurt?
Thanks, Kurt. We continue to believe that the long-term growth prospects of our company and the optical communications industry are positive. Current worldwide demand for optical products is strong and we expected to remain strong for a long time.


Our upcoming third quarter should be another record quarter for Finisar. We anticipate that revenues will be in the range of $378 million to $398 million, primarily from increased sales of 100-gigabit per second transceivers. We expect third quarter non-GAAP gross margins to improve again to approximately 37% to 38%. This increase will primarily come from a favorable product mix, plus the operating leverage from our vertical integration. One partial offset will be the impact of 1 month of the annual telecom price reductions that are typically effective January 1.


We expect operating expenses will be at approximately $72 million in Q3 or about 18.6% of revenue. Non-GAAP operating margin should continue to improve to approximately 18.5% to 19.5%. Non-GAAP earnings per diluted share are expected to be in the range of $0.58 to $0.64 per share. This would be another new quarterly record for Finisar, driven by our growing revenue and improving margins.


We continue to add capacity for a number of products. For QSFP28, in particular, we plan to increase capacity significantly in the third quarter and have plans to continue to increase capacity in the subsequent quarters. We are also adding capacity for the 100-gig and 200-gig coherent CFP2 ACO transceivers and the ROADM line cards for telecom and long haul and metro. We expect the qualification of these products by key customers in the next few months. In addition, we are also adding capacity for our wavelength selective switches. We believe that China will begin significant domestic deployments of ROADMs in calendar 2017.


Finally, we are adding capacity over the next couple of quarters in our VCSEL laser fab in Allen, Texas. This will enable us to produce -- pursue several new consumer applications for 3D sensing. Overall, we had an excellent second quarter and are expecting another one in Q3. I would like to thank all our loyal customers for their continued support, and I would like to thank all of our 14,000 employees for their hard work, creativity and attention to detail. I hope all of you listening to this call understands that our success is not a short-term effort. It comes from years of investment in R&D, people and facilities. But for all of us, it's a great time to be in optics.
And with that, I'm going to turn it back over to Angela and open it up for questions.

Question and Answer
.....................................................................................................................................................................................................................
We have orders in hand as well.
We will ship wavelength selective switches into China in the next quarter. We also did last quarter.
Well, the project could be huge, there's a lot of debate about when exactly it's going to kick off with big orders and deployment is really going to begin in earnest. But the consensus from everybody is that it will be in calendar 2017. So does that mean -- my guess is it's not going to be big deployments in the first quarter. But any time after that, I would not be expecting -- I would not be surprised.
Generally, the price negotiations this year were more favorable for us than they have been in the last several years. So while we have always said that price declines that we see at January 1 every year usually range in the 10% to 15% range. This year, they're around 10%.
We believe we are. There's always some uncertainty about where all the products are going to end up. We know some of them have ended up in China. And we think some of the once that we're shipping today are going into the early deployment or trials as we refer to them.
Well, we don't talk about specific customers or specific products or situations with particular products. All I can tell you is that we believe that we will achieve qualifications at the key industry OEMs very shortly. Now is shortly weeks or is that months? I can't tell you because there's a lot of stuff that goes into having your qual and your listing on the ABL bottomed up, but I think we're very close.
Well, it's possible that some of these projects could turn into revenue in 2017 and particularly in the second half of 2017. But I think there's a lot of uncertainty that goes within any of them in terms of consumer products and which ones they'll introduce and what features and whatnot. Anyway, I think the numbers are incredibly exciting. But I think it's -- and we think it's a good enough bet that we're spending a lot of money on facility expansion, we're spending money to hire people, we're ramping production -- or production capability. And we think that there are a number of places where this 3D sensing is going to be an exciting consumer application.
No.
Well, we've achieved a number of customer qualifications. And we're still working on a few more. So we think we are very close to achieving all of the customer qualifications where we're currently engaged.
That's a tough one. It depends on the application. I think there are likely to be some that are going to be above the company average. I think it's possible. There may be some that are slightly below. I don't know what the average margin for that product line is going to be. I'll just tell you that we think it's going to be accretive, very nicely profitable and potentially there's a lot of leverage because it comes from a fixed cost facility, a big fab.
We're hundreds of units, not thousand.
Let's see. The answer to the first question is, I'm hard-pressed to think of a product line where we're not sold out. We're still adding, obviously, a lot of equipment and people in that Wuxi facility. And yes, we are probably going to add -- not probably, we're going to add a third building, which will increase capacity there by 50%.
Well, the LR4 is still our largest product line in that in the QSFP28. The CWDM4 is next. They're both growing very fast. And I don't know, they're competitive products, there's other people that can make them. But we think we have very good products, and we think our cost structure of making them is extremely competitive in this industry.
3D sensing is something that we've been working on for years, and we've had a number of smaller customers and it really hasn't moved the needle much in terms of revenue. But over the last, I don't know year, maybe 18 months, discussions in a number of consumer-based industries have really heated up. And as a result, we think that there's likely to be significant revenue and upside for us next calendar year for sure. Now -- and the reason we talked about it in this conference call is because all of a sudden, we're spending a lot of money on it. And so Kurt thought we ought to -- we're going to spend a lot of CapEx, we probably ought to tell people why we're spending a lot of CapEx.
Well, I don't view it as positive for us. Long term, Broadcom has said that they're going to be a component supplier and arms dealers for the optics industry. Maybe that's no real long-term impact. But I think short term, as long as they are the sales arm for Foxconn, I think it's likely they have some negative impact on us. But I will tell you that any big equipment company wants 2 sources for everything. And historically, in the SAN industry, Finisar has been the largest supplier in the industry, but Avago was right behind us. So I don't -- I'd still think we're going to have substantial sales, and I think really, really good relationships with not only Brocade, but Emulex as well.
Yes, we're positioned very well because we have with -- we're the biggest supplier in the datacom industry. Most of the server connections, server to server are copper. Some of the server to top-of-rack switch are optics, but most are still copper. And this is the 25, a 10-gig links and a 25-gig links. The switches from the top-of-racks switch to the aggregation switches are virtually -- or I won't say all, I could be wrong somewhere, but they are predominantly optical. And the rest of the connection in the data center are optical. As we -- the question is going to be, as Tomahawk goes to third-generation Tomahawk and the links become 50-gig PAM4, not 25-gig, the question is are -- will the connections within the server still -- can they still be a copper at those speeds? And the answer is, I don't know. The distances get shorter and shorter. And I think optics, the optics share of that business for sure will grow, but I -- it's hard for me to predict the complete demise of copper in some connections. In some cases, they're only a foot or two long.
Well, I don't think it's clear exactly what we'll be dominant for Chinese domestic deployment. I think that there will be applications that we broadcast in select and there will others that will be route and select. And I don't -- can't tell you exactly which of the carriers might select which one or if there will be a unified approach dictated by the government. There's always a bit of uncertainty that goes with sort of a mysterious operations of the Chinese government and the big Chinese national corporations. So I don't know, I think you might end up with some of both. And I think that for us, well, we make a lot of 1x9s and we make 1x9s' Flexgrid on the finest grid spacing that money can buy. And we make 2x1x20s for the route-and-select architectures. And they are, again, flexible-grid spacing, and I think we'll have a substantial business either way and in both cases.
Well, the only seasonality that I predict in China is Chinese New Year. And everything sort of slows down and stops before Chinese New Year, and it always seems like it takes a while for things to crank back up after Chinese New Year. So other than that, I don't have -- there's no seasonal pattern that I would predict. It all has to do with when the RFIs and RFQs come out and when do the deployments get started. But it will be after Chinese New Year, I'm pretty certain.
Both.
Broad based. There's not enough capacity in the industry to supply QSFP28s. There's not enough lasers available, there's just not enough capacity. So because we have big factories, we make our own lasers. We're in really good position in that market.
Well, I have heard people predict that it could be as long as 2 years, I don't know. I can't tell you, it depends. But they have predictions on demand and they have predictions on capacity and balancing the 2 of these guys said that they thought it might be as long as 2 years before the capacity equaled demand. I'm very optimistic that it's going to be a good market for a while.
Well, eventually, we think CWDM4 will be a larger market by volume. LR4 is a little more difficult product to make. But the 10-kilometer performance is something that a lot of -- awful lot of customers will demand in some part of their networks. I think they're both going to be very strong products over time. But the industry analysts that look at this industry predict that CWDM4 will be the largest in volume, but that there won't be much difference, I don't think, in the TAM.
Let's see. In reverse order, yes, we sell a 250-gig product today. And in terms of market share, it's hard to say. I hope it's big. There aren't many players, there aren't many guys in this industry that currently make this product. And right now, there's not -- but one that makes it in any volume to speak off. So I think that and given that virtually all the equipment companies who buy these things are going to -- will want to have 2 sources, I think we'll end up with meaningful share. And define meaningful is being 30% of the industry or 50% of the industry, I am not going to hazard a guess. It depends a lot on performance, it depends on shortages, it depends on quality and price and lots of other things that are yet to come.
I think there are some applications that are like that. But the consumer industry is such that volumes are high, the negotiations are tough. And my expectations that are -- and many of it in these cases, the OEMs are trying to make sure that they have specifications that are interchangeable between suppliers. That is that in many cases, the packages are the same, the outputs are the same, the configurations are the same. So you can have multiple sources for a drop-in product and that's a little different than a lot of the IC industry, where you go and try to spec in your chip into a slot in a design, but once you won that design win, then it's very difficult to get you out and almost nobody else in the industry has exactly the same pan out that you do. So it requires a design change to replace you or even to bring in a second source, you have to have a second board design. Anyway, I think that most of these consumer companies are trying to make sure that they have designed from the beginning so that they have multiple suppliers and interchangeable suppliers. So I think there's reason to believe that the sky high margins of the IC industry might not be possible in this consumer on applications. But I do think the margins will be quite good, and I think the business will be quite profitable.
The sales in China are going to be WSSs.
That's what I'm saying, too. Sales in China for Chinese networks or for export makes no difference that the sales will be wavelength-selective switches because the Chinese OEMs designed and build their own line cards.
Well, we have some for duals that are capable of CDC, and we have some that are singles that are, those single 1x9s that are broadcasting and select. So there's both.
I don't know. I haven't thought about it that way. I think about the DCO market as being different than the ACO market. And the densities that you can achieve in faceplates are higher with ACO than they are with DCO. And so there's a lot of OEMs that are going to prefer -- they're going to prefer ACO. And there may be more of a data center interconnect kinds of applications that may -- but it depends, that may prefer DCO. On the other hand, there are a lot of applications there where density will be important. So I don't know, I don't know how it's going to shake out. I think there's -- in the end, if you look at the LightCounting estimates, you'll see that there's significant market for both.
Well, Angela, thank you very much, and I want to thank everybody for tuning in today. We appreciate your taking the time to spend with us. And we hope you'll be able to join us again 3 months from now. Have a good day.
column12:
Thank you, Karen, and good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate your taking time to listen to our conference call today. A replay of this call should appear on our website within 8 hours. An audio replay will be available for 2 weeks by dialing 1 (855) 859-2056 for domestic, or 1 (404) 537-3406 for international. Enter the conference ID number 59806101.


I need to remind all of you that any forward-looking statements in today's discussion are subject to risks and uncertainties, which are discussed at length in our annual and quarterly SEC filings. Actual events and results could differ of materially from any forward-looking statements. In addition, the company undertakes no obligation to update any forward-looking information presented. Unless otherwise indicated, all results discussed are on a non-GAAP basis. A complete reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP results may be found in our earnings press release and in the Investor Relations Section of our website.


We have prepared some slides for today's earnings call. You can view them by connecting to the Investor Relations page of our website at finisar.com, click on Investors and scroll down to Webcast Archives and click. You will see's a listing for today's third quarter 2017 earnings call.


I am pleased to announce that Finisar achieved another all-time quarterly record for revenues and profits in our third quarter. Revenues were $380.6 million, an increase of $10.7 million or 2.9% over the second quarter and 23.1% over the third quarter a year ago. This growth was primarily from strong demand for our 100-gigabit per second transceivers. In addition, customer demand for wavelength-selective switches and ROADM line cards continue to be strong.


And I'm going to let Kurt take over and review the rest of the numbers for you. Kurt?
Thanks, Kurt. We expect our revenues for the fourth fiscal quarter of 2017 will be between $360 million and $380 million. Datacom revenues should grow by approximately $5 million, mostly from continued growth of 100-gigabit QSFP28 transceivers. This will be partially offset by lower sales of 10 gigabit and below short wavelength transceivers.


We expect telecom revenues to decline by approximately $15 million mostly from 3 factors: annual telecom price reductions, seasonality associated with Chinese New Year, and lower revenue from our 100-gig CFP transceivers in China.


We expect fourth quarter non-GAAP gross margins will be approximately 36%, primarily due to the impact of the telecom price reductions and our expectation of lower levels of revenue.


Fourth quarter operating expenses will be approximately $70 million. Non-GAAP operating margins will be approximately 17%. Non-GAAP earnings per diluted share should be from $0.50 to $0.56.


We are optimistic about fiscal year 2018. We believe our revenues will grow again starting from the first quarter. We expect continued growth from the sales of 100-gigabit QSFP28 transceivers, mostly for hyperscale data centers. We are currently sold out on this product, and despite our continuing to add capacity, we expect that sold-out situation to last at least through the end of calendar year 2017.


In addition, we expect to finally achieve qualification in the first quarter of fiscal 2018 for both our 100-gigabit coherent CFP2 ACO transceiver and our ROADM line card for use in the Verizon Metro upgrade. Our qualification will be with a key OEM customer. We have already completed qualification of our CFP2 ACO at multiple customers and are in the qualification process with several others.


We also believe that Chinese service providers will begin domestic deployments of ROADMs in the second half of calendar 2017.


Finally, during the third quarter, we shipped many thousands of our high-powered VCSEL arrays for 3D sensing. We are continuing to add manufacturing capacity in anticipation of strong demand from this application in the second half of calendar year 2017.


And now with that, I'm going to turn it back over to Karen and open it up for questions.
Karen?

Question and Answer
.....................................................................................................................................................................................................................
Well, 2011 happened in a much larger magnitude and much more suddenly. And it was -- there was way overcapacity -- or not overcapacity, over inflation in inventories. They were -- the inventory levels were very high levels, and so as a result, when there was this inventory correction, it was a really big deal. We don't believe that, that's happening. And I know -- I mean, there's a little -- there may be a little bit of inventory in the system because we're -- there's several products around the industry that are still in the sold-out condition, but it is not as pervasive as it was in 2011, and particularly, in the 2 big product lines that were driving us there.
This is the same source that said only a couple of weeks before that, that the demand for 100-gig optics is going to be at least 10x what anybody had ever forecasted, so I think there are sort of mixed signals there. From our standpoint, demand is really strong from a lot of directions, and it's not just OEMs like the one you mentioned, but it's predominantly driven by the hyperscale data centers. I don't see it being -- the type of situation being released for a very long time.
Well, the revenue levels and the potential for revenue levels in the second half of our next fiscal year are going to be -- or the next calendar year, actually, are going to be tens of millions of dollars. And I don't know exactly what our competitors have said, but they -- it's a huge potential for a lot of people in the industry. We are adding capacity, we're hiring people, we're adding equipment, we are increasing our capacity very dramatically. It is true that we manufacture on 4-inch wafers. We think our yields are higher on 4-inch wafers than they would be if we were processing 6-inch wafers. And so we made a very conscious decision to stick with, 4-inch. VCSEL wafers are very thin and very fragile.
Well, our issue on CFP is -- doesn't have to do with -- I mean, they're pretty system specific and they're pretty customer specific. I mean, we sell these things to a lot of people, but in these particular cases, there's going to have to be some component changes and, in one case, component and firmware changes just to be able to compatible with all of the systems from an OEM. Each OEM has -- they build lots of boxes. And each one of those boxes you have to qualify. Each one of them has a motherboard that has different characteristics. The chip that you're interfaced with and your optical device interfaces with has a different trace length, primarily the chip, the impedance matching is often quite different. We've had, in some pieces, the power supply and the characteristics of the power supply is really quite different. So anyway, we've run into a couple of those where we're having to make some changes to be compatible with a customer's motherboard.
Well, we think that CFP2 -- well, first of all, for the year, we're going to have very strong sales if we added up for all the quarters. But as we go into the next fiscal year, I would expect that CFP sales themselves are probably going to be flat, maybe. I don't know that they're likely to grow because the problem is CFP is migrating to CFP2 and we've got CFP4, and all of those eventually are going to go to QSFP28. So anyway, CFP has been a good product for a long time for us, but I -- we're not expecting a lot of growth out of it in the future.
I would expect in the next quarter or 2 is probably a good estimate. It could happen in a matter of -- I mean, in one case it could happen in a few -- a couple of weeks but I -- these are difficult things to predict sometimes because it's dependent upon what you're testing and a bunch of attention that the end customer has to pay to these issues.
I don't know exactly how to quantify that one. I mean, we are going to produce in calendar year '17 many, many more VCSELs than we've ever produced at our history. And we celebrated a few years ago our 100 million VCSEL that we had shipped, so I'm -- the capacity is pretty astounding for us. So -- but I'm -- it's not something that I can or I'm willing to exactly lay up how many wafers and how many dye we're going to produce.
Alex, I'm not sure. We had predicted internally a few quarters ago that we -- we thought that the 40-gig and 10-gig sales would decline in a modest rate for a long time, but we haven't seen that. We're still sold out on 40-gig. Our QSFP 40-gig product, I mean, we are at capacity. We got -- we can't ship all the stuff we got orders for. Our 10-gig is one of those where we have been surprised. We have not -- we are not sold out. We have had quarters in the last few quarters where we've had sales that were up substantially in a quarter and others where they were down modestly, but I don't -- I guess, I think that 10-gig is likely to be flat to down a little bit in the future, but I don't think it's going to be a very dramatic reduction because I think a lot of what we sell in 10-gig goes into enterprise data centers, and enterprise data centers aren't making a big transition to 100-gig. I mean, lot of them are still -- are upgrading from 1-gig to 10-gig and some of them are still going from -- no, it's actually from Cat5 cable 1-gig to optics on 10-gig. So we're...
Fiber channel was a bit slow in the market in the quarter for us.  I think fiber channel is -- has been a really stable business for us. It hasn't been a rapidly growing business for us, but it has been really stable. We have some great customers there. And it's -- it is -- the big threat that everybody talks about is, will cloud services take over all of these SAP and Oracle databases? And if they do, well, then it's not clear whether the big cloud services providers are going to run fiber channel in their cloud data centers. Now I will tell you, there are a lot of fiber channel sands in these big cloud operators today. And I don't know how that's going to expand, but anyway, overall, our expectations for fiber channel revenues are modest. I mean, we don't expect a lot of growth there.
I think, yes, that's probably right. We don't see a lot of variation in the pricing of that market and we don't -- and we make a lot of them. I mean, we're really competitive in that market because our volumes are so big.
The one area that was pretty strong was our tunable XFP, so it was -- we're sold out on that.
We're doing -- we're working with dozens of customers that are in consumer-related industries. Some are automotive, some are mobility devices, most of them have some 3-dimensional sensing as the goal, but for different purposes sometimes, but there's a lot of projects right now.
Well, we -- there are integrators that will combine light sources like our VCSELs with photodetectors with lensing, with special filters, with packaging, all of that, and we supply into those integrators who are contracting for the ultimate customer.
QSFP28 LR4, we sell to, I don't know, maybe hundreds of customers, and we're sold out. And we're going to stay sold out for a long time. And the product works really well, so I don't view there being an issue there.
No. We think the inflection is going to occur in the middle of the year '17.
Yes. We've now shipped a lot of units and the truck is pulling up to the dock because we have to make subsequent shipments that are considerably larger than what we have already shipped, and so we're -- it's rolling. My confidence in terms of the success of the project has grown. It's -- there's never a sure thing in this world, but at least there's -- at least at this point, it looks pretty good.
Well, I will tell you, the latest info we've got from different service providers and different equipment builders is that there will be some broadcast and select and some route and select. We originally thought -- go back a year, we thought that by the end of 2016, tenders would have been issued for deployments very early in 2017. Well, it didn't happen. It got pushed out. We supplied fairly large numbers of units, hundreds and hundreds of ROADMs or wavelength selective switches for -- what we would call in the U.S. field trials, they would call them small deployments in China. We then thought that these tenders would be issued in right after the first of the year. That didn't happen. And then we said -- we thought it would happen right after Chinese New Year. Well, that hadn't happened. And our latest input says it's probably a second half of event. And the tenders may occur between now and July, at least we're hoping for that, but we are assured by officials at the service providers and in the equipment companies that it's coming. And the only issue is going to be at which pace that they will deploy them. And there's a lot of -- automating the optical network is a new adventure for the service providers in China. And learning how to control and manage the networks is a complicated task for them, and so they're walking through it one step at a time. And I'm -- we're disappointed, obviously, that they haven't been able to deploy earlier, but I don't think that has dampened our enthusiasm for that business and that market because the volumes are potentially so large.
Yes.
Well, that's exactly what we are doing and what we have been in qualification for the last 1.5 years, trying to qualify our ROADM blade. So it is a complete ROADM blade with WSS channel monitor, EDFA processor, memory, software, you name it. It's an interface to their system, to their network management system. And we have been disappointed that we have been unable to qualify before now and -- but we think we have made it through all of the hurdles. We think we now have an acceptable device that is functional, and all of the very exacting system tests that are going to be run, we think, have been run. So we're very optimistic now that we will actually achieve AVL status and be able to ship in production quantities in, I don't know, probably the second quarter of our fiscal year '18.
Well, it's interesting that for us, we find that the -- selling the entire blade, the gross margins are -- the prices are twice as high as setting a wavelength selective switch, but the gross margins are actually a little bit lower. They're close but they're lower. And that's partly because we have to buy pump lasers and build EDFAs. We don't make pump lasers. We -- you then -- you wrap a lot of sheet metal and some circuit boards into this package as opposed to very exotic optics that go in a wavelength selective switch. And so the combination of all that, selling the sheet metal and the circuit board, along with EDFAs, means that the end of day, we get -- though the price is higher, the gross margin is a bit lower.
Well, the driving -- the biggest factor for us is the QSFP28 and the -- though we do sell it to hundreds of customers, the top few dozen are all in the cloud services business. They're operating these hyperscale data centers. So that is the biggest pressure that we see and that's the biggest demand that's going to stay, we think, strong for quite some time. I mean, yes, there are some other parts of our business in '18 that are going to be strong. We talked a lot about the 3D sensing and the VCSELs, I mean, that has exciting possibilities. We think our qualification for our ROADM line card and our CFP2 ACO finally for the Verizon project is again an exciting prospect for us, and again, for increased revenue. We just think -- there's a lot of things wavelength selective switches and our QSFP to the 100-gig in general. We think fiscal year '18 is going to be good.
Well, demand at this point is dominated by a very few customers. The number of prospects and the number of projects that we're working on that don't have a lot of demand yet, but where we're supplying prototypes, samples, small volumes, et cetera, for testing and for -- the building of systems, there are dozens and dozens of customers that are in that bag. So it's a -- obviously, it's a market that's going -- we think is going to have legs. The real question is going to be what are the apps that people are going to write once they have this ability to do precision 3D sensing, where they can do facial recognition at even some distance? I don't -- I'm not -- we're not a company that's going to write apps, but this is one of the things that's going -- there's going to be a lot of people who are going to turned loose that are going to be trying to write apps for these capabilities. So I'm -- anyway, there's a lot of excitement generally in the people that are working in this field. And if any of their estimates in the future come through, there aren't enough VCSELs capacity in the world to take care of this.
I think the qualifications to date are approximately 10, and we've got a number more that are in process. The -- and share in the future is really hard to predict. There aren't many suppliers, and we're -- and we'll be the largest company in the industry. We won't start with the largest volume in this particular product area, but as the largest supplier in this industry, we usually get recognized for that. I mean, we get a fair amount of attention, so I'm -- we will generate substantial volume in that market.
Yes. I think you're right. We expect the datacom business in '18 to be strong.
