I think consolidation is an attractive idea in our industry. We're -- optics industry forever has been too fragmented. There's too many competitors and too many of us with too small a market share. I mean, we're the largest in the industry, but our market share is less than 20%, and that's not really a healthy industry. So I think consolidation in general is good. And the issue is -- and we obviously did a big convert to build our cash balances so that we are prepared in case we encounter or pursue some opportunity for consolidation. I can't speak to the possibilities or the probabilities. I can only tell you that we are currently open to the idea. We find the idea attractive, but it's all about -- at the end of the day, it's all about price. It's price and how do you get the shareholders of both companies to come out with an advantage for both, right? It's got to be -- it can't be a zero-sum game, so -- and that's often difficult to achieve.
Negative. All of QSFP28 is in datacom.
No. We do -- we sell a -- versions of CFP that are Ethernet, which is a single 25 -- 4 lanes of 25-gig, and then we sell 4 lanes of 28-gig, which is for -- that allows the overhead for forward error correction which is for sonic rates. For those products, we consider them telecom.
We're sold out in the product area regardless of where the demand comes from. So it's the same product that we sell in Asia, that we sell in the U.S. or in Europe. And it's just a matter  -- we have more -- we have a lot more orders for that product than we can possibly build.
Thanks, Karen, and thanks, everyone, for tuning in today. And I hope you'll be able to join us again in 3 months for our fourth quarter call. Have a good day.

column2:
I was hoping you could give us a little bit more granularity on the pressures on your gross margins and a little bit more on the mix of the decline in the business. It's our understanding that the majority of the Wireless products that are being sold in China are extremely low margins. If those are falling off, shouldn't that be a major offset to gross margin pressures? And then second, can you give us a little bit more clarity on what's going on in the transition on 100G datacom products into the data center for specifically the CFP to CFP2 and how that's impacting your revenues? How much of that is temporary as a result of that product transition and how long it will take for that to kick back in as a growth driver?
Could you give us any sense of when you think the revenue from CFP2 will reach -- or the combined revenue of CFP and CFP2 will reach the prior levels? Is there a shape to this transition curve that -- when do we get back to the prior levels where it's actually a growth engine, as opposed to just simply growing the CFP2? And how fast -- how far do you think the CFP1 falls off?
How about a follow-up here for, Kurt, on the gross margin question. If you think about the second half of the fiscal year. I know you don't like to give guidance out that far, but with the pending price cut negotiations, the ramp in LTE, do think you can expand your gross margins in the second half of the year or do think you're going to be in this 31% to 32% range?
Okay. Perfect and then, Kurt, maybe for you too, if you exclude the Wireless business within the datacom sales, did the datacom business grow sequentially?
If I look at it at the high level, optical trends of sophistication, it's becoming a bad business and it seems to be getting worse evident by, I guess the gross margin outlook. And even CNN has comments where their gross margins really took a step function down. Any thoughts on just kind of taking capacity out of the system? Consolidating? Are there any thoughts to kind of rationalize your CapEx plans, just so that we don't have these recurring concerns raised from investors?
Jerry, just on that. Is there a way to get a premium for your products so that if we're doing this for 15 years and we still have a step function down in price negotiations. How do we get a premium so that you get a return for all the investments in this sophisticated technology?
And lastly, any thoughts on the share repurchase considering your stock has been down quite a bit of this year and as we do see business returning, it's probably one of the best investments you can make?
Maybe a couple of interrelated ones on your datacom business, maybe asking in a slightly different way from a previous question. If I split the datacom business into your Wireless, kind of your Web 2.0 type of customers and kind of your general enterprise, looks like -- or looking forward here, is the base Enterprise business, do you expect that to grow or will that also be down, similar to the other 2 segments of that business?
Yes, in your current second fiscal quarter, yes.
Okay, fair enough. And then just a follow-up regarding some lumpiness, is that a veiled reference to Web 2.0 customers and if that's the case, how many customers make this a noticeable trend on your whole datacom business?
Okay. Maybe just a last quick follow-up for you, Kurt, on depreciation. It sounds like last quarter, depreciation stepped up $2 million and you're looking for another $2 million in this current quarter. Where do we see that going in terms of this CapEx build? How much higher can it go over 2, 3 or 4 quarters, whatever your visibility is into this current build at Wuxi?
Okay, so sounds like you're going to have a couple more quarters of $2 million or so per quarter step up and then maybe a more flattening after that?
I wanted to go back to the comment on datacom lumpiness and just try to understand between your cloud customers and who buy direct and OEM vendors. If you saw it more in one area or the other. And then you talked about Wireless in general being up during the third quarter, in the past when you've seen datacom downticks, they've been relatively short periods. I'm just curious how you think about the overall data center side of the business also for datacom, to start expecting -- to start to tick back up in the second half of the fiscal year?
And Jerry, just to make sure I understand. That's not just in Wireless but the data center side of your datacom as well.
You're expecting that to be better. Any kind of share with 40G BIDI that Cisco has been -- a program that's been ramping. There's some vertical integration in terms of 100G. Do you think that's impacting share or do you think what we're seeing is reflective of a kind of broader market?
Understood. And final question on the gross margin trend to the point of the second half -- or the next quarter seeing an uptick in Wireless. Kurt, where we sit right now, do you expect potentially for gross margins to go down further or can you make it  stable at these levels if we see Wireless transceivers pick up in the January quarter?
I feel like this has been asked but I'll guess I'm going to ask it again. Well, I mean, I'm hearing you guys guide down basically telecom, data center, datacom and Wireless part of datacom next quarter and you're saying that the quarter after, you have really good visibility to Wireless coming back. Do you have visibility at this point to anything else coming back besides just the Wireless piece? I mean, should we go ahead and model the rest of the datacom business or the telecom business to be sequentially up, and is there any reason to think it should be sequentially up in the third quarter?
Okay. And then what's the timing -- I just want to be clear on the timing of the CFP2 100G, when that will be ready, some -- you guys delivering it, as well as some demand in there for that to be a meaningful revenue contributor?
Okay. And then finally for me. I mean, with CapEx at these levels, that's in response to some unit demand that's out there. Given the way that the last -- things have been evolving, I mean, do you still feel as confident as ever that this high CapEx plan is correct? Does unit -- have your unit expectations generally speaking across-the-board taken a step back recently with these markets, with these kind of demand conditions? Or -- and initially, the bottom line, do you still feel confident in your aggressive CapEx plan?
So my question is very much in line with what Mike was just asking about. Just trying to understand the lumpiness you're referring to on the datacom customers. I would think it will still be helpful to at least break out between OEM vendors that do pull from inventory hubs versus the web scale type of companies that might have given you a little more visibility to their build plans, et cetera. So what I wanted to do is just be able to talk broadly about those 2 categories of customers, what that's happening. And on the web company side, what is your understanding of inventory because that's a category of customers that might actually hold some level of inventory?
Okay. Now a lot of questions being asked about 100G, largely CFP to CFP2 transitions. But obviously, that category is much broader than that including CXPs and the board-mounted optical assemblies, as well as the coherent products coming out. So can you also re-enter the 100G discussion from a timing perspective when we get some revenue growth including all of these other form factors of 100G?
Okay. And then just getting some sense on visibility in the telecom there, you do have some level of lead time from -- including your OEM vendors. So can you talk about what you're seeing on the road on designs, as well as the tunable XFP designs that were supposed to ramp?
A couple of things I was hoping to clarify. I don't think you've called out what the -- those Wireless business was in the July quarter, but it would help us if we could understand the order of magnitude. I understand it was a big driver of the growth and it's a big factor in the decline, but I feel like I need to know what percentage of the overall revenue is coming from this group of Wireless products.
Okay. And then when I look at the trends, you've had 5 quarters in a row prior to this one where your year-over-year growth was in excess of 20%. And for October, we're looking at the midpoint of 6% year-over-year growth. And I understand there's lumpiness and I'd like to try to see if you could help us look past lumpiness in terms of the shorter-term cycles and think about what you expect is the longer-term revenue growth. What's kind of the range you're thinking of for the full fiscal year even if you can't talk specifically to quarters?
And one last one for me then. Last quarter, you talked about one of the factors in pressuring the gross margin was around 100G, I guess a combination of price declines and volume. When we think about the pricing environment for your 100G products, how do you see the October quarter relative to the July quarter?
I guess, first, Kurt, I know that you're not providing specific guidance for gross margin for the back half of the year, but you did talk about mix being the key driver of the metric. So if we look at the back half of the year you're still talking about Wireless improving, which is a negative margin mix. You're talking about the 100G transition being ongoing, which could still be a headwind. The January quarter should have a month of annual telecom pricing negotiations baked in and you'll see a full impact in the April quarter. So I guess, my question is, if we just take all those negative mix impacts, is there anything on the horizon that you could point us to on the positive side that would help?
Okay. And I guess, just for any of you, you've provided a lot of reasons why the margin profile is getting pressured in October, whether it was depreciation, salary increases, the 100G or fixed cost absorption, but you didn't talk about pricing or competition. I would love your thoughts on those dynamics and if you saw or are seeing more aggressive pricing trends from your competition.
I guess, dovetailing off of that, maybe if we look at the CPRI business, specifically given your commentary on the competitive nature of the Chinese business, last quarter, I think Eitan in your prepared remarks you talked about plans to continue to cost-reduct these products even while you expand capacity. Can you talk to us where you're on this cost-reduction path? And could this product ever move from being significantly dilutive to the company's average gross margin to be more towards the corporate average, or does the mix need to shift from 3G and 6G towards 10G or will 10G even be dilutive to the margin profile?
Okay. And I guess -- just one follow-on I guess, on the 100G side, Jerry. You talked about shipping everything you can with CFP2 and that, eventually, the mix of CFP plus CFP2 is going to become a growth driver for the company later in fiscal year '15 or maybe in '16. Can you comment on when the gross profit becomes a driver from a pure dollar basis for the company given that you have higher competition, given that the ASP of the CFP2 is significantly lower than its predecessor and even though it is gross margin accretive still much lower. Just when will growth profit become a tailwind?
So the gross profit is not significantly lower from the CFP to CFP2. I think that it's inherently expected, but it's -- could be 15% lower or something to that nature?
I just wanted to do a quick follow-up because we talked about gross margin a lot. But if we have the same mix in 2015 and take your CapEx plans into account, would there be a point in any case in 2016 where margins would start to improve? Or is the comment on the no improvement there and the no investment there mean that you -- in a steady mix, you'd have a steady margin?
So in 2015, if we have wireless growth, you could still have margin improvement after the CapEx based on that different variables at the other side of the equation?
Okay. And then just switching gears, that small acquisition that you made in the quarter, the Oregon company, could you just talk about how vertically integrated that product now is, what you expect the cost savings to be there or the impetus for doing the integration and then did LightSmyth have any other customers and would they continue to have any?
So did that production move to China?
Did that production move to China?
Gentlemen, I wanted to focus on the telecom side of the market. As I look strategically on your business, datacom, you got a good market share lead there. The comparisons are tough, you've pretty much exhausted the different market opportunities that you can go after. But it seems to me, on the telecom side, there's a lot of leeway, there's a lot of potential market opportunities that you can accelerate or go after to drive growth in the business. So am I reading this correctly? Could you walk us through what the strategy might look like to continue to drive growth in the business and maybe some of the easier ways of doing so? And that's just sort of one piece of that. And then the second, as you talk about the telecom side, can you update us of the status of your qualifications with some of the customers maybe CNN, Cisco and others that were going to use your ROADM line cards, where we stand on that, have all your customers been qualified to deploy your ROADM them line cards? What's the demand's been at Huawei, for example, on the telecom side of the equation and where are we on the Verizon, metro build-out again for the telecom opportunity?
Eitan, on the coherent side, just kind of a quick follow-up there, are you getting a wink from your customers that they're -- the ones that are, for example, insourcing or vertically integrating coherent line cards today with their equipment chassis products, are you getting a sense that they are willing to, over time, outsource that line card to you or any other component manufacturer?
column3:
I'm just -- I'm trying to get a sense of the duration of the downturn considering the weakness that we're seeing from some of the carriers. Jerry, you pointed to the growth in bandwidth, the growth in video, which has been a consistent theme for many years. But I'm just trying to get a sense of how long do you think this current downturn that we might be in. And a subsequent question would be, how about -- how do we think about planning the business, monitoring -- moderating CapEx? Or are we still adding capacity, particularly in the 100 gig?
In '15? Okay.
And then, perhaps on your plans of just CapEx, is it full speed ahead? Do we throttle that back a little bit near term? Or it seems -- I'm just trying to get a sense of your expansion into your new plants and facilities.
Okay. Lastly, just competition-wise, it seems the traditional folks on telecom are now moving into datacom. If you're seeing any change in terms of dynamics in the datacom business competition-wise.
I had 2 questions. The first one is on revenue. You mentioned in the commentary that there was some lumpy demand from some datacom customers. And I just wanted to understand if those are OEMs or the cloud players. And on the gross margin, I wanted to understand, given that April has a slow quarter of telco price reductions, if you feel that the trends with revenue growth and price reductions, do you think April gross margins could tick down from current levels? Another question is on consolidation. Jerry, we've seen several moves in the last few months from different players in terms of consolidation in the space, and I wanted to get your thoughts on that.
So these would be more end customers, kind of the data center operators rather than the OEMs, is that right?
And the final question if you think about kind of the revenue trend, you talked about optimism going into calendar '15. Do you think we're, from a revenue perspective, bottoming out in the October quarter and expect quarter-over-quarter growth to continue? Do you have visibility for that going to 2015?
A couple of just very targeted questions and then a broader one. First, would there be growth in the guidance that you're giving for the upcoming quarter if we were to strip out the contribution to the quarter-to-quarter growth from China wireless sales?
And can you give us any quantification or qualitatively what the relative contribution of that piece is? Because it's such a big swing. It's so different from the rest of the business, particularly on the margin front.
Is that China wireless piece the predominant variance between the high end and the low end? Or is it other factors?
The second question is on the CFP product line to the CFP2 product line in the datacom segment. Can you quantify or give us some sense of what the trajectory of the combined revenues of those are? Is the erosion in the older CFP still a greater factor than the ramp in the CFP2? Or has that started to stabilize and nose up? Where are we on that? I was sort of under the impression that it would be in the June/July timeframe when that went positive.
Okay. So the last question is, just can you give us some sense of what you think your long-term growth targets might look like at this point and what you think the long-term gross margin and operating margins might look like? I mean, what is your thought on terms of what the company should be delivering under reasonable conditions in terms of growth, gross margins and operating margins?
Just a follow-up on the datacom 10G. I mean, it was down; 40 and 100 was up. I'm curious, the declines in 10G, is it more just the lumpy aspect to the transition to 40 or 100 going faster than anticipated? Or is it ASP reductions? I'm just trying to get a sense for where are we in that 10G upgrade cycle in the data center.
So Jerry, I know there's -- you're expecting growth for the business and growth in datacom. Do think we can get growth in 10G next year? Or is it the transition to the other speeds that are going to provide that growth?
Last question. Can you just talk about the range of the ASP reductions for the telco business? I'm assuming it's in that 10% to 15%, but what end of the range would it be at?
LLC. I just want to hit on industry consolidation again. I know you guys can't comment on any specific things in the works, but I'm just wondering is there anything that would keep you from doing a large deal, like conceptually, or I guess, sort of philosophically? And if there were a large opportunity that they were around, is that something you guys would be willing to participate in given -- if it was the right fit?
Great. So I'm just wondering, you guys talked about 100 gig QSFP28. I'm just wondering if you have any more visibility into just the switching, 100 gig cycle, when things finally kind of go from the Edge to the top-of-rack switches, or I should say the aggregation switches. For 100 gig, do you see that -- I've been hearing sort of middle of next year, you could kind of start -- we start seeing 100 gig switching systems. Like, what are your thoughts on that?
Okay. Just one final one, housekeeping. I know you guys didn't show your datacom and telecom trend. You kind of just gave us some changed up numbers quarter-over-quarter. Is it your intent to stop disclosing that detail?
Jerry, you touched about this in one of the last answers, but I wanted to go back to 40 gig, which seems, according to the double 00 [ph] numbers on the Ethernet side, to be really ramping in the -- it looks to be with the Web 2.0 vendors, including Microsoft. And I'm wondering if you see activity across all of those big players and what you can tell us about the application that it's being used for and how quickly you see that being deployed across more than just Microsoft, who has talked about it publicly?
Okay. And do you see a lot of -- is everybody moving in the same pace? Or is there opportunity for this to be a pretty good ramp as we move through calendar 2015?
Okay. And also, a follow-up on the consolidation, just a specific question. We've seen, I guess, Koch Industries with the Molex and then going out and buying Oplink, which I guess, traditionally was more of a telecom player. Can you talk about where you think that strategically is going and what that means for the industry? Because it feels like there's been some changing of the names of some of the companies, but the actual number of companies competing hasn't shifted that much yet as we talk about consolidation.
A couple of questions. First, can you talk a little bit about the $2 million excess in obsolete inventory? And looking at the total inventory, it did go up quite a bit sequentially. Last quarter, some of the increase was due to an acquisition. This quarter, can you just talk about what you saw from the hub pull from the OEM companies and perhaps the linearity of that? And then lastly, what you guys are thinking when, given your guidance, what you're thinking about the hub pull on that guide?
But can you say what the products were that was in that $2 million?
Okay. And then the OEM pull. So the pull, at least looking back in Q2, it was as forecasted predominantly? Because the reason I'm asking is a number of OEMs have missed their October or September quarter numbers and guided down. So I'm just curious whether you saw any kind of deviance versus forecast in the OEM and any linearity of that.
Okay. Last question. Eitan, can you talk about the timing of the 100 gig coherent in terms of first revenue? The $400 million market number sounds interesting. Who else do you see really modularizing the 100 gig? And do you think you'll be first to market?
On the telecom side of things, I was wondering if you could talk about a little bit geographically as we look into the next quarter. And then any sort of commentary you may have on the previous quarter, if you think that's helpful. And then the second question, just around the datacom side of things as we look into 2015, Jerry, do you think there's been enough kind of competition that has come into the fray that we should think about you guys as more growing with the market? Or do think that there's more share taking to be had in 2015?
This is Rob Richardson on for Patrick today. Just kind of wanted to get the housekeeping question out of the way. Kurt, did you mention what the top 10 customers as a percent of revenue were or number of 10% customers were in the current quarter?
Great. And then if -- I guess, Jerry, if we kind of shift back to datacom, and I'm thinking kind of more with the wireless transceivers. Was kind of the weakness in there derived from any geography? Was it China-driven or from somewhere else?
So if you think about that -- so my kind of understanding was that's a pretty dilutive product to the overall corporate average gross margin. Just kind of wondering, what kind of played in the margin in the quarter? If you saw kind of that weakness in the wireless transceivers, would have expected maybe a little better gross margin? Just looking for some thoughts on that.
Got you. Great, I appreciate that. And then, I guess, kind of one last question, if I may. So I just want to make sure I understood the expectations for the next quarter, thinking about the split between datacom and telecom. Are we thinking datacom should be up year-over-year, with telecom down to possibly flat? Or is there -- what's kind of the mix -- or your thoughts on that?
Yes, sure, quarter-over-quarter.
Just a quick number I missed in the prepared remarks was the actual CapEx in the quarter.
Great. Okay, I appreciate that. And just following up on the commentary around the data center and the 40 gig and lumpiness. It does sound that you're pretty confident about that business coming back. And so I'd like to try to get a better understanding of the dynamic of the weakness in the reported quarter and the recovery in the coming quarter. How much of that is simply a single customer or a few customers and project delays versus dynamics regarding either competition, pricing or production? Essentially, I'm trying to get a sense of whether this is pure lumpiness of activity and concentration or whether there's a bigger picture trend, given that one of your competitors talked about a pause in 40G in the coming quarter where this just sort of ebbs and flows. Sorry for the long-winded question.
And just going back to the China wireless. In your July quarter, I think you talked about some component shortages in the supply chain. I believe it was mainly some amplifiers that just slowed down in activity in China. And I think we had the impression that this problem was getting resolved and that China would ramp for wireless build-outs in your October quarter. And so to what degree were you surprised by weakness in China? And what's the cause? Is it that they didn't resolve that supply chain problem or something else?
I guess, what I'm trying to get a sense of is what was the reason? Is it that the customer is having a supply chain issue? Or are they making a choice to simply spend less because they're trying to control CapEx or have weaker demand? I'm trying to understand the source of the weakness.
Going back to this lumpiness in the 40 gig area, we hear a lot about competitive pricing dynamics between the various Web 2.0 players. Do think there's been a change in economics for these Web 2.0 guys because of all the aggressive pricing across that landscape and therefore, that's trickling down to your level and causing the projects to move around a lot?
Hopefully. I hope that some of the other guys can handle that. Getting into telecom a little bit, what happens -- we hear a lot about 100 gig and the customer base, the OEMs becoming a little bit more vertically integrated. So what are the product areas that are most at risk for you as that happens in 100 gig?
Correct, yes. Yes.
I have a couple ones. One, on this China business, the wireless transceiver business, is there any visibility into the duration of that deployment? I mean, when does that start to roll off? Kind of give us your thoughts to the extent you could see that or hear from the OEM partners you're working with.
Okay. So it sounds like you feel that this business has another 2-year type of run rate. And when it does roll off, I mean, what are you hoping to substitute that revenue with? Is it going to be just as you were saying, 40G, 100G and maybe some of the telecom starts to ramp? Is that sort of what the strategy is to kind of tack on growth here? Or is there something else in the pipe?
Okay. So it sounds like your footprint in China can help you maybe get into some other of those 4G LTE cloud RAND deployments elsewhere in the world if they do commence?
Got you. All right. And then just wanted to revisit a few items, kind of old topics, if you will. One is maybe to Eitan on the silicon photonics front. I mean, what are you guys doing on that front? I mean, JDSU recently talked about some partnerships that they're considering or are working on. Not that I'm expecting you to announce anything, but just kind of walk us through your thoughts there. That would be very helpful. And then the second one, just on the Cisco relationship. Cisco switch business was actually pretty strong this past October quarter. But the softness you had seen, it sounds from the results I'm looking at, it sounds it was more weighted towards that Web 2.0 vertical than maybe one of your largest customers, OEM customers. And just kind of revisit that customer, if you will, and give us some thoughts around the traction and strength of your business there.
Just a couple of questions for me. I'll start in the 40 gig datacom. I'm curious what you think your share is there, whether it's -- if you view yourselves as #1 in the market and how that compares with the overall datacom share. And then also, are you seeing or do you know of any component shortages sourcing into that market specifically?
Okay. Just a follow-up on that question on capacity. Is there a restraint on you adding capacity fast enough so you can relieve those constraints? Or is there equipment or other things that are preventing you from doing that?
Got it. Okay, that's helpful. Second question, Jerry, a follow-up to your responses in an earlier question regarding competition. Specifically, I think you mentioned some more competitors. I'm assuming they're coming from China. A couple -- a kind of 2-part question on that. Are you seeing this coming in as high as the 10 gig speed here? And if so, is this having an impact outside of China?
column4:
Question about the guidance. The range implies a broad range of revenues with very little on the margin side. Is there a large order in there that you're factoring into that guidance? Or is there some sort of mix that I'm not seeing on the margin side of the guidance?
So that could be some variability in the mix, that's the kind of impact.[ph]
But it's not one big contract out there that's providing us with that big range?
Okay, understood. I wanted to go a little bit more detail into the 40 gig side. It sounds like the hyperscale data centers are still doing well, and I was hoping you could talk to us a little bit about the pricing dynamic and the competitive forces going on in that market in terms of other players, given the growth prospects there.
Is there a similar pricing pressure to the telecom side of the business right now?
So just want to start with gross margin impact from the yield loss, would you mind -- would you quantify that a little bit for us? And does your guidance for the coming quarter assume that yield loss? And I guess, relatedly, like maybe you could talk about the revenues associated with this opportunity if they're coming in next quarter. Did you see any this quarter? How big is it, et cetera?
Great. Okay, I'd love to hear a little bit -- we just heard about 40 gig, 100 gig strength in datacom. Is it fair to say this is driven by the ramp of CFP2? Is that becoming a more substantial revenue contributor? I guess, I'm assuming it's a lot bigger than the Vixel-based 100 gig. Could you use any kind of texture on -- with that CFP2 contributing, perhaps even tell us kind of the rough proportion of 100 gig revenue coming from CFP2?
That's interesting. Are you seeing any -- I mean, I assume this is the -- the CFP2s are going to systems that are not with your largest datacom customer. Are you seeing the CPAC module out there? Any kind of competition from that?
Okay. Last question, just telecom. Obviously, it's very challenging around for everybody here so you're not alone. But any thoughts on the outlook for the year, 14% year-over-year decline. I mean, is that how we should think about telecoms sort of through this year? Or is there reason to think that telecom could get significantly better?
You made some really strong improvements in operating expenses reduction during the quarter. I'm just trying to get a sense of what part of that is actual changes that you've taken out in OpEx, or is it really rather expenses moving from quarter-to-quarter?
Okay, that's helpful. And gentlemen, on the gross margin, recognizing the telecom price reduction is the mix and the volume, are you also starting to see intensifying competition on 40, and potentially 100 gig, and so if there' some preemptive [indiscernible] to kind of maintain your market share in these 2 transport speeds implied in the gross margin?
Okay. Lastly, as it relates to competition and industry structure, Jerry, now that you had a chance to look at the Form 10 from JDSU, what are your thoughts in terms of consolidation? Are you more interested, less interested as to say your thoughts on just going at it alone or offsetting some price competition with greater scale?
Great. Just one from me, around the web scale guys and I guess, in particular, kind of the Web 2.0 guys. Can just talk a little bit structurally, about your visibility there and then just kind of the activity that you're seeing on the go forward? As we look at some of the CapEx estimates going forward, they are slowing some, but just want to get a sense for how you're thinking about that and how your visibility has evolved over time.
I have 2 questions. First, on the 13 weeks versus 14 weeks. I know you had mentioned that there's some benefit in the 14 weeks partially offset by Chinese New Year. If we look out to July, and if you just look historically, if you return back to a 13-week quarter, has that traditionally meant kind of a revenue decline or less of an increase? How has that worked out historically? And how do you expect it to play out this year?
And is it linear, Kurt? I mean, would 13 weeks and 14 weeks, this is 7% difference, should we think about that, or is it not that linear?
Understood. And then gross margin, I think, you mentioned that the impact of the lower yield was about 75 basis points. You have some ongoing impacts. So if I look past April, you don't have the telco price reductions going to July. The CapEx starts to level off, hopefully the yield issues, which still continue to impact this quarter, start to lighten. How should we think about gross margin trend line at the April quarter?
And then how should we think about impact if the yield issues are fixed and the CapEx declines, just -- those 2 factors. What kind of a swing factor do those create on gross margin?
Understood. And final question on telco. Jerry, Eitan, this quarter, the level of telco revenues is the lowest revenue in 5 years since you started breaking it out. And I know, I understand the carrier CapEx challenges and still waiting for metro, but how do you think about this business in terms of investing in telco given it continues to decline as a percentage of revenue and hitting kind of multiyear lows at a time where the market's not healthy but for your competitors it's not as challenging as it seems for you as well?
I understand, just [indiscernible] in that 70 -- I mean, $80 million to 90 million for long time. Now we're closing -- probably closer to $70 million. I'm just wondering from a run rate perspective as things get better, should this be 30% of revenues? And 40% -- is it a $100 million run rate? Just trying to understand, given the steep declines we've seen in telecom, what the real run rate of this business is if you start getting back to growth areas?
I wanted to just check on this, just to keep our lives simple. In terms of the OpEx trend with the extra week, you're suggesting April would be around $70-ish million, $69 million, $70 million, and then July operating expenses should be similar to the January level. Is that the way we should think about it?
Okay. And then, you talked about the web scale guys. I haven't heard much mention of submarine exposure and I know a number of the OEMs, your customers in the system side, have been talking about submarine opportunities, both literally under ocean or opportunities at landing sites, I'm wondering if you could give us some sense of how big an opportunity that is for your business and what the growth trends are?
And does that fall in your telco or your datacom segment?
Okay. And then several quarters back, the increased exposure to China and China backhaul affected your gross margin. I'm just wondering where those projects are in light of what looks like flattening CapEx in calendar '15 in China as China Mobile slows and maybe Telecom and Unicom ramp. Can you talk a little bit about the dynamic of China and how that affects your business?
Okay. And then you've talked about long-term, targets particularly, the gross margin trending towards the mid-30 range. I just wanted to do a check on how you feel about those targets and whether we should think about trending towards the mid-30s over a period of a couple years, or whether you feel like you can exit fiscal '16 significantly higher. Just want to get an idea what kind of slope we should think about towards the longer-term targets?
Yes. I wanted to dive a little bit into the OpEx side of your prepared remarks. You talked about significantly decreasing operating expenses, but then during this kind of Q&A, you talked about that January is at historically low levels giving some pushouts of R&D projects. So should we think about Finisar as being in a period or perhaps exiting a period where they've invested aggressively in R&D and we should start to see that line item growth be below the revenue growth rate that you're in somewhat of a harvest mode? Or conversely, should we tend to think that OpEx should relatively pace the revenue growth rate over an intermediate term period?
Great, that's helpful. And then, I guess, Jerry, I wanted to dig into datacom mix in the quarter and how we should think about it on a go-forward basis. You did talk about hyperscale being up a little bit. I think wireless, you did talk about some sequential growth. Can you give us a little bit on your thoughts on the enterprise business on the Fibre Channel and Storage side of the business? And then also any thoughts that you have on the transaction between Avago and Emulex and does that change the competitive landscape or impact your customer base at all?
Any comments on Avago and Emulex?
A quick one for Jerry. One of your competitors in datacom had a problem with the 40 gig components in the quarter. So I was wondering if you saw a benefit in the January quarter revenues by the April quarter guidance due to share gains [indiscernible] Web 2.0 compete.[ph]
All right. [indiscernible] Sorry didn't mean to interrupt. Then a follow-up for Eitan. Can you just give an update on how the samples of the 100 gig coherent CFP2 modules have been received? And just also on the timing, when do you think that ramps?
So it's a complicated question but I will ask it anyway because your datacom mix is as high as it's ever been. So if we were to exclude the impact from the yield loss on the optical engine, and it sounds like the impact on the mix from the wireless transceivers is -- it's been the same as in the past couple of quarters. This would suggest that your rest of the business gross margins are not even close to what you did about a year ago, which was about 37%. So I wonder if you can walk me through what's going on in the rest of the business. Are you seeing more pricing pressure in datacom? Or is it just that telecom, given the lower base of revenues you're experiencing probably, onetime pretty low gross margins for this quarter and we would eventually expect that to go back to where it was once telecom picks up. If you can just walk me through what's going on with the gross margins, it would be great.
Really appreciate it. And then just going on the business, if we split up by -- split it up by speeds, has it changed from last quarter, meaning that 40 gig is the fastest-growing part of the business and 10 gig remains the largest portion of revenues?
It's still the same?
Just want to follow up on this 100 gig CFP comment that you just had, Jerry. Given some of your competitors or many of your competitors are out maybe a little bit earlier competing in the CFP2 versus what they were in the CFP4, the original CFP, can you just talk about what are going to be the dynamics of winning opportunities? Is it going to be time-to-market, performance, price and then how do you see a more competitive CFP2 business impacting your overall business?
Okay. And how does CFP2 margins compare to corporate average?
Okay, great. And then one other question. You were talking about -- there's a question about consolidation in the industry. And if you were to play a role in consolidation, what would you be looking for? I mean, would you look to just simply gain scale? Would it be eliminate a competitor, to make it a less challenging competitive environment? Would it be to pick up a technology? What are your thought processes there and...
Great. I just have one question. You've already indicated somewhat how we should think about 1Q revenues. So if we look beyond the current quarter, 2 quarters out, on the gross margins, 2 quarters out, are you willing to say that 4Q should mark the bottom and then we should be up in 1Q sequentially a bit?
A couple of quick ones. I was just wondering, the depreciation expense that was going through the gross margin due to construction of the facility in China, when does that, Kurt, begin to alleviate? And is that a multiyear effect, is that a couple of quarters effect?
And how much basis points did that contribute in the quarter, that affect of depreciation expense in the gross margin?
Okay, all right, excellent. And then, again, a quick one on telecom side. I know a lot of questions have been asked on that front, but I'm just curious like, the competitors, one of the major competitors there had seen their ROADM business actually snap back sequentially. We want to know if you could -- were willing to talk about your ROADM business. But it sounds from the numbers that, that business had declined. So I don't know why you're not seeing exactly the positive impact of perhaps even the 100G metro deployment for AT&T, CNET [ph] reported this morning and talked about some metro projects already in effect. I know there's Verizon metro and that's potentially where you will be playing with the flex grid ROADMs. But we were trying -- what I'm trying to sort of get to is different architecture on the ROADM side that will begin to give you growth in that business and you just sort of excluded at the moment from the current metro projects that are going on. If you could comment on those 2 major carriers deployments, that would be helpful.
Okay. And if I may and I apologize for being that specific. I recall again going back a few years -- top 3 customers of yours were Cisco, Alcatel-Lucent and Huawei and Cisco sort of hanging in there and certainly had a nice quarter. And perhaps you were seeing the wind of that, this quarter as well, and then going into the next quarter. But what about the Alcatel-Lucents and the Huaweis, I mean, are you seeing other customers replacing them, are you seeing them snapping back, how these major customers of yours are performing at the moment? Are you happy with that performance?
First of all, regarding your datacom sales increasing 8.5%, I was wondering if you can go over the mix between 40G, 100G and wireless?
Okay. I see, wireless was #2. And what about for your outlook, should we expect similar dynamics or 40G and 100G to be growing faster than wireless in the first quarter?.
Got it. And then moving to telecom. I was wondering -- Eitan already talked about WSS, but what about tunable XFP and you think you can just -- if you're not going to break it out, specifically, can you just tell us what the rough mix is between WSS plus tunable XFP in terms of overall telecom sales?
And how much is a 10G telecom, or 10G and below telecom?
Okay, all right. And then, did you talk about price decline, what the actual price decline was?
Got it, got it. And I'm wondering -- I was wondering if you can tell us Emulex what their percentage revenue?
column5:
Can you give us a little bit more granularity on some of the individual products? What segments are improving, what segments are under pressure? What you're seeing in terms of scale out data center builds? What's going on with the ROADM business? Those type of metrics, plus a whole lot about products in the discussion.
Within the wireless, is -- I assume that's mainly CPRI. Are you expecting that to continue to come off? I assume that the brand builds are moderating a little bit this year from last year. Is that the right way to think about that?
And just one last question on the weak stuff. Can you give us your sense, is it right to think of that as 14 over 13, that's the percentage adjustment? Or is it right to think of that as some modestly lower adjustment in that when we think about the top line?
It sounds like 4% to 5% kind of number is probably the right number to use in the comp?
If I look at from year-over-year, a year ago you had 13 weeks. This year you'll have 13 weeks, so the comparisons are more reasonable. And then the midpoint of that is actually a decline on the year-over-year basis. So are there particular products you're seeing more of a slowdown in the year-over-year basis?
Okay. And Kurt, if we look at the wireless weakness last year, I think some of that was related to China and their ramping 4G in the mix of products there. The -- what are we seeing in terms of China this year as they expand their 4G network? If you could give us some color, that would be helpful.
Okay. That's helpful. And lastly, as we think about just the steady state and the growth in the data centers and your opportunities there, any thoughts of recalibrating how we should be thinking about OpEx on an annual basis? Also sales and marketing and then also R&D?
Jump right in, Kurt, I guess I was a little bit surprise that you're only guiding for a gross margin increase 20 basis points sequentially coming off of full impact of telecom pricing in the April quarter. What is driving this? Is there any -- is -- are you seeing more aggressive datacom pricing? Are there any mix assumptions that you've baked in that are impacting the margin guide? And can you elaborate a little bit -- I think it was during Eitan's prepared remarks, where you stated that you're seeing some increased competition. Can you elaborate on that?
Is that increased in telecom versus datacom? Is that increased in a certain speed, 100G, 40G, 10G? Is that across ROADMs, WSS? Anywhere that you can point to where it's more exacerbated?
In single mode versus multimode?
Okay. That's helpful. And then can you elaborate a little bit on your 100G business? Can you help us perhaps understand the relative contribution to datacom versus telecom segments? And then could you give us an update on both kind of your product road map for the QSFP28 and also the coherent CFP2? I believe you're shipping samples last quarter and would love to get your thoughts on when we could see volume shipments of that product.
Okay. And then just last one if I may is can you comment on how we should think about datacom versus telecom in the July quarter relative to the flat -- flattish sequential overall revenue guide?
Just back to this question of datacom competition, I mean, obviously Innolight filed today and they're obviously growing very fast in the datacom space. And I'm kind of wondering if these are one of the guys that you're seeing from a competition from? Just at a higher level in these large scheme of data centers, I mean, how are you feeling about your market share? Do you expect to maintain that? Or might you back away from some of this business if pricing gets a bit irrational? Just could you comment more on that sort of the competition in hyperscale data centers?
So just on 40 Gb, it sounds like that was down sequentially. Would you attribute that to lumpiness? Is there any kind of potential or maybe already happening wait for effect for hyperscale data centers?
Okay. And on 100 Gb, it sounds like that was up sequentially. I'm wondering, is that mostly driven by CFP2? Or I think, where are we in this CFP versus CFP2 transition? Can you give us a little detail on that?
Okay. Last one then I'll pass. WSS module, that strength, is that financially [ph] the green shoots of the metro deployments of 100 Gb or just seasonality? Or just any kind of -- is it long haul versus metro? Just any kind of color on the WSS strength and whether or not you expect that to kind of continue to the year would be very helpful.
My first question is just if I try to quantify the impact of the extra week offset by Chinese New Year. I think in the past, Kurt, you've mentioned that, that would be approximately low-double-digit million [ph] positive impact. Is that the right way to think about it? Where your $320 million have been essentially flat quarter-over-quarter somewhere in the 306, 308 number? And would this quarter's midpoint be up about 3%? Is that the right way to think about it?
Sure. And was telco a little bit better and datacom a little bit lower than expected if you look at sort of how April played out?
Understood. And on the higher competition comment, I know you mentioned that as both single mode and multimode. Is it at the higher speed as well as 40, 100? Is it sort of across-the-board on speed? Is it more 10 Gb and wireless? Can you give us some sense of where that higher competition is?
Okay. Understood. And then final question on web scale, can you talk about web scale players as a percent of revenue sort of where they're trending to? And with the talk about 25 Gb servers, 100 Gb in the data center, do you -- when do you think that starts to become sort of a demand driver? It seems like aggregation speeds in the data center today are still mostly at 40 and 100 Gb in the data center. When do you start to think of that as a real revenue driver?
And so if I look at this quarter up, kind of low-single-digit percent quarter-over-quarter, if you x out the timing issues, do you expect sort of that trend line to continue, Jerry, given 100 Gb opportunity going into the second half of the year?
Quick one for Eitan and then one follow-up for Jerry. But Eitan, given we saw some growth in WSS and tunables, I'd just like to gauge your confidence of a telco metro-optical cycle starting, whether it's beginning of next year with a little bit of build in the second half, but just your conviction on this now versus 3 months ago.
Just one follow-up for Jerry then. On the datacom business, I'd be curious to know like how good is the visibility there? If you can kind of comment on [indiscernible] forecast, or is the book-to-bill been above 1 recently? Anything you can help us out with visibility would be great.
I want to go back to the data center, which I know has gotten a lot of attention. But just the comment on the 25 Gb happening, I wanted to verify that that's your second half, but the calendar '16. And then could you just give us a little bit more detail, have all the major hyperscale guys standardized on 40? Or do you think that some of the lumpiness is the decision that's waiting for -- to build out the 25 Gb versus the 40 Gb roll out?
So the [indiscernible] that's timing issue? Or it's not an architecture decision?
Okay. That's helpful. And then I guess, Kurt, I was just curious. If you look at the mix, and I know there's some variability here and you talked about building out the second 2 floors in China, what kind of -- what's the plus and the minuses we could expect in gross margin going out for the year? What would be your best case scenario if you got some operating leverage or gross margin leverage on some volume through the China facility at the end of fiscal '16?
Just wondering, you guys indicated that wireless competition -- or competition for your wireless products was picking up a little bit. And I know that those products were -- have historically been kind of lower-margin products. So just kind of wondering, at what point do you decide to walk away from that business in wireless? Are you anywhere near that decision? And then how aggressive can you be in terms of pricing in that product line?
Okay. And then kind of get -- stay on this gross margin topic, what would it take to get gross margins up to, say, the 32% or 33% range? I know you don't want to give a time frame. But I mean, can you get there based on simply volume? Do you need all these -- execution of all these cost improvements in wireless and optical engine and other products to get there? Do we need a relief of the competitive dynamics? I mean, what are going to be the big catalysts here or could be?
Yes, I understand that. But just kind of -- is it possible to rate the factors -- or rank the factors that could potentially improve the gross margins, let's say, 32% or 33%?
Okay. And final question, are there any products that are in the horizon that you're going to introduce? I know you guys talked about all the R&D to drive new product development. Is there anything on the horizon that you feel like could give you some more favorable pricing dynamics?
This is
in for Simon. I wanted to ask a little bit about operating expenses. I understand the OpEx next quarter will have these exceptional expenses from sales conference and the restricted stock units. But how do we think about OpEx on a normalized basis going forward?
Okay. That's helpful. I wanted to ask you, how do you guys -- what are you guys thinking about the 100G market for intra data center optics? And kind of your timing for how long it takes to develop in terms of timing and ramp PS [ph]?
Yes, right, right.
When are you expecting to introduce the form factors at the CLR4 or the PSM4? Is that the same time frame?
Okay. Okay. That's helpful. And regarding the competitive piece, I just wanted to dig just a little bit more there. I guess, do you consider your key competitors inside the data center, is it still Oclaro, JDSU? Is Avago still one of the guys that you see when you talk about that space also?
Okay. So it's primarily in the Web 2.0 space then, okay.
And lastly, I just wanted to see if I could get a sense of your view around acquisitions. Maybe not any specific acquisitions, although I think some people have one in mind specifically. But just kind of trying to get a sense of your priorities, your logical priorities regarding the consolidation sector in general and your thoughts on consolidation.
Couple for me. First of all, I think you referenced gross margins doing a little better than expected due to their yields in the optical engine. Wondering how good those are compared to overall corporate averages and where you think that can go. And really, where can the volumes go? And can we see a positive mix shift from that quarter or 2 down the road?
Okay. And this is a product that we're seeing from just single customer, or are there more than one? Or do you expect more than one here in the future?
Okay. Is there any time frame by which this becomes a meaningful product category for you like a year out as an example? Any clarity you can give for this -- on that, Jerry?
Okay. Appreciate the detail there, Jerry. One follow-on question here on the topic of CFP2 coherent. How would you play out the competitive environment here? Where do you think your share will sit or your share rank? Any general thoughts as we look out couple quarters a year or so? How should we view that?
Okay. Eitan, how important is it to have a 200 Gb versus just 100 Gb for that product category?
So I'm a little confused about exactly what's going on in Wuxi. Just wondering if you could give us a little bit more clarity around it. It sounds like on the one hand, you have a little bit less CapEx in the quarter that just occurred, that you are accelerating CapEx spend for the upcoming quarter a little bit above what you had expected before. Is that a function of you changing the rate of which you're building those new rooms out and therefore choosing to also the pattern of the spend in order to facilitate that? Or is that going to cause -- are you behind schedule or on schedule relative to the original time line for the build completion that you originally scheduled for the end of April? And relative to that extra capacity, is that a reflection -- should we read into it a reflection of faster transition out of Shanghai and into this building? Where are we in actually shutting down the Shanghai side of it? But could you give us some of the pings and pongs on that? It's kind of hard for us externally to track it?
Okay. So just so I understand, the costs associated with this transition, we've been carrying around a lot of cost for training, busing people back and forth between the various facilities. I assume that, that some of these costs that you've been carrying start to fall out as you bring up the capacity over the next couple of quarters. Is that the right way to think about it? And isn't your cost structure substantially lower here than it is in Shanghai? Therefore, shouldn't those 2 factors help you deliver improvement in margins as we go over the next 2 or 3 quarters, other things being equal?
Is it fair to say that a good part of the pressure in your margins over the last 18 months has been the result of some of this transitionary pressure and as this falls out, you should get some of that margin back that you've given up? Or is that too naïve and it's really a function of product and volumes and you actually have had competitive pressures that are altering the equation? And I guess at the end of the day, are you guys more or less or just about the same in terms of how bullish you are about your business? It sounds really muddled to us from the comments. You don't want to seem to want to commit to any meaningful trajectory on change on anything, whether it's product lines or growth or cost structure. Why so muddled?
That was very helpful. It just helps to get the sense of whether you guys are bullish or nervous.
Can you give us a little bit more granularity on some of the individual products? What segments are improving, what segments are under pressure? What you're seeing in terms of scale out data center builds? What's going on with the ROADM business? Those type of metrics, plus a whole lot about products in the discussion.
Within the wireless, is -- I assume that's mainly CPRI. Are you expecting that to continue to come off? I assume that the brand builds are moderating a little bit this year from last year. Is that the right way to think about that?
And just one last question on the weak stuff. Can you give us your sense, is it right to think of that as 14 over 13, that's the percentage adjustment? Or is it right to think of that as some modestly lower adjustment in that when we think about the top line?
It sounds like 4% to 5% kind of number is probably the right number to use in the comp?
If I look at from year-over-year, a year ago you had 13 weeks. This year you'll have 13 weeks, so the comparisons are more reasonable. And then the midpoint of that is actually a decline on the year-over-year basis. So are there particular products you're seeing more of a slowdown in the year-over-year basis?
Okay. And Kurt, if we look at the wireless weakness last year, I think some of that was related to China and their ramping 4G in the mix of products there. The -- what are we seeing in terms of China this year as they expand their 4G network? If you could give us some color, that would be helpful.
Okay. That's helpful. And lastly, as we think about just the steady state and the growth in the data centers and your opportunities there, any thoughts of recalibrating how we should be thinking about OpEx on an annual basis? Also sales and marketing and then also R&D?
Jump right in, Kurt, I guess I was a little bit surprise that you're only guiding for a gross margin increase 20 basis points sequentially coming off of full impact of telecom pricing in the April quarter. What is driving this? Is there any -- is -- are you seeing more aggressive datacom pricing? Are there any mix assumptions that you've baked in that are impacting the margin guide? And can you elaborate a little bit -- I think it was during Eitan's prepared remarks, where you stated that you're seeing some increased competition. Can you elaborate on that?
Is that increased in telecom versus datacom? Is that increased in a certain speed, 100G, 40G, 10G? Is that across ROADMs, WSS? Anywhere that you can point to where it's more exacerbated?
In single mode versus multimode?
Okay. That's helpful. And then can you elaborate a little bit on your 100G business? Can you help us perhaps understand the relative contribution to datacom versus telecom segments? And then could you give us an update on both kind of your product road map for the QSFP28 and also the coherent CFP2? I believe you're shipping samples last quarter and would love to get your thoughts on when we could see volume shipments of that product.
Okay. And then just last one if I may is can you comment on how we should think about datacom versus telecom in the July quarter relative to the flat -- flattish sequential overall revenue guide?
Just back to this question of datacom competition, I mean, obviously Innolight filed today and they're obviously growing very fast in the datacom space. And I'm kind of wondering if these are one of the guys that you're seeing from a competition from? Just at a higher level in these large scheme of data centers, I mean, how are you feeling about your market share? Do you expect to maintain that? Or might you back away from some of this business if pricing gets a bit irrational? Just could you comment more on that sort of the competition in hyperscale data centers?
So just on 40 Gb, it sounds like that was down sequentially. Would you attribute that to lumpiness? Is there any kind of potential or maybe already happening wait for effect for hyperscale data centers?
Okay. And on 100 Gb, it sounds like that was up sequentially. I'm wondering, is that mostly driven by CFP2? Or I think, where are we in this CFP versus CFP2 transition? Can you give us a little detail on that?
Okay. Last one then I'll pass. WSS module, that strength, is that financially [ph] the green shoots of the metro deployments of 100 Gb or just seasonality? Or just any kind of -- is it long haul versus metro? Just any kind of color on the WSS strength and whether or not you expect that to kind of continue to the year would be very helpful.
My first question is just if I try to quantify the impact of the extra week offset by Chinese New Year. I think in the past, Kurt, you've mentioned that, that would be approximately low-double-digit million [ph] positive impact. Is that the right way to think about it? Where your $320 million have been essentially flat quarter-over-quarter somewhere in the 306, 308 number? And would this quarter's midpoint be up about 3%? Is that the right way to think about it?
Sure. And was telco a little bit better and datacom a little bit lower than expected if you look at sort of how April played out?
Understood. And on the higher competition comment, I know you mentioned that as both single mode and multimode. Is it at the higher speed as well as 40, 100? Is it sort of across-the-board on speed? Is it more 10 Gb and wireless? Can you give us some sense of where that higher competition is?
Okay. Understood. And then final question on web scale, can you talk about web scale players as a percent of revenue sort of where they're trending to? And with the talk about 25 Gb servers, 100 Gb in the data center, do you -- when do you think that starts to become sort of a demand driver? It seems like aggregation speeds in the data center today are still mostly at 40 and 100 Gb in the data center. When do you start to think of that as a real revenue driver?
And so if I look at this quarter up, kind of low-single-digit percent quarter-over-quarter, if you x out the timing issues, do you expect sort of that trend line to continue, Jerry, given 100 Gb opportunity going into the second half of the year?
Quick one for Eitan and then one follow-up for Jerry. But Eitan, given we saw some growth in WSS and tunables, I'd just like to gauge your confidence of a telco metro-optical cycle starting, whether it's beginning of next year with a little bit of build in the second half, but just your conviction on this now versus 3 months ago.
Just one follow-up for Jerry then. On the datacom business, I'd be curious to know like how good is the visibility there? If you can kind of comment on [indiscernible] forecast, or is the book-to-bill been above 1 recently? Anything you can help us out with visibility would be great.
I want to go back to the data center, which I know has gotten a lot of attention. But just the comment on the 25 Gb happening, I wanted to verify that that's your second half, but the calendar '16. And then could you just give us a little bit more detail, have all the major hyperscale guys standardized on 40? Or do you think that some of the lumpiness is the decision that's waiting for -- to build out the 25 Gb versus the 40 Gb roll out?
So the [indiscernible] that's timing issue? Or it's not an architecture decision?
Okay. That's helpful. And then I guess, Kurt, I was just curious. If you look at the mix, and I know there's some variability here and you talked about building out the second 2 floors in China, what kind of -- what's the plus and the minuses we could expect in gross margin going out for the year? What would be your best case scenario if you got some operating leverage or gross margin leverage on some volume through the China facility at the end of fiscal '16?
Just wondering, you guys indicated that wireless competition -- or competition for your wireless products was picking up a little bit. And I know that those products were -- have historically been kind of lower-margin products. So just kind of wondering, at what point do you decide to walk away from that business in wireless? Are you anywhere near that decision? And then how aggressive can you be in terms of pricing in that product line?
Okay. And then kind of get -- stay on this gross margin topic, what would it take to get gross margins up to, say, the 32% or 33% range? I know you don't want to give a time frame. But I mean, can you get there based on simply volume? Do you need all these -- execution of all these cost improvements in wireless and optical engine and other products to get there? Do we need a relief of the competitive dynamics? I mean, what are going to be the big catalysts here or could be?
Yes, I understand that. But just kind of -- is it possible to rate the factors -- or rank the factors that could potentially improve the gross margins, let's say, 32% or 33%?
Okay. And final question, are there any products that are in the horizon that you're going to introduce? I know you guys talked about all the R&D to drive new product development. Is there anything on the horizon that you feel like could give you some more favorable pricing dynamics?
This is
in for Simon. I wanted to ask a little bit about operating expenses. I understand the OpEx next quarter will have these exceptional expenses from sales conference and the restricted stock units. But how do we think about OpEx on a normalized basis going forward?
Okay. That's helpful. I wanted to ask you, how do you guys -- what are you guys thinking about the 100G market for intra data center optics? And kind of your timing for how long it takes to develop in terms of timing and ramp PS [ph]?
Yes, right, right.
When are you expecting to introduce the form factors at the CLR4 or the PSM4? Is that the same time frame?
Okay. Okay. That's helpful. And regarding the competitive piece, I just wanted to dig just a little bit more there. I guess, do you consider your key competitors inside the data center, is it still Oclaro, JDSU? Is Avago still one of the guys that you see when you talk about that space also?
Okay. So it's primarily in the Web 2.0 space then, okay.
And lastly, I just wanted to see if I could get a sense of your view around acquisitions. Maybe not any specific acquisitions, although I think some people have one in mind specifically. But just kind of trying to get a sense of your priorities, your logical priorities regarding the consolidation sector in general and your thoughts on consolidation.
Couple for me. First of all, I think you referenced gross margins doing a little better than expected due to their yields in the optical engine. Wondering how good those are compared to overall corporate averages and where you think that can go. And really, where can the volumes go? And can we see a positive mix shift from that quarter or 2 down the road?
Okay. And this is a product that we're seeing from just single customer, or are there more than one? Or do you expect more than one here in the future?
Okay. Is there any time frame by which this becomes a meaningful product category for you like a year out as an example? Any clarity you can give for this -- on that, Jerry?
Okay. Appreciate the detail there, Jerry. One follow-on question here on the topic of CFP2 coherent. How would you play out the competitive environment here? Where do you think your share will sit or your share rank? Any general thoughts as we look out couple quarters a year or so? How should we view that?
Okay. Eitan, how important is it to have a 200 Gb versus just 100 Gb for that product category?
So I'm a little confused about exactly what's going on in Wuxi. Just wondering if you could give us a little bit more clarity around it. It sounds like on the one hand, you have a little bit less CapEx in the quarter that just occurred, that you are accelerating CapEx spend for the upcoming quarter a little bit above what you had expected before. Is that a function of you changing the rate of which you're building those new rooms out and therefore choosing to also the pattern of the spend in order to facilitate that? Or is that going to cause -- are you behind schedule or on schedule relative to the original time line for the build completion that you originally scheduled for the end of April? And relative to that extra capacity, is that a reflection -- should we read into it a reflection of faster transition out of Shanghai and into this building? Where are we in actually shutting down the Shanghai side of it? But could you give us some of the pings and pongs on that? It's kind of hard for us externally to track it?
Okay. So just so I understand, the costs associated with this transition, we've been carrying around a lot of cost for training, busing people back and forth between the various facilities. I assume that, that some of these costs that you've been carrying start to fall out as you bring up the capacity over the next couple of quarters. Is that the right way to think about it? And isn't your cost structure substantially lower here than it is in Shanghai? Therefore, shouldn't those 2 factors help you deliver improvement in margins as we go over the next 2 or 3 quarters, other things being equal?
Is it fair to say that a good part of the pressure in your margins over the last 18 months has been the result of some of this transitionary pressure and as this falls out, you should get some of that margin back that you've given up? Or is that too naïve and it's really a function of product and volumes and you actually have had competitive pressures that are altering the equation? And I guess at the end of the day, are you guys more or less or just about the same in terms of how bullish you are about your business? It sounds really muddled to us from the comments. You don't want to seem to want to commit to any meaningful trajectory on change on anything, whether it's product lines or growth or cost structure. Why so muddled?
That was very helpful. It just helps to get the sense of whether you guys are bullish or nervous.
column6:
First off, I'm sorry to hear Eitan's leaving. But it does beg the obvious question which is, can you give us any color on what the reason for the departure is? And does it have any implications for any of the major programs that were under his umbrella? Most notably, the ACO 100G Coherent project? Or any of the other new product development programs?
Jerry, the expectation for the back half of the year has been plotted for a while. This isn't really a new piece of information in the sense that most people knew that there was increasing competition at the low end and the low-end market was being retained longer as a result of the push out of the 25G cycle. There's obviously a lot of new products in startup mode, which you have a lot of prototyping cost for. You've got the Wuxi plant ramping. So a lot of turbulence through the back half of calendar '15. But your commentary suggests that, that pressure is going to be retained through -- all the way through the end of the fiscal year ending July. And that's a much longer window than I think people who are optimistic on the company's longer-term prospects would have expected, particularly in light of the fact that you're now down 2 years in a row in earnings already. So can you give us a little bit more color on why the length of time is so long? And what is changing in the mix to cause that pressure to last further into CY '16 in prior expectations?
And what about on the competitive front? Has there been any change in your thinking relative to the 10G and quad 10G products in terms of price pressure? Volume pressure? The repackaging of the -- for the data center without the -- with the strip to package, non-hermetic? Any of that piece of it?
One last question, and I'll cede the floor. Could you just give us some indication of what the direction was sequentially on the ROADM products?
I'm just -- Jerry, I just wanted to ask on the competitive environment. We're seeing a lot of competition on the low-end. And I guess the investor worry is that this will replicate itself on the mid-range and also ultimately on the high-end. And as Finisar cuts OpEx to protect profitability, how do you work on the balance of it instead of investing more in R&D, so that you can actually move up the food chain? I just wonder if this is the right time to be actually cutting OpEx instead of actually increasing OpEx?
Jerry, on that point, I mean, it does become an industry of escalation and almost an arms race as people try to gain footholds into their key customers within data centers. So anything else that you might be considering -- the Board might be considering, in terms of looking at this -- reducing this arms race between you and very nimble, smaller and larger and ultra competitors?
Okay, that's helpful. And then lastly, Jerry, any qualitative comments on data center spending overall? Whether things are actually slowing for you as you -- or actually still steady-state on the data center side? There's some discussions of CapEx cuts or adjustments.
I guess maybe to ask Mark's earlier question slightly differently. I guess as you look at the competitive industry dynamics, you did talk about moving through the product development cycle at a faster pace as a key goal. But I'm curious though, does the elevated competitive dynamics increase your desire or view on the need for industry consolidation? And do you believe that economies of scale could be a key differentiator, along with a faster development cycle?
Great. And I guess, just shifting to gross margin, Kurt, it's been consistently above 30% for the last decade, outside of a blip in late 2009. And given that 30% has historically been a floor for the company, should we think about gross margin expansion being a fiscal year '17 event with some new products in 25G and 100G which should possibly impact mix? Or based on kind of the competitive dynamics and Jerry, just touching on a more fragmented telecom and datacom, is there a structural shift that's happening that could actually end up pressuring gross margin below 30%?
Jerry, or I'm sorry, Kurt, I guess maybe just asked slightly differently, I think in the past, when you were -- had a gross margin above 35%, you had consistently communicated to investors that typically 35% is where we kind of end up in any given cycle. Is that still a comment that you would stand by?
Maybe a couple of questions for Kurt here. Can you let us know how big is 40G as a percentage of your datacom business?
1/4 of datacom. Okay, are there any supply constraints at 40G, currently?
Okay, and then just one last question on gross margins for me. Kurt, do you think last year, in the January quarter, gross margins declined 110 basis points sequentially, and that was with 3% sequential revenue growth. So is that something that we should think about for this year, as we're working on our models now? Or is there something unique that clouds such a big kind of step down last year?
Okay, and maybe one last question. On the 10G business that's seen all the pricing erosion, are you matching pricing or are you walking away from any business?
My first question's on the telecom side of the business. It grew sequentially despite 1 less week in the quarter. Can you talk a little bit about what may have driven that sequential strength?
Okay, great, thanks. And then, on the datacom side of the business. I'm wondering if you can just give a little bit more clarity. In the prepared remarks you talked about 40G being strong. But presumably, that and 10G are both seeing the pricing pressure. Kind of on a relative basis, did 40G performed as expected or better?
Okay, great, that's helpful. And then, then maybe a final one, if you can -- can you just directionally give us a sense for, at this point, datacom versus telecom margins, if one is above or below the other?
Just a quick follow up on that 40G comment. Given the end of the quarter on August 2, was -- I understand it's lumpy, but was July appreciably different from June? Or was the 40G momentum pretty steady throughout the fiscal quarter?
How many -- can you guys give us a little more clarity or more commentary, I should say, on the number of customers of 40G? And then, as you think about the potential transition of the switchback to 25G that you're talking about, are all the customers moving in the same pace towards that standard architecture and are your products fit for all of the different, all the big Web 2.0 players?
I just wanted to -- as you -- when you think about that 4x 25, do you think that the architecture is being used by the, your customers for 40G are going to be standard? Or do you think there will be nuances in the different ones that you're going to require perhaps more spending or different approaches in viewing the [indiscernible]
Okay, just a question, it looks like on the GAAP side, I think these are related. There was an acceleration in the duplicate facility costs.
