Can you tie that into, I guess, the CapEx trends and what we should be thinking about, so where the underlying business is going with the transition in the facilities? And then with the commentary on the 20% OpEx being tied to that, is that a combination of revenues and costs? Or is that -- or what's the weighting of that, as you to get to that 20%? Is it more cost savings than a growth story for 2017?
I do have a handful of questions I wanted to run through. One, I think you alluded to this. But just want to see if we could get a little bit more explicit regarding your exposure to China. There was, I guess, a comment about wireless exposure and I -- I'm sure that some of your products go into China, but the end destination is different. But anything you can offer to help us understand the China exposure?
Great. And then as you're preparing for the 100G products coming off of the availability of 25G ethernet chips for inside the data center, the intradata center, can you talk about where you are in terms of product readiness? Do you have a 25G laser available now? Or do you have timing for when you'll have that available? And your expectations for that ramp?
Great. Earlier on the call, you commented about some delays in metro builds coming into more of the second half of calendar '16. Do you know what the cause of those delays are?
Yes, no, I appreciate that. You're probably at more than arms' length on some of that, so I understand. So you did talk a little bit about your views on the need for consolidation. And I think I ask you this on every opportunity. But just want to get an update on your philosophy as a consolidator. What you're thinking in terms of what you may do, what actions you might take to actually initiate or move along consolidation within your markets?
Great. And one last one for Kurt, I believe. During fiscal '15, prior to the 14-week quarter, you did average expenses of about -- just over $67 million a quarter. And I understood you had some items that elevated the July quarter a bit. But you're guiding October, I believe, roughly flat on OpEx. So I'm just trying to understand, what's really driving the year-over-year increase in operating expenses, given where revenue appears to be trending?
For the current quarter, with the revenue guide with the midpoint flat, should we think about datacom and telecom both being consistent this quarter? Or is one expected to do better than the other?
Got it. And then, when you make these cautious comments about fiscal '16, to me, I'm thinking that the datacom competition and the pricing is probably overall a much more significant factor than the 100G telecom delays you're calling out. So am I thinking about that correctly? Or do you think about it differently than that?
Right. And then the reason -- just as long as we're kind of summarizing everything once again, the reason that datacom will do better in '17. I'm sorry to beat a dead horse, but this will be my last question. Just, if you can wrap that up in a bow again, Kurt, that would be great.
So I heard your comments on CFP being down. I presume that's the legacy CFP and not CFP2? I'm just wondering, can you comment, the mix of CFP2 versus CFP? And I guess, since you gave us 40G contribution, I'd be curious where the 100G contribution is, in terms of your datacom percent of revenue?
Great. And just relatedly here...
Overall, thank you. And then just related beyond the QSFP28 100G. Like -- my suspicion here is this is probably going to be meaningful middle of next year. Any -- I'm just curious, you comment on the timing when you think 100G QSFP28 might meaningful for you.
Okay, thanks. And then one quick follow-up. CFP2, ECO any sense for what the kind of revenue opportunity there is on an annual basis? And I know it's -- I'm sure it's pretty cloudy. But just trying to figure how to model that, if it's going to be tens of millions a quarter? Like, what do you think?
Jerry, I was just wondering, given the pricing pressure that you're seeing on the data center side. I believe you've talked in the past about a new, lower-cost version of maybe a 100G product. Do I have that right? Are you coming out with a lower-cost product there to compete with the Chinese? What's the timeframe of that?
Okay. And I mean, as we think about industry consolidation or have thought about industry consolidation, have you seen any interest coming out of China to be active participants, as consolidators at all? Have you seen any of that?
Okay. And final question, kind of piggybacking off a question asked earlier in the Q&A session, but the talk about cutting down on R&D spend a little bit and whatnot. Do you need to cut back on any product lines or become less vertically integrated? I mean, is that -- does that run through your discussions at all? Or do you still see it as being a tremendous advantage to be fully vertically integrated?
A couple of quick ones for me. First, on the cost reduction plan. You guys aren't providing kind of a dollar amount on the cost reduction there. And we sort of have to work with the percentages of revenue as you guided kind of 20-ish percent targets in the first half of '17 off of 21.4% this current quarter. So the revenue base is sort of a moving target. So you are guiding for flat look revenue next quarter. Am I crazy to assume this could be a flat year for you, fiscal '16? How do we think about the next couple of quarters in terms of revenue growth?
Okay. And what's sort of the market growth rate you guys are targeting, running your models towards? Is it kind of high single digits? You've been outgrowing the market all along the last couple of years, at least in the datacom side of the segment. Competition is certainly catching up. And what are your thoughts in terms of kind of -- are you going to be market kind of growth rate, type of company? Above that? Below that? And give us some sense of -- around the kind of numbers out there.
Okay, Jerry, I appreciate the honesty there. And lastly, maybe, pardon me being direct here, but you're 70, you're taking over the CEO role. You've been the CEO, then Executive Chairman, back to the CEO seat. Is there a succession plan in place? I mean, kind of walk us through what the thinking might be, I don't know, a year, 5 years. I mean, I don't know what the plan might be. But if there is one, would love to hear more about it.
A couple of quick questions. First, I wonder if you can talk about, to the extent that China and wireless in China in particular was the source of weakness in the quarter, what sort of outlook you have there? Do you expect that, that has stabilized or even rebounded in the context of kind of the overall datacom being flat? And I wonder if you can offer a comment or 2 on demand trends in terms of results and outlook for the storage market as well. And then I have a quick follow-up.
So storage hasn't been causing you any problems, in terms of results or outlook?
Correct?
Great. And then just a quick follow-up. On a question before, I mean, to the extent -- I think what you said is that manufacturing is not really that strategic to what you're doing. I completely agree with that, for whatever that's worth. Although you do -- and you would do it cheaper because you don't have to pay somebody's operating margin, I understand that. But you are spending $30 million, $40 million a quarter, building a building in China. Can you reconcile kind of those two views? And talk about the investment side of this as well as the operating side of it, and whether that's -- in retrospect, whether maybe that was worth doing.
column7:
I guess, just jumping right in, I wanted to dig a little bit on the China commentary. Can you discuss a little bit where you're seeing the demand specifically? And then could you also discuss whether you're seeing any sense that China could be adopting ROADM technology longer term?
Great. And I guess, for Kurt. I know typically you don't like to talk about beyond the current quarter guidance. But given it's the holiday season, I thought maybe you'd give us a gift and perhaps comment a little bit about how the April gross margin should trend. We've seen it on 2015 and in 2013 tick up sequentially, despite the annual pricing declines while it was hit pretty hard in 2014. So if you could give us kind of any range of what you think is a reasonable assumption sequentially from the January quarter guide of 30%?
Great. And then just one last big-picture question from me...
Great. And just one more kind of big-picture question is, we did have Avago sell its modules business to Foxconn, exiting September. I'm curious if you could comment on how you think that would impact the competitive landscape for Finisar given that, historically, that's been a very good duopoly for the company?
Jerry, for you, I was wondering if we could spend some time on ROADMs and WSS demand. I guess, it's been a while since we've seen some good growth from that. So could you go over maybe like the form factors that matter right now? And I know, historically, you had some design wins with Cisco and Ciena, just the design activity and competition in the ROADM market.
Great. That's fair. And how about just one on datacom. So the 100G transceiver business, can you just talk about capacity that you have today? Where you guys are at utilization? And how much capacity you plan on having over the next couple of quarters?
Maybe as a follow-up to that on the commentary on the QSFP28. But remind me where we are in terms of general availability? I thought you guys started sampling basically in the past quarter or so. So wondering kind of how much notional amount that represents at this point and the expected ramp from here.
Okay. That's helpful. Maybe looking at the other side of the datacom market, 40-gig and 10-gig in particular. Is it fair to assume or would you characterize kind of the competitive environment as having normalized? Meaning the price reductions that you had been seeing and the price pressure, is that now largely behind you?
Okay. Got it. That's helpful. And then one quick question on the telecom side, wondering if you've had any visibility into the price reductions kind of relative to prior cycles? And last quarter, you had commented a little bit on the North American metro launches, I think, particularly with Verizon as having perhaps extended into the second half of the year. Has there been any change in your opinion on the time line of that?
I want to start out with just 2, I think, easy clarifications. The first one, Jerry, you indicated that the -- in your guidance commentary that telecom, you expected to grow and datacom you expected to decline. I just want to verify, that was intended on a sequential basis, is that correct?
Okay. That's what I thought you mentioned, just wanted to double check that. And when you talk about your ROADMs and your wavelength selective switches, those are products that do fit within your telecom reporting segment, correct?
And they are generally margin accretive to your business, is that also correct?
Great. That's it for clarifications. Now on a question. In the past, you've talked about some of the competitors in the data center with low-cost designs, the concept of non-hermetically sealed packaging as an alternative way of building products for some of the web-scale operators. And I think you've talked about the idea of maybe offering comparable products, and you don't want to sell your higher-performance products at those lower prices. Could you update us on your thinking in terms of whether or not you're introducing products in that category of low-cost manufactured, lower spec design-type products, how you're thinking today?
And what's the time line for availability of those new platforms?
And will this be true for all rates, at 10-gig, 40-gig and 100-gig products?
And then just one last one. In terms of 100-gig, it certainly sounds like you're optimistic about the ramp there. I appreciate that one of the factors might be around the availability of some of the chipsets, the Broadcom chipsets. Could you help us understand how that factors into your expectations and what your assumptions are in terms of volume availability of the semiconductors related to 100-gig?
A couple of questions. You mentioned 2 10% customers. Are those the same 2 as last quarter, I guess? Can you comment?
Okay. Well, also last quarter you mentioned a couple of metrics around your 40- and 100-gig business. I believe it was sort of about 10% of overall revenue at 100-gig, 1/4 of the datacom revenue at 40. Might you have any updates on either one of those metrics?
Okay. Great. And then one final question. I wonder if you could talk about kind of the market opportunity that you see and the competitive position within the CFP2 100-gig pluggable market, the ACO-type component, how you feel you're positioned there? And what your expectations are? I imagine that's one of the new product cycles you referred to for fiscal '17.
One question on CapEx, a little bit less than you expected in the quarter, but up again next quarter. Can you balance what's driving the actual spending each quarter to some of the commentary on the lead times and perhaps some product being on allocation. Is there anything specific going on? Is it just timing? And when should the big CapEx be over at this point?
Okay. And then just a question more generally on the data center architecture. Jerry, you made a comment about the opportunity in China with some new big hyperscale or Web 2.0 data centers being built. Are they using the same architecture as the ones that we're seeing in the United States? Is there a Fibre Channel opportunity for your, I guess, traditional business, which you're very strong in? Or are they going straight to Ethernet? Are they skipping 40-gig and going right to a 25-, 50-, 100-gig? What's the strategy there? And how does play out from a architecture perspective?
What I really want to understand is the upside in the telecom business in the quarter. It seems like from the commentary, a lot of it came from 10G WDM. So where exactly in the world are they deploying all this 10G DWDM? And what are they using it for?
Are you seeing that activity more in one region versus another? Or it's fairly broad-based globally?
Okay. And then just finally, on the same topic, just in the sustainability of that. I mean, because it seems fairly unexpected since it was much higher than your guidance last quarter that this kind of came in during the quarter. And I'm just wondering about the sustainability of it in your view versus with being a short-term phenomenon.
Probably have 2 or 3 for me. Maybe starting with the 100-gig Ethernet transceivers because one of the reasons for the upside in the quarter. Can you give us a sense of whether you see that coming from share gains or is this the market growth here? And Jerry, just want to make sure, were you tying the growth of this product line specifically to China or is it more globally driven?
I would assume CFP2 is kind of the mainstream form factor there. Are you selling meaningful amounts of CFP4 yet?
Okay. That's what I figured. A quick question on 40-gig. You said you had obviously a very strong last quarter and came down from there. Seems like we're seeing a very strong move at that speed in the datacom moving towards 100-gig. Do you see 40-gig as a growth category in 2016 and beyond? Or is that going to fall off dramatically?
Okay. That's very helpful. Maybe 2 questions remaining for me. QSFP28, I'm assuming most, if not all, of your sales here -- which are obviously small starting here, but are multimode. As we look out into -- out a few quarters, do you expect that to be dominated still by multimode? Or how do you see your single mode fibre-related products ramping up?
Okay. Fair enough. Just last quick question, your WSSs, can you give us a sense of the breadth of the customer base, especially for the ones related to Flexgrid deployments in the near term and as you see it kind of developing into calendar '16?
column8:
Jumping right in, I think gross margin was definitely a positive surprise, especially on the outlook perspective. And I think you talked a little bit about some of the key demand drivers from a mix perspective that are benefiting it. But if we look out longer term, I think you talked about an uptick or a sustainable uptick in gross margin largely being driven by your forthcoming new product ramps in 25-gig portfolio. I'm curious if you can talk a little bit about the timing of that, the timing of QSFP28 hitting the market in volume and just your confidence that you'll be able to drive some margin accretive business over the next several quarters from that 25-gig portfolio.
Kurt, can you wrap any numbers around the gross margin potential of those products?
Okay. And then Jerry, you talked about strength on WSS and the ROADM business currently and being capacity constrained across a number of products. Could you help us understand the relative size of that WSS business and perhaps quantify the amount of capacity that you're planning on expanding at this point?
Great. And then just one last one, if I may is that, Jerry, we're about another quarter removed from that Foxconn transaction. I'm just curious if you could provide any thoughts around implications to Finisar. Could this be an opportunity for you to improve your market position? Or have you seen any changes in the competitive dynamics?
A couple of quick questions. Just following off of Patrick's comment, can you talk a little bit about the 10-gig pricing environment, particularly, relative to Vixel-related short-range optics stuff, which obviously is where that Foxconn event happened. But it's also where you've been seeing a lot of competition from low-grade Chinese competitors otherwise?
Just the question was really around pricing. I mean, it come down pretty hard last year. Has it finally stabilized? Or is it still coming down at that same steep rate?
Oh, good. That's great. The second question is, could you just tell us what the rate of growth was in the ROADM/wave selective switch segment? And when you gave the 30% number, I assume that's both wave selective switches and blades, right?
So what was the rate of growth there?
Good job. And then the last question, just on the sizing issue. If I were to take the CFP2, CFP2, CFP4 and QSFP28 and compare it in size to the 40-gig and CFP older product, 100-gig product, how does the relative scaling of those compare? Because obviously, there's very different growth rates between those two.
CFP2, CFP4 and QSFP28 to 40-gig and CFP, which is the much older 100-gig piece.
But have you crossed over against 40-gig as really the crux of it?
So I don't know if you've commented publicly on ZTE. I guess, I can infer here that you don't have much revenue exposure there, and I don't see much downside from the restrictions that have been imposed. But could there eventually be some upside here given your strong relationship historically with Huawei? And perhaps kind of wondering if that's -- the comments in the Middle East, if that's going to be through Huawei as well?
Okay. And then just quickly on the last quarter here and the decline in datacom, and I recall I think you expected 40-gig to be the big driver of that. I'm just wondering if you can confirm that. Is it mostly 40-gig? Did 10-gig also decline? What really drove that off?
Just a couple of questions. The CapEx number that you gave, the $26 million, could you kind of give us a little bit of color on the -- how much is left to build out the plant? And how much capacity -- or how much CapEx are you using to relieve some of the capacity constraint you're having? Or do those go hand-in-hand and we can't isolate the two right now?
Okay, so this -- okay, but there's an acceleration there at the end after a slow spend so...
So is there additional test -- so I guess, is there -- what's the -- how can we think about the incremental for where there's capacity constraint? And how many quarters do you think it takes? Or how are you addressing the long-term versus short-term capacity constraint issue within your spending plan?
Okay. That's actually -- that's helpful. And then, I guess it's been -- we've touched on it a couple of different ways, but I think if you look at the progression of revenues and margins, it's been fairly tight over the last 5 quarters, in the same range on EPS margins and revenues. When you think about that product mix and the new building, is there a product category that will drive sustainable revenues? Is there an inflection point where you think you can get to a $320 million level and sustain that for a few quarters? Or is it really just a question of timing across a broader portfolio of product?
The first, I just want to talk to you graphically about China as an end market. How large is that maybe in the most recent quarter versus the past few quarters? And then, kind of a question that I guess had been relevant across a number of different companies, but what is your visibility into that region, especially considering there's some products that may be capacity constrained right now?
In China and demands of deployments in China.
Maybe following up on the WSS and kind of ROADM deployments. How do you view your competitive position? Do you see kind of opportunities for share gains or share opportunity in North America and generally your exposure to kind of Verizon, which is the most public of the known kind of metro network builds?
And then one final one. Just on new products, so the QSFP28 and kind of the CFP2 coherent ACO product. I wanted to get your views on competitive differentiation or unique attributes that you believe your product may bring to the market relative to competition.
Just a couple of things I wanted to follow up on. One is sort of both the short and long-term question on the Chinese end market question. First of all, in terms of the quarter you're in right now, your April quarter, did you experience the normal seasonality during the month of February around Chinese New Year? And is it behaving historically normal? Or is the China demand particularly strong in defying your past years of seasonality? And then following up on that in China, what is your expectation for the duration of such healthy spending trends from the Chinese end market?
Okay. And then I wanted to follow up on your position in the North American opportunities around ROADMs and blades. I believe you were in a position where you were getting certifications from the OEMs last time we spoke. Just wanted to get a better sense of what your timeline might be for when you would expect to receive your certifications and start to see more material contributions to your revenue from North American buildouts featuring your ROADM products?
Great. And then just one last one, a little bit more granularity I'm looking for in terms of gross margin drivers. I've made the assumption that as 100-gig increases in the mix, your datacom gross margins are increasing and that WSS and ROADMs increasing in mix drive up the telecom gross margins. So as we make assumptions about mix, each of those segments should see gross margins trending higher through the balance of fiscal '17, is that a fair assumption?
Jerry, for you on the QSFP28, can you let us know if you are shipping all 3 flavors of the product?
Well, specifically PSM4, LR4 and QSFP28 [ph].
Okay, understood. And then, in the QSFP28 market, do you feel like it's crowded? And as I just think back when 10G and 4 by 10 took off, it seems like you and Avago [indiscernible]. Do you have any concerns that there's just kind of more competition here at the front end of this 100G datacom cycle?
One last one for Kurt. Just when you look at the April quarter guidance, are you expecting both datacom and telco to grow sequentially? Or is telco going to be significantly stronger?
with Northland Capital Markets.
And I apologize in advance for looks like a little background noise here. Have a couple of questions really following on that competition question on 100-gig QSFP. I wonder as you kind of looked at where price points appear to be shaking out early on, are they trying to come in line with what you would have expected? And what would support the notion of maintenance or even expansion of gross margins? So question 1, QSFP pricing. And then somewhat related on the growth side, and you talked about that as a major growth driver so that your peers are seeing double-digit type growth and some cases much greater than that. Your guidance still calls for a year-over-year decline. I wonder if you could sort of take us through the metrics in terms of kind of newer products versus legacy in terms of what's going to kind of tilt the balance for Finisar to be able to grow, I think, forward on the year-on-year basis? And I'll leave it there.
No, overall growth for the company. I mean, midrange, you're still talking about sort of a 1% decline. And I thought you were getting ready to give us some growth expectations for fiscal '17? Or maybe you did and I missed them, but feel free if you would like to. But I'm just trying to understand the dynamics between what is some growth in new products versus declines in legacy products. And what sort of growth rate that kind of might sort out to if a growth rate at all?
Okay. If I could do maybe one quick follow-up. And I think heading forward and interested in trying to bracket expectations for that growth because there's obviously a wide range of -- that could imply a lot of different things. Can you comment on your expected share in 100-gig datacom transceivers versus where you think you are in 40?
So first, I wanted to understand your expectations for 40-gig for calendar '16. I mean, how do you see the growth trajectory of 40-gig in calendar '16? I mean, do you think -- can you still see growth maybe from some of the Asian customers? Or do you anticipate 40-gig falling off a cliff as we move to 100-gig?
One last question for me. It's something that's happened in the industry in the past. Certainly, things have changed over the last 5 years and so. But we're starting to get questions from investors getting concerned about double ordering. So I want to get your take as far as whether that's -- whether things are different this time for -- whether investors should now be as concerned since we're using VMI, something that wasn't there in the past. So if you can provide some context on that, I'd really appreciate it.
Okay, just a quick follow-up with that. You and many other peers in the space are talking in terms of being capacity constrained. So would you think that your customers are getting close to engaging in that type of behavior at this stage?
Kurt, can I get the depreciation and amortization number first?
And then on regarding your outlook, you expect datacom to be up. Should we expect, obviously, 100G will be up, should we expect 10G and 40G to be what, flat to down a little bit? And then 100G, more than offset the decline?
Got it. All right. And then any kind of revenue you left on the table because of the component bottleneck, if any?
And then so you said WSS was up 25% sequentially. What was year-over-year growth?
Okay. If that is the case, WSS, up 25%. Obviously, something was a drag. Which telecom products were a drag on growth last quarter?
I have a couple of questions. More on the channel vertical specific kind of focus on the -- in China, the wireless transceiver business. If you guys could comment where you are on that trajectory of exiting that business. Have you exited completely? Is there some revenue still? And if so, when does that sort of gets out of the model completely? And then also from web scale perspective on the Web 2.0 in that channel, what are you seeing out there demand-wise? Is it healthy as it can be? Do you see some pockets of weakness from that channel? Just kind of a broader, kind of look into the web scale guys and what they're doing out there as far as demand goes?
Jerry, I just want to ask if we're talking about the CPRI transceiver business for a wireless deployment, not the telco buildout?
Okay, got it.
The Web 2.0 demand.
And you guys mind separating that a bit and telling us what exactly -- how much revenue is flowing through that channel versus maybe your enterprise business, which I would venture to say probably fill a fair majority of the datacom revenue you get?
Okay. And can I ask again on the wireless side what percentage of the business? I know it's opportunistic sale from hereon, but what how do we think? Is it...
However you like to define it as, datacom overall.
But do you expect that number to decline as for...
Okay, great. All right, and that's very helpful. And if I may, maybe one last question, and this is getting more on the technical, I guess, side of things. As you look into the telecom market, there seem to be new products coming off your conveyor belt or manufacturing belt if you will. The ACO is one of them. It is also seen to be a quite competitive market with some new competitors announcing products as of late. There are some folks calling out kind of low cost options that may have not penetrate the market initially but, over the long haul, may benefit from their single-chip transmitters solution, et cetera. So I'd like to get your perspective there. Your 2-chip solution today is the modulators potentially either they're internally sourced or you're buying them externally. How are you approaching this ACO market on the telecom side of things? And I also ask that in context of maybe Ciena want to be -- well, potentially want to be our customers on the telecom side onboarding or buying some of the component companies like [indiscernible] and bringing some of that component capability in-house on the telecom side. I'd love to get your view there of what you think of that acquisition and how that may impact the overall space.
And please excuse my voice. I'm under the weather here today. So I'm just going to ask one question, which is revenue timing expectations on CFP2 ACO. When do you expect to have your initial revenues? Is that going to be off of the pilot line which we would then expect a couple of quarters later that it would start to ramp towards volume? Just an update on the timing there, please.
column9:
I guess, first, just a multipart question on ROADMs. Could you help us understand the update? Or update us on the status of the Verizon qualification. It would seem from your guidance that you're anticipating that the qualification will be completed in the current quarter and you will ship revenue. And then could also comment on what's causing the delays in some of the adding of your WSS capacity?
And Jerry, any concerns at all that the delaying qualification with Verizon could impact your market share?
Okay. And then I guess on the 40G side -- or I guess, on data centers, I think there was an expectation that the CFP product family would be very strong, but I was a little bit surprised by the 40G growth. So could you isolate the intra-data center part of your single-mode product portfolio and help us understand your thoughts on when 40G growth will turn to decline or on the duration of the contract.
Great. And just on the gross margin side, Kurt, you've consistently talked about mix being most important driver. Could you help us understand how to think about the gross margin potential in FY '17, especially given that in your prepared remarks, you talked about a significant number of new products coming to market?
I've been switched firms. A couple of questions. First, can you talk a little bit about the rate of change in the 100G product line? Just how rapidly it's growing quarter-to-quarter or ideally year-over-year as well, if you could adjust for the 14- to 13-week compare.
Great. And within the telecom piece, can you give us a little bit of more granularity on what individual pieces did? What was the -- how much was the pressure quarter-to-quarter on ROADMs? Was it down 5%, 10%, 15%?
So it sounds like the non -- the legacy products had to -- have been down a lot then. I mean, you're talking about very steep declines there.
So are we talking like 30% type declines there?
All right. Can you also give us a little bit more update on the ACO product, a little bit more granularity on what you've done relative to getting sample units out, where you are in terms of ramping that product line? You said -- you made some comments about it being accretive to growth going out in the upcoming quarter. Any sense of magnitudes around those?
So just so I can get some clarity on what we're saying here, it's -- these are production -- these are nonproduction-line products. These are coming off of the prototype line, I would assume. And we're not yet at the point where we've moved to any production-type line at this point.
And I think I know the answer to this, but generally speaking, the pricing should be fairly stable from April quarter forward for the rest of the year, calendar year?
In general.
Talking in general.
Kurt, can you give us any color on Web 2.0 customers? Maybe what percentage of your datacom business representing the total sales comes from Web 2.0?
Okay. And for you too, Kurt, any comments on what the book-to-bill would have looked like in the April quarter?
Yes. Did you guys have 2 10% customers last quarter -- in prior quarter?
Okay. And any thoughts on the Huawei subpoena?
Okay. I guess where you are locally. But I mean, any changes in our ordering patterns, any concerns? I mean, there's been concerns about the bookings in China and whether or not they can grow from here. And this chatter on Huawei create any pull-in orders. Or do you think there's any concerns like we saw from ZTE? I know that was a quick fix, but just quick thoughts would be great.
I wanted to ask a capacity question from 2 fronts. One is if -- on the CapEx guidance, how much of those facility and how much those new capacity and how should we think about that ramping through the fiscal year? And then I know it's early and you talked about price stability in telecom for the rest of the year. But given you and your competitors talking about capacity constraints, especially in new products for telecom, is there any thought that next year's price negotiations and reductions will be mitigated or lower than this year? Or is it just too early for that?
Okay, that's helpful. And then just, I guess, longer term or maybe not even longer term, but if you -- as you look at the -- inside the data center and you think about the landscape there, could you talk a little bit about the competitive landscape? This should be a year with 25, 50, 100 interconnect to start to take off in the Ethernet side. A good percentage of that probably goes up to both towards the end of the year. And I'm just wondering how you guys see yourself positioned. And then any comments about the adapter card guys you're working with given the Cavium's acquisition of QLogic and what's going on at that level in the data center.
So you don't -- do you see more competition? Are you guys trying to integrate optics? Because Intel's been talking about it. Other companies have been talking about it. Is that impacting anything you're seeing in terms of pricing or competition?
First, I just wanted to follow up on some comments you've made on the ROADM WSS sales in the past. I think you indicated last quarter that the revenue for those products was in the neighborhood of $25 million. And I recall some suggestions that maybe you would exit the calendar year around $35 million for those products. I just wanted to double check your thoughts on that baseline and the trajectory for the WSS ROADM growth.
And in terms of kind of these longer-term gross margin trends, I think you said your typical range is from 30% to 35%, and we're coming from the low point and improving. And I want to get an understanding from you, how you see the industry dynamic, how have things changed in the current cycle or maybe the secular trends where it seems as if on one side, you've got headwinds from some lower cost upstarts, private companies that are talking about very aggressive pricing inside the data center. Maybe that's a headwind. On the positive side, it sounds like there's a lot of capacity constraints in the industry and very significant unit demand. So how do you think about the longer-term trend for Finisar as well as the industry in terms of gross margin and your ability to get back to the high end of your typical range?
So maybe to set the bar just a little bit lower, do you see it as reasonable to model a trajectory over, let's say, the next 2 fiscal years of achieving the midpoint of your historic range?
I realize that and appreciate it. Just wanted to get your perspective. Certainly, I appreciate you taking my questions.
I guess I just want to clarify quickly again on the comment that you think WSS will recover in the coming quarter or grow in the coming quarter. Where do you expect the bulk of that growth to come from? Is that in North American vendors? Do you assume that you do get qualified in North America when you say that? Or is that driven by China? Just any kind of -- or the Chinese vendors to other regions. What's driving that comment?
Okay. To quality -- or sorry, to clarify, I mean, so what you're saying is your guidance for WSS is to be up sequentially, does not rely on the qualification that [indiscernible]?
Okay. That's helpful. So I know, Kurt, you don't want to answer a lot of questions about revenue breakouts, but I'll try this anyway. I mean, QSFP28 versus CFP and CFP2, just curious if you could provide some update on the mix there, and maybe a revenue number for QSFP28 would be great.
That's a lot of detail. I appreciate that. Just one quick though, on CFP2 versus CFP, could you tell me which one is -- the CFP2 bigger than CFP yet?
My first one is a follow-on to the ROADM discussion, kind of pulling it all together. I understand you're building out additional capacity right now for the demand, and that's kind of before the Verizon opportunity. Given the fact that you're still capacity-constrained at these levels, will you have capacity online in time for when those project deployments theoretically begin? Or will you have to continue adding from here? And might capacity continue to be a limiting factor?
Okay. And then more broadly on the telecom side, I mean, investors -- and we would agree that we're entering kind of this multi-year cycle, and yet revenues in the quarter on the telecom business came in at the second lowest level that they've been since you started breaking it out. Is there something that needs to change in terms of industry structure or pricing dynamics to get that business back to prior peak levels or close to the $100 million range?
Okay, that's helpful. And then you mentioned -- and my final question was on the 10G legacy side. Was that geographically specific? Or were there any kind of particular end markets or geographies that you'd point to where you saw the weakness?
Yes, yes.
Okay. Well, just out of curiosity, was that a North American customer or international?
I wanted to follow up on some of the dynamics in the quarter in terms of revenues. Assuming you had pretty good visibility to the impact of pricing declines heading into the quarter and you did guide telecom revenues up heading out in the last quarter, I imagine that, that was a sort of surprise in the downside. And I'm just trying to get sort of what the X factor was on the datacom side to kind of plug that hole. So it sounds like you were -- from my perspective, it looks like 100G had a nice growth as expected. It sounded like 40G might have been the surprise to the upside that kind of allowed you to report kind of around in line. Would that be an accurate [indiscernible]?
Right. And then -- and just to follow up, kind of digging into that 100G, I would have imagined that, that was the source of the upside given the QSFP28 ramp. It's again sort of in line with what I might have expected and what you probably expected. And that occurs in light of at least some commentary around chip availability, chipset availability maybe constraining some of your peers or competitors' ability to ramp QSFP28. It doesn't sound like you're seeing that, but I wonder if you could offer a comment on any constraints outside of Finisar that might be weighing on your ability to ramp QSFP28.
Maybe my first will be on 100G CFP. Would -- how would you characterize the geographic demand for that here? And would you characterize your past quarter here as one showing some share gains for you relative to competition?
Okay, that's fair enough. I appreciate the detail there, Jerry. A question on 100G QSFP28. Based on a response from the last question, talking about roughly $5 million or so in the last quarter and you expected double to roughly $10 million. While an impressive growth here...
More than double. I'll use $10 million as a proxy. I hope you don't mind that. But just thinking about that number, obviously nice growth and a meaningful number for you, but based on the scale that's expected in the industry, still a long ways away from where you possibly could go. Do you see RFPs and RFQs out there from customers that are shorter term in nature? Or do you see someone out there that are possibly getting to some very large numbers over a multi-quarter period of time?
Okay. And to follow up on that topic, Jerry, what do you -- how do you view your pricing in that space relative to what some of the more price-aggressive ones have been talking about? There's a lot of speculation going around OFC a few months ago. How would you characterize where you're at? And where could this go in a year? I think kind of the bogey that some people are talking about is getting down to $500, somewhere between where PSM4 and CWDM4 might be. Where would you speculate the time frame to reach those kinds of levels?
First question is, I don't know whether you talked about this but regarding the price, telecom price negotiations, was it worse than expected?
Got it. And then you gave the datacom mix of 140 and 10, that's about roughly 70% or so. So what's the remaining 30%? Is that wireless piece [ph]?
Got it, all right. And I think you said that CapEx will be $30 million for this current quarter. What was the CapEx for the fiscal fourth quarter?
All right. And my last question is, so what's the mix -- regarding your telecom mix, what's the mix between 10G versus 100G?
Right. I mean, would you classify a ROADM as a 100G product? Or is this -- is it a separate product?
column10:
I guess just diving right in on the gross margin side, a very nice surprise there, both the results and guidance. And I think the last quarter, you had said getting back to kind of a 35% level would not happen in the near term. So I'm just curious, what was the biggest surprise with this metric? And do you think that you have the right mix, the right products and the right competitive dynamics that now perhaps a 35% gross margin is realistic in the intermediate term?
Great. And then I guess just shifting to some of the 100G commentaries, specifically on the datacom side. With the QSFP28, can you help us understand the relative revenue contribution? And then any commentary around capacity or the competitive dynamics in that market?
And then just last one for me...
Great. And then just last one if I may is on the ACO. I think you discussed it as contributing to your outlook on the telecom side. Can you help us understand the relative size of that business right now or any type of output?
So I wanted drill down a little bit here on telecom for a minute. So can you tell us how much WSS grew sequentially? And basically, what I'm hearing here is with the telecom strength didn't come from the new line card despite the Verizon deployment. But does your guidance assume that, that line card is ramped and qualified?
That's very helpful. And so just shifting to datacom for a second. I was hoping you'd maybe dimensionalize here the decline in for 40G. I don't think you mentioned 10G. I'm wondering how that is trending. And what are you kind of assuming here for 40G and 10G as you go into this next quarter?
I got a couple of questions. Just going back to quantifying the trajectory of WSS/ROADM products, was it up more or less than the overall telecom? And was it the stronger performing segment? Or was it less than the rest of telco?
That's great. The ACO products, and you talked about where you are in getting qualifications on the DSPs. There are 7 DSPs out there. What have you qualified on?
Going back to the DSPs just for a second. Are those in-house DSPs or are those COTS DSPs?
That's very helpful. And going back to the margin mix, Kurt. You're so far above what most people had been expecting on the gross margins, and therefore the operating margins, that it's a pretty big perturbation to the model. And clearly, at any point in time, you could bring back in some of the wireless stuff. But if we assume that no wireless comes back, and it just stays at this level in wireless, is there anything that would suggest your margin should regress? Or should we, in fact, be thinking that this is kind of a new normal level here and we got to be using that going forward with the potential that there could be a spike in wireless in any given quarter and given the lumpiness of it? I'm trying to be as general as possible, but get some sense of whether this is the new norm.
And one last question, I'll cede the floor. There was a lot of discussion about the Web 2.0 adoption, the 25-gig, 50-gig, 100-gig architecture starting in 3Q. But it looks like that slowed a little bit because of the lack of availability of Intel NIC cards. If that's the case, should we be thinking that the 10 gig, 40 gig is going to take a little longer before it starts to roll over? Or is that inconsistent with your viewpoint? How do we think about the mechanics around those 2 pieces?
Okay. One last question. I forgot to ask this before. The Intel announcements of their silicon photonics with the Indian phosphide right on the silicon substrate, any thoughts on -- whether that's interesting or competitive? And how it might impact you? And then I'll cede the floor.
So any impact?
Quick question within the datacom, 2 parts here. How much of the business is 40G right now, or 40 and 10G? If you could help us out, that'd be great.
Perfect. And then on the QSFP28, can you just help us out with the bulk of the flavors that's driving the revenues right now, is it the CWDM, the SR4s or [indiscernible]?
And Jerry, just last one for you. It's probably a month or 2 before we start the annual negotiations for the pricing. Just curious if you have any thoughts on kind of what the pricing environment would look like with the supply shortages?
Yes, they're all saying the same thing. So hopefully that plays out for them.
A couple of things I wanted to dive into. One, I want to go back to the gross margin discussion. Historically, I've had the impression that the datacom gross margin was typically 2 or 3 points above your corporate average and telecom may be typically 5 or 6 below. And obviously, with the step-up this quarter, I just want to understand if there is some kind of -- first of all, if my assumptions have been valid, and second is how that might be changing. I presume products like WSS are very helpful to the telecom. So any color you can give us on how to think about gross margin by segment?
Great. Appreciate that. And you mentioned earlier some strength from the Web 2.0 or web-scale customers. I think in the past, you've talked about it bouncing around 10% to 15% of revenue. How did that group of customers fare this quarter?
Great. Appreciate that. And then I just wanted to see if you could talk a little bit about your current views on China as a market and both the 100-gig duration in the metro builds. And then you've talked in the past about adoption of switch architectures and WSS/ROADM opportunities. Love to hear an update as to what you see as the time line for the operators in China for deployment as well as how you would quantify the opportunities specifically for Finisar.
I wanted to follow up on the last question with China. Because it's my impression that right now, you're probably benefiting a lot from 10G in China. And I thought that with 100G in China that they were looking for dual rate CFPs, and I didn't think that you sold those. And obviously you don't sell the discrete components. So I just wanted to -- whether my impression is right. But also just going forward for your greater participation in China, is it WSS that we should primarily focus on? Or are there other products over the next 1 to 2 years that you could get into China for the first time including possibly CFP2 ACO?
Okay. That's super helpful. And then my only other question is just on the guide for the sequential 7% growth at the midpoint. Shall we equally distribute that between datacom and telecom? Or do you think one will grow more than the other?
And actually, just to go back to the last question, just speaking about China, appreciate that answer. But on -- just what's going on with 10G in China and things like SFPs and SFP+? Is there still very strong demand there? And is that going to go away as there's even more 100G into China? Or do you think 10G telecom will stick around in China for a long time?
Great. It's a great thing everybody in the industry are doing so well.
I was wondering if you could go into some of the comments on supply constraint and the comments you made on pricing and keeping things under control. Could you just go into some -- where you think you've got -- where your supply constraint is versus the other players in the industry? Is everybody constrained at the same level? And does your CapEx Q2, perhaps components where you've got a considerable advantage and unlocking some of that capacity constraint will lead to even better margins?
Any color you could give us on the couple of places for you to stay -- at a broad level, that's great. Are there any specifics you could give us where you think you're going to make a bigger investment in some of the competition and your -- or where you would be pulling back?
Okay. That's helpful. And then I guess, I know we've talked about gross margin in different formats during the Q&A. But I'm wondering, if you go forward and you think about getting back to a higher gross margin level, how much of this quarter or how much of the move from 31% to 34% is a mix question? How much is capacity? So -- or how much more can you squeeze out on those 2 different vectors?
A couple of questions. Vis-à-vis that broad rebound in telecom that you mentioned, will you be able to isolate that regionally to being more weighted to China or North America, I mean, as most of that potential upside came from China? Can we say that? Or was it broad-based, spread broad-based across all the regions?
Okay. All right. And one other thing is I think last quarter that was a bit of a surprise -- well, it wasn't a surprise really, but just you incurred some issues qualifying the ROADMs, and potentially that's still a North America event at this point in time. But talk a little bit where we are on that qualification. Have we passed qualification issues? Are those behind you now and you're ready to ship this full speed?
Okay. Calendar '17, so that was my sort of follow-up. It's -- you're not really projecting that into your guidance yet for Q2?
Okay. Fair enough. And then lastly, maybe 1 or 2 more questions. One on the Wuxi, China facility. Could you remind us what type of products are being manufactured there? Datacom, telecom, a mix of both worlds, where you are on the ramp-up of these products. Just sort of an overview of that facility there.
All right. Well, great to see that transition had worked to your expectations, or better. And then maybe lastly then. On the 100-gig side and the pricing environment there, it sounds like the margins are holding up quite nicely just yet, and there's obviously a competitive dynamic developing around 100 gig and Web 2.0s and most of the RFPs that are pretty aggressive as far as what they're asked for on a price per gigabit. So can you comment a pretty benign sort of environment at this point in time? And on 100 gig, frankly, what are you expecting going forward?
First regarding CapEx. So first quarter was $30 million. What should we expect for second quarter as well as for fiscal '17?
Got it. And then specifically on WSS, it sounds like you added a little bit more than 10% last quarter. Are you kind of targeting similar capacity expansion this quarter?
Got it. And then on ACO, I just wanted to make sure. I think you talked about maybe shipping a few hundred units in first quarter. And are you still quite confident about shipping meaningful revenue by the end of this year? I guess that will be about fiscal third quarter or maybe fiscal fourth quarter at the latest.
Got it. And just regarding your 2 10% customers, I assume they are same 10% customers as of -- from the fiscal '16. Or were percentage of sales pretty comparable to last year's numbers as well?
They were like around, what, 12%, 13%, something like that in fiscal '16? And just wondering if they were kind of comparable in the first quarter as well.
So most of my questions have been answered. So first, a housekeeping question, though. Did I hear correctly that you expect the tax rate to be between 4% to 5% for the rest of the year?
Okay. And then so on line cards specifically, it sounds like -- based on the question by a gentleman ahead of me, it sounds like you're not expecting line card contribution on your October guide. But I wonder if you can walk us through the process of adding capacity and getting to production on line cards specifically. Is it similar to WSSs where you have to get the production in Wuxi, China, for which you have to hire staff, train staff and also add equipment? If that's the case and you're not qualified, what gives you confidence that we can see some revenues, for example in the January quarter?
I have a couple of questions really about kind of expectations heading into the quarter and how things turned out. I think last quarter, you've indicated expectations for growth on both the datacom and telecom side sequentially. You really didn't see that on the datacom side. I wonder if you could provide any color about kind of why that matter remains flat. And I say this what's on -- an eye on the go-forward guidance where if you do see kind of equal percentage increases, you'd be breaking out of this kind of 240-ish million range the datacom business has been in for a couple of years. And I wonder if you could talk to what the drivers of that might be.
And then as you look forward on the datacom side, it would seem like that you're seeing some nice growth in 100 gig, both QSFP28 and CFP. And at this point, you don't really expect much in the way of a negative offset from 10 and 40 gig and for that to remain flat and maybe for some of that growth to show through on a sequential basis. I don't know if that's right the way to look at it. And -- well, I'll leave it there.
And just to follow up real quickly. Would it be fair to say that 10-gig datacom was also flattish in the quarter that you're just reporting?
It's up a little bit. Okay. So one final question on the CFP2 ACO, I think you guys mentioned expectations for shipping hundreds to shipping several times that. In the current quarter, imagining that, that didn't happen, I wonder if could you comment on whether we're seeing expectations push out a little bit for the CFP2 ACO ramp? Because had you shipped several times, we'd be talking to a few hundred units, we'll be talking about more than $1 million to $2 million. So wondering if you can talk about kind of expectations there on the CFP2 ACO side, whether the timing is maybe a little bit different than you might have thought.
column11:
Your main ROADM competitor, I believe, this week said that they already have orders in hand for ROADMs in China for the near term. Do you have any commentary along the same lines you could share?
And will there be revenue from that included in the guidance you just gave?
Okay. Any commentary on sort of how that could ramp into a sort of a full run rate? Or how big or how long-lasting that project can be?
Okay, great. And then just one more for me would be on the annual price negotiations, can you share any color there of what's looking like this year? And should we be -- how much conservatism should we may be put into our April gross margin estimates, if any?
And Kurt, if we're seeing 2 months of that in April, I know you don't give more than 1 quarters of guidance at a time, but would you want us to take that into account? Or are there other factors where we could be flat in April?
So just a couple of things, if you could give us some detail on the actual kind of growth rate in the ROADM/wave selective switch quarter-to-quarter? And can you give us a little bit of a cut at 10-gig SAN in SIPRI?
Yes, if you can just give us a little bit more on what 10-gig did and what SAN did and what SIPRI did?
Is wireless now less than -- like less than $10 million kind of thing kind of trending around very de minimis amount?
Okay. And then SAN?
Going back to Mike's question about the China demand. I think he wasn't asking if ROADMs and wavelength switches were going to go into China -- for sale into China, but rather for use in China, which is a very different question. You've been selling ROADMs into China for years. Obviously, that's not the issue. The question is, are you shipping in the current quarter product for sale into China that would be used in China?
So along the same lines as the prior question on gross margins, as we look out into the April quarters, we've been bucking the trend here with very strong demand, you're seeing extremely robust situation, ramping capacity. Is it feasible to think about another year where we're not down sequentially on the top line in that quarter? I know -- I'm not looking for guidance, just sort of general conceptual thought process there.
I guess, first question to one of you is the status update on qualification for -- at Cisco for your ROADM line card. Also, I'd love as you guys would share what the QSFP28 revenue did sequentially in the quarter?
QSFP28. 100-gig revenue.
And that would happen again next quarter?
Just last one. You guys, it looks like you're joining the 3D sensing party, potentially here. I'm just wondering if you could speak to a little bit about what you think your revenue opportunity would be? I assume you're talking about for mobile device primarily and what do you think the dollar per phone could be. And when do you think that could ramp? It sounds like a lot of people will just going to ramp in the second half of next year. I'd just love to hear more on that.
Just a follow-up on James question there on the 3D sensing stuff. Could you answer the question about the dollar content for phone?
Okay, right. How about maybe for -- one more for Jerry here, just an update on the ACO status. Any new certifications, qualifications, yes, during the quarter?
Perfect. And just maybe one for your, Kurt. The story you've talked about 35% being the right gross margin level for this industry and, obviously, near term where we love that now and I think we can grow higher, I'd just like to hear your thoughts longer term about what you think the gross margin profile is for Finisar in this industry?
All right. And you said -- maybe just one follow-up on that. If you think about the 3D sensing opportunity, with the margins, gross margins on that be above corporate average?
Just to ask a little bit more on the CFP2 ACO. Can you help us understand your shipment levels, are we currently in the hundreds of units, several hundreds of units, just a ballpark there.
Great. And then, I guess, on capacity utilization in Wuxi. Can you help us understand where you stand there? And from a footprint perspective, should we expect any major facility expansions for Finisar?
Okay. And then on the QSFP28, can you give us a little more color on which variance are seeing the most demand or order, and then also the pricing dynamics within those products.
Great. And just last one, Kurt, on G&A, that's down nicely in the quarter. I believe you have some legal costs that rolled off, correct me if I'm wrong there. And how should we think about the -- just the level of G&A on a go-forward basis?
First one is on the datacom side. Can you give us a sense of how big 100 gig is now as a percentage of datacom? And then question on 3D sensing, I'm curious about kind of the generation of getting into that businesses. This is kind of the first time that we're hearing about you proactively going after it and adding capacity. Is this something, though, that you've been developing or working on or talking to customers or potential customers for a period of time? Or is this a recent shift in strategy?
Probably that was helpful. Then my question also on 100 gig as a percentage of datacom and then I wanted to have a follow-up.
Okay, perfect. And then finally one is related to the SAN business, but obviously a fairly large customer being acquired by someone that you could consider a competitor or alternative source. Can we get your early thoughts on what that impact maybe? And if there are any lessons to kind of gleam from the Emulex days?
I appreciate the detail. And maybe just to follow up on that, final one for me, how large is the SAN exposure at this point for the datacom business just so you can kind of help frame that.
I want to shift the discussion a little bit on service side optics, And with the Tomahawk pushing cloud operators to 25-gig and then 50-gig rates, do you foresee copper still being used in that environment? In my imagination sort of tells me maybe at 100 gig, you will have to almost go to fiber, but potentially fiber could adjust to 25-gig, 50-gig level as well. So as you go into that rack-server level optics environment, how is Finisar positioned for that opportunity? What's the timing? And how you're thinking about the TAM? I supposed that the opportunity for you in that kind of market shift is opening up?
A couple of things. One, I'm going to go back to a question I've asked you in the past to get an update if exposure you've had direct sales to web scale, how that may have moved around in this particular quarter?
Great. And in terms of the ROADM opportunity in China, specifically the deployment by Chinese carriers, we've heard some mix commentary about their choices of architecture, whether they would look at a legacy-type architecture and a low-count 1x9, or whether these operators would adopt something similar to the western vendors, maybe one by 20 with the CDC. It sounds like maybe there's some mix. I'd like to hear your thoughts in 2 parts in terms of what you expect the Chinese operators will deploy in terms of a mix of technologies for ROADMs and then what does that mean to Finisar?
And in terms of the timing on the Chinese operators for the 100-gig opportunity, specifically transceiver opportunities for you, what do you expect in terms of any of the seasonal patterns during the course of the year, the timing of the tenders some of what we've heard is this tends to be back-end loaded because of Chinese New Year and just the time it takes to route, review and assess tender bids. What's your view on the timing for those opportunities in calendar '17?
Maybe I'll start with the 100-gig QSFP question. Can you characterize the growth coming from -- is more of it coming from Web 2.0 direct sales or through OEMs? Can you give us some understanding of that would be great, please.
Both. Okay. How would you characterize your customer base on the web scale side for the QSFP28 products? Is it similar to singular customer or very broad based? Or how would you characterize that shift?
Okay. To that point, Jerry, when do you expect industry constraints to be overcome? Does that have to happen within the quarter or more like a half year? How do you view that?
Okay. And to follow on that topic, how do you expect it to read into the pricing trends? It seems like LR4 is less competitive space there, where we expect price to be better, but how about even on the CWM4 (sic) [CWDM4] format?
That's helpful. One last question for me on 100-gig or CFP2 ACO. You talked about some qualifications and more to come. Jerry, could you take a venture to guess what kind of share you might expect in this market, say, in a year's time? And also fruitfully, you've talked about your products being able to do 100 and 200, do you expect to be able to do 250 at some point in the near future? And how important would that be to do so?
Kurt, what was the CapEx for second quarter?
Okay. So regarding 3D sensing capacity, what's the current capacity? And how much are you planning to add next year?
Okay. And then regarding, Jerry, your comments about 3D sensing gross margin, you said some might be above and some might be below. I thought -- correct me if I'm wrong, but if you're selling chips, should they be nicely above corporate average since they will be similar to like semiconductor gross margin of, say, 50% or so?
Okay. Moving to WSS/ROADM business. What's the current mix? I assume WSS is still much bigger than ROADM at this point. What's the current mix at this point?
I'm assuming when you say qual, you're talking about the North American market. But what about China? Do you think it will be more WSS or ROADMs?
I'm talking about the Chinese network, but that will be going to Chinese networks.
Got it, got it. And then, I guess, you already talked about whether it's CD, CDC, hard to say. But what about the current orders that you have on hand? I mean, can you tell us whether they are CD or CDC at this point?
Got it. And then lastly, in case you're already sampling CFP2-DCO. So is there additional pressure for you and other ACO vendors to introduce CFP4 just to keep up with CFP2-DCO?
column12:
Jerry and Kurt, I guess given the stock action post market, the question I'm getting from investors is, how is this different than 2011? You walked us through some of the puts and takes on the lower guidance, I think, focusing on 100G CFP and also walked through some potential growth items through the remainder of this calendar year, but if you could maybe help us allay some fears here, that'd be great.
Great. And then, I guess, on QSFP28 side, Jerry, you said you're sold out, you're adding capacity and you should be sold out through at least calendar 2017. If we look back at Arista just a couple of weeks ago, they talked about optical supply constraint easing as early as this first calendar quarter. Is there any way you could help us maybe square their comments versus what you're seeing?
And just if I can sneak one more in -- thank you for the details on 3D sensing and generating revenue in the quarter, but I think certain -- I think investors in general see Finisar as having less of a market opportunity perhaps than competitors, given the perception of less capacity stemming from foreign VCSEL wafers that may be put you at a disadvantage per -- versus peers. I'm curious, is this perception wrong? And can you comment on whether you have the potential to generate similar levels of revenue that have been alluded to by your competitors?
So I guess, first one to sort of verify something. There's been some chatter about you guys having some product quality or qualification issues on a couple of different LR4 products. I want to clarify whether you've seen any of that. Is that at all creating a lack of offset as CFP rolls off? Can you just kind of clear the air on that issue?
Okay. How are -- in general, as you step back, I mean, how are you thinking about the CFP, CFP2, CFP4 business in aggregate this year? I mean, do we think that -- CFP has probably a higher ASP because of the gearbox and there's been some fluctuations issue in QSFP28 as well for LR4, but as you look at that bucket of CFP datacom modules, I mean, is that going to be a significant headwind in this calendar year?
I guess, to sort of close the loop in the qualification issues that you were talking about, is this temporary? Are you expecting this to be resolved in the next quarter or 2 or some finite period of time?
Maybe just a follow up on the qualification issues. Can you help us size or quantify out of the impact to the fiscal third quarter the fiscal fourth quarter guidance that you're anticipating from kind of these specific issues?
Well, I guess, maybe to address that specifically, what is the revenue impact of those technical issues that you're facing with customers? I mean, is it $5 million, $10 million in the quarter in the guidance?
Okay. Maybe another question on 3D sensing. Can you give us a sense, you've been adding capacity now pretty aggressively for 2 quarters. I mean, how much capacity do you anticipate being online by the second half of the year to service these customers -- or customer or customers? Can you give us a sense on how far down the road you'll be?
Okay, understood. And then maybe one final question, just looking out to next year. I know you just got it for fiscal fourth quarter, but looking into fiscal '18, any sense on if growth rates should accelerate or decelerate after coming out of '17, which is kind of mid-teens growth?
I was hoping you could slice and dice a couple of things a little bit more for us. Talk a little bit about what you're thinking on 10-gig, 40-gig and whether that business is now going to not just flatten out but actually start to roll over on a sequential basis going forward beyond the impact of the pricing. Obviously, to date, we haven't really seen most of the upgrades kick in, in the scale-out data centers because there's been other constraints, but that looks like it's going to resolve itself. So is that going to start to roll over more aggressively?
Can you give us some sense on what's going on in the fiber channel segment in the market in the quarter trading and [indiscernible]?
So seasonal decline on pricing and then just flattish on volume?
One more product area, the SIPRI, and you actually mentioned it in your prepared remarks, the sub-10-gig stuff. I'm assuming that, that's down to very low single-digit kind of revenue levels and that it's not anticipated that, that's going to change in a meaningful way. I was a little surprised to hear it. I thought it was already small enough to have fallen out of the mix. Can you talk about what your plans are there, whether you're going to use any capacity in that space or whether you're going to continue to keep it at very low levels?
One last question, just on the telco side, excluding the ROADM wave selective switch stuff, what was the trajectory of the non-ROADM non-wave selective telco switch business?
Okay. So it was down revenues and volume? Or just down on pricing?
I wanted to focus a little bit on gross margins. I know if you go through historically where margins have peaked, there have been periods where it was -- gross margin grew significantly because of specific product launches and I guess, monopoly types of activity. If you look at what's going on in the -- for the fourth quarter in the guidance, which seems to be pricing and a little bit of mix, how should we think about the opportunities with some of these new products coming out, VCSELs and things like that, and where margins can go from here for the next 12 to 18 months?
Okay. And then just kind of a follow up on some questions that have been with the VCSEL expansion and the CapEx. If you look at that CapEx that you're shipping and there's going to be revenue in the second half, do you -- are you working on one application or are there multiple end markets where -- that are interesting right now to just start with one area and potentially move further along into other consumer electronics sorts of applications? Are you seeing designs for that already?
And how independent -- I mean, if you don't sell all the pieces that would go into a module that would do the 3D sensing, are you just selling independently or are you working with integrators and the other components that go into making these modules work?
A quick follow up on -- James had asked a question, Jerry, about I think these quality issues for the QSFP28 LR4 and I thought your answer was more on CFP. So could you just talk about any issues on the LR4?
Okay. Understood. And just to understand, Jerry, on 3D sensing, I think I heard 2 different answers. Your belief in an inflection in this space, was that at the end of this calendar year '17 or the end of fiscal year '18?
Middle of '17. And would you say that your conviction on that infection happening now is higher than what it was just 3 months ago?
This is Mauricio in for Simon today. Can you guys talk about the ROADM opportunity in China? It looks like your visibility improved, and just wanted to know if you could talk about your expectations from the timing of the deployments, volume wise, and maybe provide some quantifications on the revenue opportunity and the mix. By mix, I mean, the more -- the ROADM select versus the more legacy broadcast select?
Then on the Verizon Metro project, do you now expect obtaining qualification on a major OEM for this 100-gig Metro initiative? And I think you mentioned that the timing was early in fiscal year '18. Did I get that right?
Okay. Then given that the bulk of your ROADM revenues clearly come from sales of WSS and other components employed to make a blade, how should we think in terms of revenue and profit margins once you start obtaining qualifications on these -- on the North American project where -- differently than China. OEMs in North America, they seem to be adopting the entire ROADM blade rather than outsourcing WSS and building their own solution in-house.
So what is the revenue margin profile of filling the entire blade versus just filling the sub-components, WSS and other components?
I guess, just few for me, and I'll start -- probably one for Jerry on 3D sensing. You talked about a big pick up in the second half of the year, and I think from some other answers you gave to previous questions, it sounds like you're having a breadth of customers driving this. Can you characterize that a little bit more? Is that dominated by any particular one or is this more broad? And it's also, if you could maybe lay out the competitive landscape there as you're seeing it right now that would be great to hear.
Okay. And I apologize, Jerry, I may have misspoke it, the essence of my question is basically regarding 3D sensing. So I apologize if I misstated that, but can you lay out kind of the competitive landscape there and the breadth of demand you're seeing in that area?
Okay. Great, that's great to hear, Jerry. The other question on the CFP2 ACO, and I might have missed the entire essence of your prepared remarks there, but if you could clarify how many qualifications you have now, how many you might expect over the next quarter or 2? And then do you have any expectations of what kind of share you might able to generate looking a year out or so? Any perspective there would be great.
Okay, fair enough. My last quick question, for your guidance for the April quarter, can you characterize how much you're expecting from ROADMs, specifically from Verizon and/or from the ACOs?
Question kind of on the historic seasonality on the telecom side and relative growth rates in telecom and datacom. I think last year, you saw quite a -- similar type decline in telecom in Q4 sequentially, maybe with some different drivers, and maybe that's why I had you modeled down overall sequentially for Q4 here heading in. But I wondered -- it looks like even with that decline sequentially in telecom, you're going to be up mid-20s on a year-over-year basis. So wonder if you could compare the 2 kind of sequential declines on the telecom side, the one you saw last year versus this year, obviously, at higher levels. And then that brings the fiscal year in at 20-something percent growth on the telecom side versus low teens, datacom. I wonder if you expect, leaving 3D sensing aside, that kind of mix of growth rates to change as you look forward into fiscal '18.
Okay. So it sounds like your baseline expectations for maybe those growth rates to reverse, if any -- not -- I'm not talking about absolute levels, but to the extent telecom grew faster -- significantly faster than datacom in '17, sounds like you expect that to potentially reverse in '18, subject to some of these kind of qualification, fairly binary issues that you discussed or the various [indiscernible] you said there.
And Kurt, the other question was about Q4 seasonality in telecom this year versus last year. Is there any sort of commentary that you have?
Got it. And final question for me, clearly, as you've noted, your cash balance increased pretty significantly in the quarter due to the convert. I think there is an assumption here that you're looking to do something with that cash over time. I wonder if you can update us with your views on the potential attractiveness of consolidation in the industry and maybe with an eye toward addressing some of the qualification issues on the telecom side that you've been struggling with or really, any other way you want to approach it. How are you thinking about consolidation here now that you've got the convert in the back?
To start with just a clarification, is -- QSFP28, do you have some of it counted in datacom and some of it counted in telecom?
Okay. Because I thought earlier, you talked about CFP as a telecom product in China, so I thought maybe...
Okay, perfect. On the QSFP28, you mentioned being sold out in the hyperscale market. Are you also sold out in the Chinese market as well?
Okay. And then finally for me, I see a lot of positives for fiscal '18 here, but also, we did miss the numbers and the guidance that was just put up. So I was just wondering if you could reconcile -- I mean, I've heard maybe some CFP weakness and some pricing declines. Are there any other reasons -- how would you describe the reasons for the miss?

column2: Eitan Gertel Former Chief Executive Officer and Director
column3: Eitan Gertel Former Chief Executive Officer and Director
column4: Eitan Gertel Former Chief Executive Officer and Director
column5: Eitan Gertel Chief Executive Officer and Director

column2:
Thanks, Kurt. During the quarter, we completed the acquisition of LightSmyth Technologies of Eugene, Oregon. LightSmyth is a pioneer in the use of semiconductor manufacturing tools to produce differentiated high-performance and cost-effective grating products.


LightSmyth, previously, was a supplier of grating for Finisar's WSS ROADM products. This acquisition further enhanced Finisar's vertical integration strategy. And the acquisition is not expected to be material from an revenue or earnings per share basis.


With respect to new products, we are making excellent progress on the development of our 100G CFP2 coherent module, which we utilized our vertically integrated advanced indium phosphide lasers, modulators and receiver components. We believe we will have an industry-leading product in terms of power consumption and performance for both metro and long-haul coherent applications.
