We are continuing to ship qualification samples of our 10G tunable SFP+ to many of our customers. As a result of our next-generation vertically integrated optics, we continue to believe we will have the lowest power consumption module in the industry of approximately 1.5 watts.


Our standard and low-profile dual wavelength selective switches program is progressing very well. Due to our long history of developing innovative LCoS-based devices and WSS products, we are offering our customers a higher level of performance than they can obtain from any other solutions. Our designs are using common platform that can address multiple markets and give our customers the flexibility of buying one product that can be deployed in many different configurations.


While demands for our transceivers that address Wireless applications was very strong in the first quarter, demand of these products is expected to decrease in the second quarter. We expect the demands to return and the revenues to increase sequentially for these products during the third quarter based on continued LTE deployments around the world but especially in China. We have a very broad portfolio of short- and long-reach and various data rate solutions for these important markets.


In datacom, we have production-released our 100G CFP2 LR4 and are seeing a very strong demand for this product. Due to our vertical integration of the lasers and receivers, our module consumed the lowest power amount, the lowest power consumption of any other solution in the market. We are currently adding capacity in order to shorten the lead times and address opportunities to expect -- expand our market share.


In the 40G datacom market, we believe we have the broadest portfolio in the market for both transceivers and active optical cables in the single or multimode configurations. And finally, we have several exciting product announcements and demonstrations scheduled for the ECOC trade show in Cannes, France later this month.


And now, I'll turn the call over to Jerry for some final comments. Jerry?
I think it's all of the things you say. I mean, mix is affecting the gross margin. We continue to take the costs out of the product. The product continues to be competitive in the market too. So we don't expect this to be getting into -- this product to get into the average -- corporate average gross margin. And we actually said that before. This is accretive to our earnings per share, and it's a very little R&D, if no R&D. So basically, the return on invested capital is still where it needs to be. And we are reducing the impact as we go along, but we don't expect it to be in the average or for average gross margin.
I think my comments regarding the gross margin improvement not meeting the mid -- the average corporate gross margin was related to the Wireless business only.
So Joseph, if you look from a product point of view, their gratings are sitting in a majority of our products right now and I would expect them in the next year or 2 to be in all our products. Now, if you look at how they integrate to the rest of the products, it's not only in WSS they're going to help. We see them as a broader -- as a supplier for a much broader product, which is not only WSS.
Please, I'm sorry, I didn't hear you.
This is a fab. So basically, when they make their components, it's an ISC type. So the packaging is going to move to China, but the fab itself stays where it is.
So -- your question is about telecom, you mean telecom has been soft for a while but there's a number of products we're developing, which we think have a very -- great growth drivers. So on the WSS side, we continue to develop new products. We have new line cards. It's customer-specific so we can't talk about which one is qualified where, but we can say all our projects are on schedule for qualification. Has demand been what we expected it to be? No, it has been softer than we expected it to be on the line card, but as far as all our new projects, the new line cards meeting their targets on qualification, the answer is -- it's yes. And that means we have the share we expected. As far as new -- exciting opportunities in the telecom side is we have a significant program, which one of them we talked about in this call about the coherent product and we think that represents a significant opportunity for the company and we expect to be the only leader or one of the leaders in this business with our execution on this program. Our tunable XFP is doing great in the market. So if you combine all these opportunities, we think there is a great opportunity. And those parts are used in telecom and datacom together, because in some cases there is no more differentiation. Telecom, datacom, it's just the functionality of the part itself.
Not the line card but when this coherent becomes a pluggable product like the CFP2, which is the product that's supposed to be in the customer's end in alpha mode. But before the end of this calendar year, the answer is yes.
column3:
Thanks, Kurt. Our R&D spending in the second quarter was about $45 million, down slightly from Q1. Our projects and technology centers are spread around the world: U.S., China, Australia, Israel and Europe.


We are pleased with our new product development efforts in devices, ICs and modules, and our ability to ramp those new products into production volumes at our manufacturing sites.


At ECOC in September, we demonstrated our next-generation ROADM technology, including our low-profile Dual 1x20 Wavelength Selective Switch and a new high-resolution Optical Channel Monitor.


In Q2, Finisar also demonstrated 100 gigabit QSFP28 Active Optical Cable, the first of several new products in the QSFP28 form factor.


We continue to make excellent progress on our development of our 100 gigabit CFP2 coherent module. Industry analysts forecast 100G coherent transceiver markets to be approximately $400 million in calendar year 2016.


We expect our overall product development to be maintained at a similar level as Q2 so that our R&D investments will be about $46 million for our third quarter.


Now I'll turn the call back to Jerry for some final comments.
In the telecom, I mean, the actual strength of metro is we expect it to be in the mid-2015. So right now, we don't expect significant growth in telecom. We have some new products going into the market on a regular basis. So we see moderate growth, fluctuating with the market. But the significant growth we expect to happen when metro upgrades will be a reality.
Yes, it depends on the timing of the switches. I think a lot of people are talking about deploying I/O, 25 gig I/Os. And our modules are going to be ready between next year to the next 2 years depending on the modules, specifically. But it's -- more of that is driven by the time of deployment of the 25 gig I/Os.
For us, our schedule as we said, I think even in the last call, we said by the end of the year, we're sampling our customers. And by mid-next year, we expect to be in full production. We are dealing with a large number of customers, so we expect this transformation into the pluggable devices to be pretty wide industry and a big opportunity for us. As far as the actual timing and how they ramp, we roughly say it's the second half of next year. But from what we see it's not only new customers who were -- it includes customers who were actually building line cards before and want to transfer to pluggable devices, so the opportunity is pretty sizable.
I think for geographic comments, it's hard to -- for us to see where the demand is because we have customers who are located geographically but they deploy their equipment in other geographies. But we didn't see substantial difference from what was in the last few quarters. So the behavior was not substantially different. I mean, so -- but overall, if you see the softness in the telecom, it came pretty evenly across the geographies.
You mean the 100 gig coherent?
I mean, we look at it as opportunity because if you look at the cost dynamics of 100 gig coherent when it started, it was a very expensive solution. And as more and more are being deployed, the cost effectiveness is coming around the DSP and their optics is becoming the majority of the costs. And our efforts in our pluggable CFP2 coherent is to bring more effectiveness and enable the higher density. And basically, the people who make the DSP let them optimize their business and their core competency, but we supply an optical module to fit everybody's DSP. So we think the opportunity here is to help our customers reduce their costs and help the 100G coherent proliferate much deeper into the network when you enable lower cost and higher efficiency.
Let's see if I remember all your questions. So you're started asking me about silicon photonics. Look, for us, silicon photonics is just another technology. We have many technologies and we don't intend to specify each technology to each product. Are we working on silicon photonics? We have projects on silicon photonics we have demonstrated in ECOC, which we think is one of the most advanced modules in the market for silicon photonics on 2x50 gigahertz -- 2x50 gigabits, sorry. And it was on fully integrated transceiver. But the way we look at it is we will match any application with the most cost-effective and best performance for our customers. Silicon photonics for us is just another technology that we can use. I think the important message here is we have indium phosphide, we have silicon photonics, we don't need to buy anybody, we don't need to have major revamp in our operation to use it. And we'll use them as our products need them.
I don't know what the number is, but I think we still have capacity issues to deliver the market whatever they want to buy and we're still ramping capacity on our products.
column4:
Thanks, Kurt. We expect revenues for our fourth quarter will be in the range of $310 million to $330 million. Please note that the fourth quarter fiscal 2015 will have 14 weeks compared to 13 weeks in prior quarter. However, the positive benefit of the revenues for extra week in the quarter will be partially offset by the impact of the Chinese New Year, which occurred in February. We expect non-GAAP gross margins to be approximately 30% primarily due to the impact of full 3 months of the annual telecom price reductions. Non-GAAP operating expenses are expected to increase primarily due to the extra week relative to the prior quarter. Non-GAAP operating margins are expected to be approximately 8% to 9%. Non-GAAP earnings per diluted share are expected to be in the range of $0.22 to $0.28 per share. As a reminder, our first quarter of fiscal 2016 will once again have 13 weeks relative to 14 weeks in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015. We continue to believe in the long-term growth prospects of the company. Finisar revenue is driven primarily by growth in the worldwide demand for bandwidth with ever-increasing distribution and use of video, images and digital information. In addition, Finisar continues to benefit from growth in cloud services which drive networking hardware upgrades of existing data centers and build-outs of new hyperscale data centers.
And now, with that, I'm going to turn back over the call to Matt to open it up for questions.

Question and Answer
.....................................................................................................................................................................................................................
I mean, currently, we -- Subu -- we're investing in the most strategic products that we think is going to have the growth. And obviously in the product that's not going to give us the return investment, we're reducing the level of R&D. So obviously, we have big investments going in coherent and some level of ROADMs and other things and SFP+. So we choose our products and we try to match what we expect from the growth and what we expect the best return to be.
Well, I think if you look at the long term, I'm still hoping that this thing would be coming back to the $100 million level. I can't tell exactly when that happen. It's actually -- it's all the ramp up of new products, it's the impact of all the upgrades in the metro and actually some of the telecom products spreading to and going into non-telecom application with telecom-type products. So all those combined together should help grow the revenue but, on the long term, I expect that to be in the $100 million level.
I think, Simon, the answer to that is, I don't know, because a lot of equipment that goes in the edge of the submarine line is the regular equipment we sell to other telco applications. So we know there are some submarine lines looking at equipment from us, but we don't know how much of it is going to either one of the applications. Some of them are starting to look at the high data rate coherence and things like that, but there's still time to go for that to be meaningful. But the rest of it, I wouldn't know how to break it down.
Well, it -- I mean, I think majority of it is in the telco side but, again, I don't have the visibility to them.
Well, the backhaul equipment, which we talked -- the wireless, we talked about China, was slightly up this quarter, not much. And we predicted to be slightly up again, but not in any significance. So the level is flat to slightly up over the prior quarter and the quarter looking forward. And the margin impact of those is the same as it was before. It's below our corporate average.
I would say we're shipping samples to customers. Customers have received our sample have a very good respond, are very happy with our performance. There are some cases they're surprised with the performance. But it's early days and we're in the alpha stage. And as far as the program versus our schedule, I would say plus, minus couple of weeks we're on schedule. So we expect to continue with the program and continue with the ramp. It's a significant product program from us and again we're excited about the performance and level we can achieve from this module.
I don't think we are excluded from any deployment. Our ROADM business, we don't break it down but it's doing fine. It's not growing tremendously, but it's pretty flat quarter-over-quarter and we have significant share in the market. I don't think our share changes -- our share has changed in the market in any meaningful way. And we actually have high expectations for the market going forward from our ROADM play actually in the metro projects that you're talking about. So I don't think not all but lost any step in this market and I think our new products are playing very well. But I haven't -- we haven't seen growth yet and that's what we're looking for. But the product line itself is working fine.
Look, I mean, the only thing I can say -- we can't talk about specific customers because we can't comment on what one customer does versus others. All I can say, we have share in all of them. And when everybody wins -- when each one of them wins, I mean, we benefit from one versus the other. And maybe in some different weights or issues, but we do. But I can't comment on a specific customer versus others.
And we don't have any meaningful telecom below 10G, anyway.
No, we can't.
column5:
Well, Patrick, last quarter, we started shipping -- demonstrating basically alpha products. And we've continued ramping our shipment to customers, and we -- as we said before, we see that being more meaningful to our revenue towards the end of the calendar year. So we continue to ship units for 100 Gb application and 200 Gb application in the CFP2 format.
It's -- I think the growth we've seen to date is from existing product that we had shipped before and we start to see ramp from new products, from a lot of our dual product lines. So we expect that, that will be favorable for the WSS as we move along the year.
I think it stays the same. We don't change the date. I think the meaningful demand from this is beginning of next calendar year as the deployment, I don't think, have started in significant -- significantly right now. But we -- it is happening. From all the public announcements, you see its happening. And what was the other question?
But in general, I would say all the products that we have, the highest gross margin come from our newer products, and the big coherent is a product line. I mean, the CFP2 product is the first product of it. So in the future, we see more and more impact of those products coming into the mix of the gross margin and they affect us positively.
We think we have a very competitive product. We think from the best of our knowledge is we have the only product in the market that's already sampling -- that does 100 and 200 Gb on the same device as is today. So your limitation is on your DSP, not on the optics. And going forward, we are -- our plan is to get a significant market share. What that will be, time will tell, but we treat it extremely seriously. All the components are made inside, so we are fully vertically-integrated on the product. And as we come into GA, the full product is going to be manufactured in our Asian facility. So it's planned to be a significant ramp for us.
I think it's more important on the later generations than immediate. But when people are getting the product, they have both capabilities available for them Day 1 from us. Effectively, if you can run 200 Gb, your cost per bit is close to 50%, than what you run on 100 Gb because the cost of the hardware is the same. So I think from that point of view, it's important. But the timing when people are actually utilizing the 200 versus the 100 will depend on the customers themselves. But we believe getting into the market with a product that enables this Day 1 is a significant improvement or significant edge.
